question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of behavioral problems. His mother says that he has frequent angry outbursts and gets into fights with his classmates. He constantly complains of feeling hungry, even after eating a full meal. He has no siblings, and both of his parents are healthy. He is at the 25^th percentile for height and is above the 95^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows central obesity, undescended testes, almond-shaped eyes, and a thin upper lip. Which of the following genetic changes is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of behavioral problems. His mother says that he has frequent angry outbursts and gets into fights with his classmates. He constantly complains of feeling hungry, even after eating a full meal. He has no siblings, and both of his parents are healthy. He is at the 25th percentile for height and is above the 95th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows central obesity, undescended testes, almond-shaped eyes, and a thin upper lip. Which of the following genetic changes is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
hint: This boy presents with behavioral problems, short stature, hyperphagia, facial dysmorphism, and cryptorchidism, which is consistent with Prader-Willi syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Prader-Willi syndrome, and recall its genetic etiology.

answers.content: De novo mutation of MECP2 on X chromosome
answers.explanation_why: Sporadic, de novo mutations of the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome are responsible for most cases of Rett syndrome. Germline mutations inherited from phenotypically normal mothers can also occur, but are rare. Rett syndrome almost exclusively affects females and manifests with progressive loss of intelligence, cognitive abilities, and fine motor skills.

answers.content: Microdeletion of long arm of chromosome 7
answers.explanation_why: Microdeletion of the long arm of chromosome 7, which contains the elastin gene, causes Williams syndrome. This patient's constellation of features does not suggest Williams syndrome.

answers.content: Mutation of FBN-1 gene on chromosome 15
answers.explanation_why: Mutation of the FBN-1 gene on chromosome 15 results in Marfan syndrome. Because this condition is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner with variable penetrance, one parent is usually affected, which is not the case here. This child's features do not resemble those found in Marfan syndrome.

Mitotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21 results in mosaic trisomy 21, which accounts for 1–2% of trisomy 21 cases. In these cases, two cell lines and thus two karyotypes are present, and the phenotypic expression varies according to the ratio of healthy to trisomic cells. Although cryptorchidism and obesity are common features of trisomy 21, this patient's behavioral problems, hyperphagia, and facial dysmorphism suggest a different genetic condition.

answers.content: Deletion of Phe508 on maternal chromosome 7
answers.explanation_why: Deletion of the phenylalanine codon at position 508 of the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 is the most common mutation in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). Because CF is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, the deletion would need to be present in both the maternal and paternal chromosomes for the fetus to develop the condition. This patient's constellation of features is not consistent with cystic fibrosis.

Mutation or deletion on the paternal chromosome 15 (at 15q11–q13) in combination with genomic imprinting (i.e., silencing) via methylation of the maternal chromosome 15 (also at 15q11–q13) results in Prader-Willi syndrome.

Imprinting of the paternal allele in combination with a microdeletion of the same region on the maternal chromosome 15 would result in Angelman syndrome.

question_text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of chronic cough, sinus pain, and nasal discharge. He has a history of frequent upper respiratory infections and recurrent sinusitis since childhood. He is also concerned about fertility, as he and his wife have been trying to conceive for 5 years unsuccessfully. Pulmonary examination shows crackles and wheezing throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a defect in which of the following molecular structures?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of chronic cough, sinus pain, and nasal discharge. He has a history of frequent upper respiratory infections and recurrent sinusitis since childhood. He is also concerned about fertility, as he and his wife have been trying to conceive for 5 years unsuccessfully. Pulmonary examination shows crackles and wheezing throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a defect in which of the following molecular structures?
hint: The CT scan of the chest shows dextrocardia, a condition in which the heart's apex is located on the right side of the body.
learning_objective: Recognize primary ciliary dyskinesia, and recall its associated molecular defect.

answers.explanation_why: A defect in the IL-12 receptor causes IL-12 receptor deficiency, which leads to decreased Th1 cell function and thus increases the risk of developing disseminated mycobacterial, Salmonella species, and fungal infections. This defect would not explain this patient's infertility or dextrocardia.

A defect in the IL-2R gamma chain is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), which causes recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, similar to this patient's history. However, SCID typically causes severe (and often fatal) infections within the first year of life unless the underlying defect is corrected with bone marrow transplantation, making this condition unlikely in this 31-year-old man. Additionally, this defect would not explain this patient's infertility or dextrocardia.

A defect in NADPH oxidase causes chronic granulomatous disease, which manifests with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, similar to this patient's history. These infections are most often caused by catalase-positive organisms because neutrophils are unable to produce reactive oxygen species that attack these pathogens. However, chronic granulomatous disease does not cause infertility or dextrocardia.

The underlying cause of cystic fibrosis is a defective or deficient CFTR protein in the apical membrane of epithelial cells, which results in decreased secretion of chloride ions and water. This leads to hyperviscosity of fluid in the lungs that impairs mucociliary clearance and causes chronic sinusitis and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Cystic fibrosis also causes infertility (due to congenital absence of the vas deferens in men and abnormally thick cervical mucus in women). Though this patient has all of these features, cystic fibrosis does not cause dextrocardia.

A defect in axonemal dynein arms renders cilia immotile and is one cause of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). Impaired ciliary function reduces mucociliary clearance, resulting in bronchiectasis (due to recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, which are responsible for this patient's crackles and wheezing on examination) and chronic sinusitis. It also renders sperm immotile, which reduces fertility, and can cause dextrocardia (because cilia are responsible for the position of internal organs during embryological development). Other clinical features of PCD include chronic otitis media and conductive hearing loss. Kartagener syndrome is a subtype of PCD characterized by the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

Primary ciliary dyskinesia can also be caused by defects in ciliary assembly proteins or radial spokes.

A defect in α-1 antitrypsin causes α-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which results in increased protease activity in the lungs and destruction of the pulmonary architecture. As a result, patients have an increased risk of developing recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, similar to this patient's history. However, this condition does not cause chronic sinusitis, infertility, or dextrocardia. Instead, it is associated with cirrhosis (due to aggregation of misfolded α-1 antitrypsin).

images.title: Dextrocardia in Kartagener syndrome
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)The base-to-apex cardiac axis is directed to the patient's right (dextrocardia). The right ventricle (RV) and left ventricle (LV) are reversed. This patient also presented with right to left reversal of the morphologic atria and abdominal organs (situs inversus; not shown).Dextrocardia with situs inversus is part of the triad of manifestations seen in Kartagener syndrome, which also includes chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis.

question_text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after his right arm was burned by a fire. He is diagnosed with extensive third-degree burns of the right forearm and upper arm and is admitted to the hospital for debridement and grafting. During his stay in the hospital, he suddenly develops confusion and agitation. Neurologic examination shows horizontal nystagmus and a broad-based gait. Laboratory studies show decreased erythrocyte transketolase activity. Administration of which of the following most likely caused this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after his right arm was burned by a fire. He is diagnosed with extensive third-degree burns of the right forearm and upper arm and is admitted to the hospital for debridement and grafting. During his stay in the hospital, he suddenly develops confusion and agitation. Neurologic examination shows horizontal nystagmus and a broad-based gait. Laboratory studies show decreased erythrocyte transketolase activity. Administration of which of the following most likely caused this patient's current condition?
hint: The triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia suggests Wernicke encephalopathy, which is due to deficiency of thiamine (most commonly seen in patients with alcohol use disorder). Decreased activity of the enzyme erythrocyte transketolase, which uses thiamine as a cofactor, is diagnostic of Wernicke encephalopathy.
learning_objective: Recognize Wernicke encephalopathy, and recall the effects of administering glucose without thiamine.

answers.explanation_why: Cobalamin (vitamin B_12) serves as a cofactor in enzymatic reactions responsible for red blood cell formation and myelination of the nervous system. Deficiency is seen in malnourished patients (e.g., due to chronic alcoholism) and manifests with chronic neurologic symptoms, including gait abnormalities. However, supplementation of cobalamin would improve symptoms, not worsen them. Moreover, cobalamin is not known to precipitate Wernicke encephalopathy. Other features of cobalamin deficiency include macrocytic anemia, mild icterus, and glossitis, as well as symmetric peripheral neuropathy, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, and neuropsychiatric disease.

The active form of thiamine, thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), serves as a cofactor for dehydrogenases such as pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, both enzymes that are essential for ATP generation. Thiamine deficiency (e.g., due to malnutrition or chronic heavy drinking) leads to ATP depletion, which primarily damages highly aerobic tissues such as CNS neurons. Infusing glucose in a patient with thiamine deficiency without administering thiamine beforehand precipitates Wernicke encephalopathy. The presence of glucose drives glycolysis, which leads to the production of pyruvate, and the lack of thiamine results in an impaired pyruvate dehydrogenase complex. The pyruvate cannot be metabolized into acetyl-CoA and enter the citric acid cycle, so the excess pyruvate is instead reduced into cytotoxic amounts of lactate. In addition, as a cofactor for the transketolase reaction of the NADPH-producing pentose phosphate pathway, TPP is also essential for the regeneration of the antioxidant glutathione. Decreased glutathione regeneration due to thiamine deficiency impairs free radical neutralization, causing further cell damage.

Aspirin is an NSAID and, if administered during viral infections, may in rare cases cause acute encephalopathy (Reye syndrome). Typical early manifestations include vomiting, lethargy, and signs of hepatic failure. Agitation, horizontal nystagmus, or gait disorders would not be expected. Moreover, this condition is generally considered a childhood disease, and laboratory studies would not show decreased erythrocyte transketolase activity. Finally, aspirin is not known to cause Wernicke encephalopathy.

Disulfiram can be used to treat patients with alcohol use disorder. This drug increases the negative side effects of alcohol ingestion by inhibiting acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. Rapid accumulation of acetaldehyde after alcohol consumption results in intoxication symptoms such as nausea, vertigo, and confusion. However, nystagmus or gait disturbances would not be expected. Administration of disulfiram is not known to precipitate Wernicke encephalopathy.

Overly rapid correction of severe hyponatremia with hypertonic saline infusions can cause osmotic demyelination syndrome. Symptoms appear a few days after correction of hyponatremia and include an altered level of consciousness, coma, locked-in syndrome, dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia, and/or worsening quadriparesis. Agitation, horizontal nystagmus, or gait disorders would not be expected. Administration of hypertonic saline does not cause Wernicke encephalopathy.

Clindamycin is an antibiotic mainly used in the treatment of infections with anaerobes. Adverse effects include pseudomembranous colitis, which manifests with watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. However, neurological symptoms would not be expected. Moreover, clindamycin does not precipitate Wernicke encephalopathy.

Haloperidol is occasionally used in the management of severe agitation during alcohol withdrawal. Extrapyramidal symptoms, including gait disturbances, are common side effects. However, confusion, agitation, and horizontal nystagmus would not be seen. Haloperidol is not a known precipitant of Wernicke encephalopathy.

question_text: A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and weakness. His mother reports that he has difficulty feeding. He is at the 20^th percentile for height and 3^rd percentile for weight. Physical examination shows an enlarged tongue. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum glucose is 95 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows cardiomegaly. The patient most likely has a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
content_preview: A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and weakness. His mother reports that he has difficulty feeding. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 3rd percentile for weight. Physical examination shows an enlarged tongue. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum glucose is 95 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows cardiomegaly. The patient most likely has a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
hint: This child's failure to thrive, generalized hypotonia, signs of heart failure due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (e.g., pulmonary edema, cardiomegaly), macroglossia, and normal serum glucose suggest Pompe disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Pompe disease, and recall the deficient enzyme.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase causes Pompe disease. Without this enzyme, the conversion of glycogen to glucose in the lysosome cannot be completed and glycogen buildup becomes toxic to numerous cells, predominantly skeletal and cardiac muscle cells. Pompe disease does not present with hypoglycemia because glycolysis and gluconeogenesis do not depend on lysosomal glycogenolysis.

Myophosphorylase deficiency causes McArdle disease, which can cause fatigue and weakness. However, the onset is usually during adolescence or early adulthood. Macroglossia and features of heart failure would not occur because McArdle disease only affects skeletal muscles.

Iduronate sulfatase deficiency causes Hunter syndrome, which would almost exclusively affect males (X-linked recessive disorder). Failure to thrive, macroglossia, and heart failure (due to valvular heart disease) can also occur with severe forms of Hunter syndrome. However, the clinical features of Hunter disease typically do not manifest before the first year of life.

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase causes von Gierke disease, which can present with failure to thrive, easy fatiguability, and heart failure during infancy. However, hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly would be expected, and macroglossia would not occur. This patient's liver does not meet the definition of hepatomegaly since the liver is physiologically palpable 1–2 cm below the costal margin in infants and toddlers.

Beta-glucocerebrosidase deficiency causes Gaucher disease, which can cause failure to thrive during infancy. However, other manifestations such as skeletal abnormalities (e.g., osteoporosis, aseptic necrosis of the femoral head, painful bone crises), hepatosplenomegaly, and/or pancytopenia (bleeding, recurrent infections) would also be expected. Neurological disease occurs in less common forms of Gaucher disease (type 2 and 3) but presents as progressive spasticity (not hypotonia). Cardiac involvement in Gaucher disease is uncommon.

Alpha-galactosidase deficiency causes Fabry disease, which would almost exclusively affect males (X-linked recessive disorder) and cause failure to thrive. However, the onset of symptoms is usually during childhood or adolescence, and patients typically present with angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, recurrent abdominal pain, corneal clouding, tinnitus, hearing loss, and/or acral paresthesias. Heart failure is less common and typically a late manifestation. Macroglossia would not be expected.

question_text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of diffuse bone pain in his right leg. His family immigrated to the United States 6 months ago from northern Canada. He is below the 5^th percentile for height and at the 10^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the right distal femur. There is hepatosplenomegaly. An x-ray of right femur shows generalized trabecular thinning and several osteolytic bone lesions. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
9.2 g/dL

Leukocyte count
7,600/mm^3

Platelets
71,000/mm^3

A bone marrow aspirate shows mononuclear cells filled with lipid that appear like wrinkled silk. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of diffuse bone pain in his right leg. His family immigrated to the United States 6 months ago from northern Canada. He is below the 5th percentile for height and at the 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the right distal femur. There is hepatosplenomegaly. An x-ray of right femur shows generalized trabecular thinning and several osteolytic bone lesions. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL Leukocyte count 7,600/mm3 Platelets 71,000/mm3 A bone marrow aspirate shows mononuclear cells filled with lipid that appear like wrinkled silk. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lipid-filled macrophages that resemble crumbled silk. These clinical findings are characteristic of a disease that, in one of its more severe variants, can feature congenital ichthyosis (“collodion baby”).
learning_objective: Recognize Gaucher disease, and recall the deficient enzyme.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of sphingomyelinase is the cause of Niemann-Pick disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. While developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly are features of Niemann-Pick disease, osteolytic bone lesions and anemia would not be expected. Also, “cherry-red” spots on the macula is a feature of the condition that is not seen in this patient. Although bone marrow aspirate of a patient with Niemann-Pick disease would show lipid-laden macrophages, they would not resemble wrinkled silk.

A deficiency of α-galactosidase A is the cause of Fabry disease, the only x-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease. Osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, developmental delay, and lipid-filled macrophages would not be expected in this disease. Early clinical manifestations of the condition include peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas, and corneal opacities. Late clinical signs include cardiomyopathy, cerebrovascular events, and Fabry nephropathy. This patient has none of these clinical features.

A deficiency of Arylsulfatase A is the cause of metachromatic leukodystrophy, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. Although developmental delay is a feature of this condition, osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lipid-filled macrophages would not be expected. Also, ataxia, dementia, and peripheral neuropathy are features of childhood- and juvenile-onset metachromatic leukodystrophy that are not seen in this patient.

A deficiency of galactocerebrosidase is the cause of Krabbe disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. Although developmental delay is a feature of the condition, osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lipid-filled macrophages would not be expected. Also, peripheral neuropathy, limb stiffness, opisthotonic posture, and loss of vision are features of Krabbe disease that are not seen in this patient.

A deficiency of hexosaminidase A is the cause of Tay-Sachs disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. Although developmental delay is a feature of this disease, osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lipid-filled macrophages would not be expected. Also, “cherry-red” spots on the macula, hypotonia, seizures, and hearing impairment are features of the condition that are not seen in this patient.

A deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase is the cause of Gaucher disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. Type I, non-neuronopathic Gaucher disease manifests with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pathology, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and growth delays. Diagnosis of a patient with suggestive clinical features is confirmed by the finding of reduced glucocerebrosidase activity, often in peripheral leukocytes or fibroblasts. Treatment is with recombinant glucocerebrosidase. Type II, acute neuronopathic Gaucher disease manifests with hepatosplenomegaly, congenital ichthyosis, and rapidly progressive neurodegeneration; affected patients usually die before 2 years of age.

See “Overview of lysosomal storage diseases” table.

images.title: Lysosomal storage disease
images.description: The chart illustrates the breakdown of select sphingolipids in the lysosomes, the corresponding enzymes that catalyze the reactions, and the diseases that an enzyme defect can cause.GM1, GM2, GM3, GA1, and GA2 refer to various gangliosides, i.e., sphingolipids with different sugar residues.

question_text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and headache for the past 6 hours. Three days ago, she was started on dapsone and rifampin for the treatment of tuberculoid leprosy. Her pulse is 115/min and respirations are 12/min. Physical examination shows bluish discoloration of the lips and nail beds. A venous blood sample appears chocolate-colored and does not change color when exposed to oxygen. Compared to a healthy child, arterial blood gas analysis in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

%O_2 saturation
O_2 partial pressure
O_2 content
Hb concentration

A
Normal
normal
increased
increased

B
Normal
normal
decreased
decreased

C
Decreased
normal
decreased
normal

D
Decreased
decreased
decreased
normal

E
Decreased
normal
decreased
increased
content_preview: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and headache for the past 6 hours. Three days ago, she was started on dapsone and rifampin for the treatment of tuberculoid leprosy. Her pulse is 115/min and respirations are 12/min. Physical examination shows bluish discoloration of the lips and nail beds. A venous blood sample appears chocolate-colored and does not change color when exposed to oxygen. Compared to a healthy child, arterial blood gas analysis in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? %O2 saturation O2 partial pressure O2 content Hb concentration A Normal normal increased increased B Normal normal decreased decreased C Decreased normal decreased normal D Decreased decreased decreased normal E Decreased normal decreased increased
hint: In a patient undergoing treatment with dapsone, tachycardia, respiratory depression, cyanosis, and chocolate-colored blood on venous sampling should raise suspicion for acute methemoglobinemia.
learning_objective: Recognize methemoglobinemia, and recall its arterial blood gas findings.

answers.explanation_why: These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with polycythemia vera (PV), a condition characterized by an increase in erythrocyte count and thus hemoglobin (Hb) concentration. While this results in an increased arterial O_2 content, O_2 partial pressure and O_2 saturation remain normal because these parameters mainly depend on the inhaled oxygen concentration, atmospheric pressure, and gas exchange in the lungs, none of which is affected by increased Hb concentration. Classical manifestations of PV include facial flushing and pruritus, neither of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, respiratory depression, which is seen here, would not be expected.

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with anemia, which is characterized by low serum concentrations of hemoglobin (Hb) and, as a consequence, reduced arterial O_2 content. O_2 partial pressure and O_2 saturation remain normal because these parameters mainly depend on the inhaled oxygen concentration, atmospheric pressure, and gas exchange in the lungs, none of which is affected by low Hb concentration. Anemia can cause tachycardia, which is seen in this patient, but pallor rather than cyanosis would be expected. Moreover, chocolate-colored blood that does not change color when exposed to oxygen is not seen in anemia.

Methemoglobinemia is caused by an abundance of methemoglobin, an altered form of hemoglobin in which ferrous iron (Fe^2+) is oxidized to the ferric form (Fe^3+). Since Fe^3+ cannot bind oxygen, arterial O_2 saturation and total O_2 content decrease. This leads to functional anemia, despite normal hemoglobin concentrations. Patients with methemoglobinemia show clinical signs of cyanosis due to poor tissue oxygenation. O_2 partial pressure (PaO_2), which reflects the concentration of dissolved oxygen in plasma, is not affected. In patients prone to developing methemoglobinemia (e.g., patients with G6PD deficiency), oxidant drugs such as dapsone and topical anesthetic drugs should be avoided. Treatment consists of converting methemoglobin to hemoglobin by using reducing agents such as methylene blue and vitamin C.

Although prolonged or chronic methemoglobinemia may lead to erythrocytosis or polycythemia, this patient has only been taking her medication for three days.

See “Overview of factors that affect oxygenation” table.

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with hypoxemia (e.g., due to impaired gas exchange in the lungs). Impaired oxygenation of the blood decreases both the amount of oxygen dissolved in the plasma (↓ PaO_2) and the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin (↓ SaO_2). As a result, the total amount of oxygen transported by arterial blood (i.e., O_2 content) will also be reduced. In states of hypoxemia, the hemoglobin concentration is initially unaffected, but may eventually increase due to stimulation of erythropoietin secretion. Hypoxemia can cause signs of cyanosis, which are seen here. However, unlike this patient's blood sample, deoxygenated blood changes color to bright red upon exposure to oxygen.

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with chronic carbon monoxide poisoning (e.g., from cigarette smoke). Since carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin (Hb) with much higher affinity than oxygen (producing carboxyhemoglobin), it cannot easily be displaced. This results in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which impairs oxygen delivery to the tissues. The amount of oxygen bound to Hb (SaO_2) as well as the total arterial O_2 content are reduced, while the amount of dissolved oxygen in the plasma (PaO_2) remains unaffected. Elevated erythropoietin production secondary to chronic hypoxia induces an increase in Hb. Clinical findings of chronic carbon monoxide include dizziness and seizures, neither of which is seen here. Moreover, based on this patient's history, there is no reason to expect prolonged exposure to CO.

question_text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of recurrent episodes of headaches, palpitations, and sweating. He was adopted shortly after birth and does not know his biological parents. His pulse is 103/min and blood pressure is 160/105 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple soft, yellow papules on the tip of the tongue. There is a 2-cm, firm thyroid nodule. He has long and slender upper extremities, and his elbows and knees can be hyperextended. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a mutation in which of the following genes?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of recurrent episodes of headaches, palpitations, and sweating. He was adopted shortly after birth and does not know his biological parents. His pulse is 103/min and blood pressure is 160/105 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple soft, yellow papules on the tip of the tongue. There is a 2-cm, firm thyroid nodule. He has long and slender upper extremities, and his elbows and knees can be hyperextended. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a mutation in which of the following genes?
hint: This man's paroxysmal headaches, palpitations, sweating, and hypertension are concerning for a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. His long upper extremities and joint laxity are features of Marfanoid habitus. Together with the firm thyroid nodule (possibly thyroid cancer) and the soft, yellow papules on the tongue (likely mucosal neuromas), these findings raise suspicion for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B).
learning_objective: Recognize multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B, and recall the associated gene mutation.

answers.explanation_why:
Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2, which includes MEN 2A and MEN 2B, results from a gain-of-function mutation of the RET gene. RET encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase that plays a key role in cell growth, differentiation, and survival. Medullary thyroid cancer (which develops in almost all patients) and pheochromocytoma are associated with both MEN 2A and MEN 2B. MEN 2A is associated with primary hyperparathyroidism, and MEN 2B is associated with marfanoid habitus and mucosal neuromas.

Early diagnosis of MEN 2-associated medullary thyroid cancer is essential because this malignancy is highly aggressive. High-risk patients identified by genetic screening should undergo thyroidectomy during the first year of life.

Mutations in the FBN1 gene result in a deficiency of fibrillin-1, which is the underlying cause of Marfan syndrome. This condition typically manifests with long extremities and joint hypermobility as seen in this patient but is not associated with pheochromocytoma, thyroid nodules, or mucosal neuromas. Moreover, patients with Marfan syndrome usually also have cardiovascular (e.g., aortic disease) and ophthalmologic symptoms (e.g, lens dislocation), which are not seen in this patient.

Mutations in the TSC2 tumor suppressor gene result in a deficiency of tuberin protein, which is the underlying cause of tuberous sclerosis. This condition typically manifests in childhood with ash-leaf spots, angiofibromas, Shagreen patches, and benign brain tumors (most commonly hamartomas). Most patients have intellectual disabilities and epilepsy. None of these features are seen in this patient.

Mutations in the COL5A1 gene result in faulty synthesis of type V collagen, which is the underlying cause of classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. This condition typically manifests with joint hypermobility as seen in this patient but is not associated with pheochromocytoma, thyroid nodules, or mucosal neuromas. Moreover, patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome usually also have skin hyperextensibility and abnormal wound healing, which are not seen in this patient.

images.title: Skin hyperextensibility in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
images.description: The skin of the elbow is hyperelastic (cutis hyperelastica) due to impaired collagen synthesis.This, along with joint hypermobility, is a characteristic feature of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene result in inactivation of menin protein, which is the underlying cause of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. This condition most commonly manifests with hyperparathyroidism and is associated with endocrine pancreatic tumors (e.g., gastrinoma, insulinoma), pituitary adenomas, and carcinoid tumors, none of which are seen in this patient.

Mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene result in a deficiency of neurofibromin protein, which is the underlying cause of neurofibromatosis type I. This condition typically manifests with café-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules, and multiple cutaneous neurofibromas and optic gliomas, none of which are seen in this patient.

images.title: Clinical features of neurofibromatosis type 1 and type 2
images.description: Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of low-grade fever, joint pain, and muscle aches. The day before the onset of her symptoms, she was severely sunburned on her face and arms during a hike with friends. She also reports being unusually fatigued over the past 3 months. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive pill. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Examination shows bilateral swelling and tenderness of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints. There are multiple nontender superficial ulcers on the oral mucosa. The detection of antibodies directed against which of the following is most specific for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of low-grade fever, joint pain, and muscle aches. The day before the onset of her symptoms, she was severely sunburned on her face and arms during a hike with friends. She also reports being unusually fatigued over the past 3 months. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive pill. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Examination shows bilateral swelling and tenderness of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints. There are multiple nontender superficial ulcers on the oral mucosa. The detection of antibodies directed against which of the following is most specific for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's fever, arthritis, increased photosensitivity, and painless oral ulcers are highly suggestive of a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
learning_objective: Recognize systemic lupus erythematosus, and recall its specific antibody markers.

answers.explanation_why: Antibodies directed against myeloperoxidase (i.e., perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, p-ANCA) play no role in the diagnosis of SLE. This type of antibody is used to diagnose individuals with microscopic polyangiitis, which can present with fever, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, and oral ulcers. However, microscopic polyangiitis is not associated with photosensitivity. It is usually associated with palpable purpura and hemoptysis, neither of which is seen in this patient.

Antibodies targeting the cell nucleus (i.e., anti-nuclear antibodies, ANA) are very sensitive marker (∼ 95%) for SLE. However, it is a nonspecific marker that is seen in many other conditions (i.e., systemic sclerosis, Sjögren syndrome, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and even in healthy individuals). The presence of ANA in serum necessitates further testing to determine the etiology of the diagnosis.

Antibodies directed against single-stranded DNA (i.e., anti-ssDNA antibodies) are not used to confirm the diagnosis of SLE. This particular type of antibody can be found in patients with SLE, but it is not specific enough to be diagnostic.

Antibodies directed against the Fc region of IgG (i.e., rheumatoid factor) are present in ∼ one-third of SLE patients. Rheumatoid factor is not specific enough to be of diagnostic value, but it is a moderately sensitive test for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, which can manifest with low-grade fever, swelling, and tenderness of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints. It is not associated with multiple oral ulcers or photosensitivity.

Antibodies directed against phospholipid-binding proteins (i.e., antiphospholipid antibodies) are found in 30–40% of patients with SLE. Of those with antiphospholipid antibodies, about 20% will go on to develop antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. Screening for this type of antibody is therefore important in patients with SLE. However, it does not have any diagnostic value for SLE.

Antibodies to nuclear Sm proteins (i.e., anti-Smith antibodies) are a highly specific marker for SLE. However, they are only positive in 30% of patients, meaning they are not a very sensitive marker. For this reason, the diagnosis of SLE is always based on clinical features as well as immunologic test results. Another highly specific antibody for the diagnosis of SLE targets double-stranded DNA. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are present in 70% of patients with SLE (high sensitivity), correlate with disease activity, and are associated with lupus nephritis.

See “Overview of antinuclear antibodies” table.

Antibodies directed against histones (i.e., antihistone antibodies) are found in nearly 95% of patients with drug-induced lupus. This woman's only medication (OCP) does not cause drug-induced lupus and she has no history of taking any drugs that cause it (e.g., sulfonamides, hydralazine, isoniazid, procainamide, or phenytoin). Antihistone antibodies can be seen in SLE; however, they are far more common in drug-induced lupus.

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of progressive shortness of breath, difficulty speaking, and diffuse, colicky abdominal pain for the past 3 hours. Yesterday he underwent a tooth extraction. His father and a paternal uncle have a history of repeated hospitalizations for upper airway and orofacial swelling. The patient takes no medications. His blood pressure is 112/62 mm Hg. Examination shows edematous swelling of the lips, tongue, arms, and legs; there is no rash. Administration of a drug targeting which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of progressive shortness of breath, difficulty speaking, and diffuse, colicky abdominal pain for the past 3 hours. Yesterday he underwent a tooth extraction. His father and a paternal uncle have a history of repeated hospitalizations for upper airway and orofacial swelling. The patient takes no medications. His blood pressure is 112/62 mm Hg. Examination shows edematous swelling of the lips, tongue, arms, and legs; there is no rash. Administration of a drug targeting which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient?
hint: This patient presents with abdominal pain, swelling of the extremities (without hives or pruritus), and dyspnea secondary to edema of the lips and tongue after a triggering incident (dental work). These findings, together with a family history of recurrent orofacial swelling, are indicative of hereditary angioedema (HAE), a disease caused by deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor.
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary angioedema, and recall its treatment targets.

answers.explanation_why: Antihistamines are used to treat patients presenting with mast cell-mediated angioedema (without anaphylaxis). Although this patient's significant orofacial swelling could be due to mast cell-mediated angioedema, it is more often associated with significant pruritus and hives, which are noticeably absent here. Antihistamines are primarily used for treating pruritus and urticaria and would not benefit this patient.
Attenuated androgens (e.g., danazol) are effective therapies for long-term prophylaxis in patients with HAE. However, they are not useful in treating acute attacks.

The autosomal dominant defect in patients with HAE causes a deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor, which physiologically suppresses steps in the complement pathways and inactivates kallikrein. Because kallikrein normally converts kininogen to bradykinin, increased levels of kallikrein lead to a buildup of bradykinin, with resultant vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and eventual angioedema. First-line therapies for HAE focus on antagonizing the bradykinin B2 receptor (icatibant), replacing the defective enzyme with intravenous injection of purified C1-INH, or preventing further generation of bradykinin with a kallikrein inhibitor (ecallantide).

Trauma, dental work, and mental or physical stress are common triggers for these acute attacks.

images.title: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema
images.description: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema is triggered by increased levels of the proinflammatory vasodilator bradykinin, which can build up via several different mechanisms.Top left: The rare hereditary angioedema (HAE) type III (normal levels and function of C1-INH) can be caused by several different gene mutations; illustrated here is a mutation resulting in increased Factor XII activity, which leads to increased bradykinin generation.Center left: In HAE type I (low levels of normal C1-INH), HAE type II (normal or high levels of dysfunctional C1-INHI), and acquired angioedema (acquired low levels of C1-INH), the normal inhibitory function of C1-INH on the kallikrein-kinin system is reduced, resulting in increased bradykinin generation.Bottom left: In ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema, reduced bradykinin breakdown due to inhibition of ACE results in the build-up of bradykinin.C1-INH: C1 inhibitor; ACE: angiotensin-converting enzyme; HMWK: high-molecular-weight kininogen; HAE: hereditary angioedema

answers.explanation_why:
The use of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors is absolutely contraindicated in a patient with HAE. ACE inhibitors prevent ACE from degrading the already elevated bradykinin and also lead to lower levels of angiotensin II, which normally acts to inhibit bradykinin synthesis.

ACE inhibitors are the most common cause of acquired angioedema.

Glucocorticoids are an appropriate treatment for patients presenting with mast cell-mediated angioedema (without anaphylaxis). While this could explain this patient's significant orofacial swelling, the lack of significant pruritus or hives makes it highly unlikely. Glucocorticoids are ineffective in the context of HAE.

answers.content: Agonist at alpha and beta-adrenergic receptors
answers.explanation_why: Epinephrine, a dual α and β-adrenergic agonist, is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis associated with allergic or mast cell-mediated angioedema. Abdominal pain can also occur in some cases of anaphylaxis, most commonly with a known food allergen. However, anaphylaxis usually has an acute onset (within minutes to hours of exposure to an antigen), is rapidly progressive, and would present with additional system involvement (hypotension, pruritus, and hives). Epinephrine does not improve airway-associated symptoms in acute angioedema attacks in patients with HAE.

question_text:
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 4-hour history of severe abdominal pain and intractable vomiting. She also has had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss during the past month despite no change in appetite. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She appears somnolent. Pulse is 130/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 95/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Her breath has a fruity odor. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation; there is no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Serum studies show:

Na^+

136 mEq/L

Cl^-

97 mEq/L

K^+

3.9 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

15 mEq/L

Glucose
400 mg/dL

An intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline and insulin is begun. An increase in which of the following parameters best indicates the resolution of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 4-hour history of severe abdominal pain and intractable vomiting. She also has had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss during the past month despite no change in appetite. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She appears somnolent. Pulse is 130/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 95/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Her breath has a fruity odor. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation; there is no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Serum studies show: Na+ 136 mEq/L Cl- 97 mEq/L K+ 3.9 mEq/L HCO3- 15 mEq/L Glucose 400 mg/dL An intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline and insulin is begun. An increase in which of the following parameters best indicates the resolution of this patient's condition?
hint: Hyperglycemia and a history of weight loss in a 14-year-old patient are consistent with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). This patient presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea, fruity breath, features of dehydration due to osmotic diuresis (hypotension, tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor), and altered mental status combined with glucose levels 200–600 mg/dL, which indicate diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a common complication of T1DM.
learning_objective: Recognize diabetic ketoacidosis, and recall the best indicator for its resolution.

answers.explanation_why: The insulin-deficient state of DKA leads to increased lipolysis, resulting in more free fatty acids. Metabolic acidosis develops as these free fatty acids become ketones, two of which are acidic (acetoacetic acid and beta-hydroxybutyric acid), resulting in consumption of serum bicarbonate, which acts as a buffer for the acidic ketones. The primary goal of treatment with insulin and intravenous fluids is to stop ketogenesis and allow the body to metabolize the existing ketoacids, thereby correcting acidosis. As the condition resolves, the concentration of ketoacids in the blood decreases, leading to a rise in the pH. The key criteria for resolution of DKA are glucose < 200mg/dL, serum bicarbonate ≥ 18 mEq/L, and an increase in venous PH to ≥ 7.30.

The serum anion gap is elevated in DKA because of the accumulation of ketoacids. As insulin therapy halts ketone production, and the body clears the existing acids, the anion gap normalizes. Therefore, resolution of DKA results in a decreased rather than an increased serum anion gap.

Interstitial glucose, measured by continuous glucose monitors, lags behind plasma glucose levels, especially when glucose is changing rapidly, as it does during the treatment of DKA. Because of this lag, interstitial glucose is not used for the acute monitoring of DKA resolution. Furthermore, as the patient's hyperglycemia is corrected, glucose levels (both serum and interstitial) will decrease rather than increase.

Potassium levels are typically normal or elevated in patients with DKA despite a total body potassium deficit. Insulin deficiency and the hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state cause potassium to shift to the extracellular space along with water from inside cells, which is then lost in urine. Treatment with IV fluids and insulin causes potassium to move back into the cells, decreasing rather than increasing serum potassium. Potassium repletion is often necessary despite normal serum values. Potassium concentration is not used to monitor for resolution of DKA.

In DKA, severe hyperglycemia leads to glucosuria, which causes osmotic diuresis, resulting in the excretion of urine with a high osmolality. As treatment with insulin and fluids lowers the blood glucose level, glucosuria resolves, and urinary osmolality decreases. Therefore, urinary osmality decreases rather than increases as the patient's condition improves.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of crushing chest pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. The pain is constant and radiates to his left shoulder. Over the past year, he has been admitted to the hospital twice for deep vein thrombosis. He has a history of learning disability and has been held back three grades. The patient is at the 99^th percentile for height and the 45^th percentile for weight. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. His fingers are long and slender, and his arm span exceeds his body height. Electrocardiography shows ST-segment elevation in leads V_1 and V_2. His serum troponin I concentration is 2.0 ng/mL. Coronary angiography shows 90% occlusion of the proximal left anterior descending artery. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of crushing chest pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. The pain is constant and radiates to his left shoulder. Over the past year, he has been admitted to the hospital twice for deep vein thrombosis. He has a history of learning disability and has been held back three grades. The patient is at the 99th percentile for height and the 45th percentile for weight. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. His fingers are long and slender, and his arm span exceeds his body height. Electrocardiography shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2. His serum troponin I concentration is 2.0 ng/mL. Coronary angiography shows 90% occlusion of the proximal left anterior descending artery. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: The patient's early-onset coronary heart disease and marfanoid habitus (tall and thin stature with increased arm span, arachnodactyly) in combination with a history of deep vein thromboses (DVTs) and learning disability raise suspicion for homocystinuria.
learning_objective: Recognize homocystinuria, and recall its associated ocular finding.

answers.explanation_why: Bilateral gynecomastia is a possible manifestation of Klinefelter syndrome. Individuals with this sex chromosome disorder typically have a tall stature with long extremities and may present with a learning disability. However, Klinefelter syndrome is not associated with arachnodactyly, early-onset coronary heart disease, or thromboembolic events. Instead, symptoms related to testosterone deficiency (e.g., testicular hypoplasia, reduced body hair, osteoporosis) would be expected.

Homocystinuria is a group of autosomal recessive metabolic disorders characterized by downward lens subluxation, a marfanoid habitus, intellectual disability, early-onset atherosclerosis, and increased risk of thromboembolic events (e.g., DVTs). Other clinical features may include myopia, pale skin, osteoporosis, and kyphosis. This condition is caused by several enzyme defects (e.g., cystathionine synthase deficiency, methionine synthase deficiency, and methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase deficiency), all of which result in the accumulation of homocysteine. Treatment depends on the underlying defect (e.g., cysteine, vitamin B_6, vitamin B_12, folate supplementation).

Marfan syndrome is an important differential diagnosis of homocystinuria. Distinguishing features include intellectual disability, which is only seen in homocystinuria, and the direction of lens dislocation (downwards in homocystinuria; upwards in Marfan syndrome).

Macroorchidism is a possible manifestation of Fragile X syndrome, a condition associated with intellectual disability and tall stature. However, early-onset coronary heart disease and recurrent thromboembolic events are inconsistent with Fragile X syndrome. Instead, features such as a long and narrow face, large ears, mitral valve prolapse, and hyperactivity would be expected.

Saccular cerebral aneurysms are a possible complication of Ehler-Danlos syndrome (EDS). This patient has a marfanoid habitus, which can be seen in some types of EDS. However, learning disability, early-onset coronary heart disease, and recurrent thromboembolic events are inconsistent with EDS. Moreover, EDS is associated with further clinical features such as skin hyperextensibility, a tendency to bleed, and mitral valve prolapse.

Mucosal neuromas are a possible feature of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN 2B), a syndrome commonly associated with a marfanoid habitus. However, learning disability, early-onset coronary heart disease, and recurrent thromboembolic events are inconsistent with this condition. Moreover, MEN 2B is characterized by further neoplasms such as pheochromocytoma and early-onset medullary thyroid carcinoma (in 95–100% of patients with MEN 2B).

Aneurysm of the ascending aorta is a possible complication of Marfan syndrome. This patient has a marfanoid habitus; however, learning disability, early-onset coronary heart disease, and recurrent thromboembolic events are inconsistent with Marfan syndrome. Moreover, although compression of a coronary artery by an aortic aneurysm can result in myocardial infarction, this patient's coronary angiography indicates underlying coronary artery atherosclerosis.

question_text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department one hour after developing shortness of breath and “squeezing” chest pain that began while he was mowing the lawn. He has asthma, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. Current medications include salmeterol, amlodipine, lisinopril, and vardenafil. His pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Sublingual nitroglycerin is administered. Five minutes later, his pulse is 137/min and his blood pressure is 78/40 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's hypotension?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department one hour after developing shortness of breath and “squeezing” chest pain that began while he was mowing the lawn. He has asthma, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. Current medications include salmeterol, amlodipine, lisinopril, and vardenafil. His pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Sublingual nitroglycerin is administered. Five minutes later, his pulse is 137/min and his blood pressure is 78/40 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's hypotension?
hint: Vardenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor and should not be used in combination with nitrates.
learning_objective: Recognize drug-induced hypotension, and recall the role of cGMP in vasodilation.

answers.explanation_why: ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) can lead to the accumulation of bradykinin, which can cause hypotension (due to vascular dilation). However, an acute, life-threatening drop in blood pressure is unlikely. Furthermore, if an accumulation of bradykinin had occurred in this patient, symptoms such as bronchoconstriction, angioedema, and dry cough would also be expected.

Calcium channel antagonists (e.g., amlodipine) can cause vascular smooth muscle relaxation, which may lead to a drop in blood pressure. However, this class of drugs rarely causes acute, severe hypotension, even when taken in conjunction with nitroglycerin.

Alpha-1 antagonists (e.g., prazosin) cause peripheral vasodilation by inhibiting the alpha-1 receptor in smooth muscle cells. This can also cause hypotension, which is why this class of drugs is contraindicated in patients who take nitrates. However, this patient is not currently taking any alpha-1 antagonists.

Nitrates (e.g., sublingual nitroglycerin) and PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g., vardenafil) both work by increasing the intracellular concentration of cGMP. Nitrates increase intracellular NO, which is responsible for activating guanylate cyclase in the cytosol of vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to increased synthesis of cGMP. PDE-5 inhibitors, as their name implies, inhibit phosphodiesterase (PDE), which leads to a decreased breakdown of cGMP. Accumulation of cGMP leads to activation of myosin-light-chain phosphatase (MLCP), which dephosphorylates the light chains of myosin. This results in smooth muscle cell relaxation in blood vessels with subsequent vasodilation. Life-threatening hypotension can occur if these two drugs are taken in combination.

images.title: Mechanism of action: nitrates and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors
images.description: Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.

answers.explanation_why: Nitroglycerin, a nitric oxide (NO) donor, causes vasodilation, which leads to smooth muscle relaxation via a process that starts with the activation of guanylyl cyclase. So NO production would be increased rather than decreased in this patient.

A release of histamine, which acts as a peripheral vasodilator, is the mechanism underlying hypotension in anaphylactic shock. Anaphylactic shock could account for this patient's hypotension and tachycardia, but he lacks other typical features of anaphylactic reactions, such as urticaria, angioedema, wheezing, nausea, and vomiting. Furthermore, allergic reactions to nitroglycerin are rare.

Beta-2 receptor agonists (e.g., salmeterol) cause relaxation of the smooth muscle in bronchial tubes and blood vessels. They are primarily used as bronchodilators in the management of asthma and other obstructive pulmonary diseases (e.g., COPD). Although smooth muscle cell relaxation leads to vasodilation, severe hypotension is rare, even when beta-2 receptor agonists are taken in combination with nitrates.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of hair loss and a rash on her face. She has also noticed that food has recently tasted bland to her. Her medical history is remarkable for Crohn disease, for which she had to undergo segmental small bowel resection several times because of intestinal obstruction and fistula formation. She was previously started on infliximab, which she stopped taking 9 months ago. Examination shows several bullous, erythematous perioral plaques. There are two well-circumscribed circular patches of hair loss on her scalp. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of hair loss and a rash on her face. She has also noticed that food has recently tasted bland to her. Her medical history is remarkable for Crohn disease, for which she had to undergo segmental small bowel resection several times because of intestinal obstruction and fistula formation. She was previously started on infliximab, which she stopped taking 9 months ago. Examination shows several bullous, erythematous perioral plaques. There are two well-circumscribed circular patches of hair loss on her scalp. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: A congenital cause of the same deficiency is Acrodermatitis enteropathica, which can manifest with depressed immunity, resulting in frequent infections and, in males, decreased spermatogenesis.
learning_objective: Recognize clinical features of zinc deficiency, and recall its etiologies.

answers.explanation_why: Retinoic acid (vitamin A) deficiency can manifest with dry, scaly skin (xerosis cutis). However, this patient lacks other typical features of vitamin A deficiency, such as night blindness, xerophthalmia, and corneal degeneration. Moreover, perioral plaques, altered sense of taste, and alopecia are not consistent with this deficiency.

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency (also known as scurvy) can manifest with dermatitis. However, this patient lacks typical features of vitamin C deficiency, such as gingivitis, mucosal bleeding, curly body hair, arthralgia, and follicular hyperkeratosis. Finally, altered sense of taste and alopecia are not commonly seen in scurvy.

Niacin deficiency (also known as pellagra) can manifest with dermatitis. However, dermatitis associated with pellagra typically manifests as a symmetrical rash with hyperpigmented lesions on sun-exposed areas. This patient lacks additional features of niacin deficiency, such as glossitis, dementia, and diarrhea. Finally, altered sense of taste and alopecia are not consistent with pellagra.

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

answers.explanation_why: Cobalamin (Vitamin B_12) deficiency can be seen in patients with inflammation of the terminal ileum (e.g., as seen in Crohn disease), where cobalamin is absorbed. This deficiency typically manifests with dry skin and altered taste sensation. However, other features of cobalamin deficiency, such as fatigue, peripheral neuropathy, symmetric paresthesias, numbness, and gait abnormalities, are absent in this patient. Moreover, cobalamin deficiency does not explain this patient's erythematous perioral plaques.

Selenium deficiency is a very rare nutritional deficiency that occurs most often in populations dependent on selenium-depleted soil for agriculture. Known manifestations of selenium deficiency include hypothyroidism (as thyroid hormone production is dependent on selenium) and myocardial necrosis leading to heart failure (for reasons that remain unclear). This patient's symptoms are not consistent with selenium deficiency.

Iron deficiency may also cause hair loss, which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, because iron is normally absorbed in the duodenum, Crohn disease is a risk factor for this type of deficiency. Iron deficiency most commonly manifests with easy fatigability, shortness of breath, conjunctival pallor, and weakness (all attributable to iron deficiency anemia), as well as koilonychia and pica. This patient lacks these other cardinal findings. Moreover, iron deficiency would not explain this patient's dysgeusia and dermatitis.

Zinc deficiency can lead to a constellation of clinical features including immune dysfunction, impaired wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea, dermatitis, alopecia, abnormal sense of taste (dysgeusia), and an abnormal sense of smell (dysosmia). Etiologies include poor dietary intake, impaired absorption (e.g., due to Crohn disease), congenital conditions (e.g., acrodermatitis enteropathica), and liver or renal disease. Crohn disease and numerous small bowel resections have most likely substantially impaired this patient's ability to absorb zinc, thereby predisposing her to zinc deficiency.

Zinc is a mineral that is vital for the function of numerous enzymes and is essential for the synthesis of zinc-finger transcription factors.

question_text:
A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of nausea, abdominal pain, and confusion. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with over-the-counter calcium carbonate antacids. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is metformin. Her pulse is 86/min and blood pressure is 142/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft abdomen. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: 

pH
7.46

PCO_2

44 mm Hg

PO_2

94 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

30 mEq/L

An ECG shows a QT interval corrected for heart rate (QTc) of 0.36 seconds (N = 0.40–0.44). The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to be increased in this patient?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of nausea, abdominal pain, and confusion. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with over-the-counter calcium carbonate antacids. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is metformin. Her pulse is 86/min and blood pressure is 142/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft abdomen. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.46 PCO2 44 mm Hg PO2 94 mm Hg HCO3- 30 mEq/L An ECG shows a QT interval corrected for heart rate (QTc) of 0.36 seconds (N = 0.40–0.44). The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to be increased in this patient?
hint: The constellation of nausea, abdominal pain, confusion, and shortened QT interval suggests hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia with metabolic alkalosis on arterial blood gas analysis indicates milk-alkali syndrome, which is typically caused by the prolonged intake of calcium carbonate antacids.
learning_objective: Recognize milk-alkali syndrome, and recall the associated serum substance change.

answers.explanation_why: Parathyroid hormone (PTH), which is secreted by the parathyroid glands in response to a drop in serum calcium levels, increases serum calcium by stimulating the reabsorption of calcium from the renal distal tubules, the production of calcitriol in the kidneys, and the release of calcium from bone. Hypercalcemia (e.g., due to milk-alkali syndrome) inhibits PTH secretion, which is why PTH levels would most likely be decreased (not increased) in this patient. Hypercalcemia in combination with increased PTH levels is seen in primary hyperparathyroidism (e.g., due to parathyroid gland adenomas).

Thyroid-stimulating hormone levels are decreased in hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism can cause hypercalcemia through the activation of osteoclasts, which results in the release of calcium from the bones. Confusion and elevated blood pressure can also be seen in hyperthyroidism. However, this patient lacks typical features of hyperthyroidism, including tachycardia, palpitations, heat intolerance, fine tremor, and weight loss.

β-hydroxybutyrate is a ketone body produced by the liver and used by peripheral tissues (e.g., heart, brain, skeletal muscle) as an energy source when glucose is not readily available (states of ketogenesis, e.g., during prolonged starvation, in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), or chronic heavy drinking). There is no history of starvation or alcohol use in this patient. DKA is seen primarily in patients with type I diabetes mellitus, as opposed to type II diabetes mellitus. Although clinical findings of DKA include nausea, abdominal pain, and confusion, which are present here, it typically results in metabolic acidosis rather than metabolic alkalosis.

Phosphate homeostasis is a complex process that is regulated by various hormones (e.g., parathyroid hormone, vitamin D). Hypercalcemia due to milk-alkali syndrome is typically associated with decreased, not increased levels of phosphate. The decreased phosphate levels result from prolonged ingestion of calcium carbonate without the simultaneous ingestion of phosphate. Calcium carbonate binds to phosphate, lowering phosphate serum levels.

Calcium homeostasis is a complex process that is regulated by various hormones (e.g., parathyroid hormone, vitamin D, calcitonin). A mechanism that occurs in response to hypercalcemia (e.g., due to milk-alkali syndrome) is increased renal conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, an inactive intermediate in vitamin D metabolism; in addition, there is decreased conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the most active form of vitamin D. Since calcitriol normally increases serum calcium concentrations (via effects on the gastrointestinal tract and the kidneys), decreased formation of calcitriol results in a reduction in serum calcium concentrations.

question_text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Since the age of 2 years, she has had multiple fractures after minor trauma. During the past year, she has fractured the left humerus and right clavicle after falls. Her father also has a history of recurrent fractures. She is at the 5^th percentile for height and 20^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows increased convexity of the thoracic spine. Forward bend test demonstrates asymmetry of the thoracolumbar region. There is a curvature of the tibias bilaterally, and the left leg is 2 cm longer than the right. There is increased mobility of the joints of the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding?
content_preview: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Since the age of 2 years, she has had multiple fractures after minor trauma. During the past year, she has fractured the left humerus and right clavicle after falls. Her father also has a history of recurrent fractures. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows increased convexity of the thoracic spine. Forward bend test demonstrates asymmetry of the thoracolumbar region. There is a curvature of the tibias bilaterally, and the left leg is 2 cm longer than the right. There is increased mobility of the joints of the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding?
hint: The patient's short stature, history of fractures after minor trauma, bone deformities (kyphoscoliosis, bowed tibias), joint hypermobility, and family history of recurrent fractures is highly suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI).
learning_objective: Recognize osteogenesis imperfecta, and recall its association with hearing impairment.

answers.explanation_why: Lens dislocation is associated with Marfan syndrome (upward dislocation) and homocystinuria (downward dislocation). Both conditions cause joint laxity and kyphoscoliosis. However, patients with these conditions usually have tall stature and long limbs while this patient has short stature. Additionally, these conditions do not increase the risk of developing fractures. Lens dislocation is not a feature of OI.

Hearing impairment is a common clinical manifestation of OI, and results from fracture, dislocation, or abnormal formation of the ossicles. Additional findings in patients with OI include blue sclerae (due to choroidal veins appearing through the overlying thin sclerae), easy bruisability, and brittle, opalescent teeth (i.e., dentinogenesis imperfecta). Depending on the type of OI, manifestations may range from mildly symptomatic (type I) to perinatally lethal (type II). This patient likely has moderate to severe OI (comprised of types III-IX) given her early presentation, short stature, and significant bone deformities.

images.title: Osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease) fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Widely spaced permanent teeth (Hutchinson teeth) in a child suggest late congenital syphilis. Although this condition can cause skeletal deformities such as tibial bowing, the patient lacks other typical manifestations, including a saddle nose, frontal bossing, a short maxilla, and skin lesions (perioral fissures and gummas). Also, congenital syphilis does not cause joint hypermobility or increase the risk of developing fractures. OI is not associated with Hutchinson teeth but rather brittle, opalescent teeth due to a lack of dentin (i.e., dentinogenesis imperfecta).

Cerebral berry aneurysms are associated with several genetic diseases, including Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), which manifests with joint hypermobility. However, EDS does not cause short stature or increase the risk of developing fractures. Cerebral berry aneurysms are not associated with OI.

Prominence of the costochondral junctions (rachitic rosary) is characteristic of rickets, which can cause bone deformities (including tibial bowing and kyphoscoliosis) and impaired growth in children, as well as fractures in severe cases. However, rickets does not cause joint hypermobility. Costochondral prominence is not a feature of OI.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Increased head circumference, or macrocephaly, is a common finding in patients with achondroplasia, which causes disproportionate short stature (along with an average-sized torso and short, plump extremities) and kyphoscoliosis. However, this condition does not cause joint hypermobility or skeletal asymmetry, nor does it increase the risk of developing fractures. Macrocephaly is not a feature of OI.

Several causes of short stature, including chromosomal abnormalities (Down syndrome, Williams syndrome) and exposure to toxins in utero (embryo-fetal alcohol syndrome), can cause intellectual disability. However, patients with osteogenesis imperfecta typically have normal intelligence.
