question_text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of depression is brought to the emergency department by her husband 45 minutes after ingesting an unknown amount of a termite poison in a suicide attempt. She has abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Her husband reports that she has had two episodes of watery diarrhea on the way to the emergency department. A distinct, garlic-like odor on the breath is noted on examination. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and QTc prolongation. Administration of which of the following is most appropriate?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman with a history of depression is brought to the emergency department by her husband 45 minutes after ingesting an unknown amount of a termite poison in a suicide attempt. She has abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Her husband reports that she has had two episodes of watery diarrhea on the way to the emergency department. A distinct, garlic-like odor on the breath is noted on examination. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and QTc prolongation. Administration of which of the following is most appropriate?
hint: While abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea are rather nonspecific findings that can occur in several types of poisoning, the garlic-like odor on the breath and QTc prolongation suggest arsenic poisoning. Arsenic is a common component of pesticides.
learning_objective: Recognize arsenic poisoning, and choose the most appropriate chelation therapy.

answers.explanation_why: N-acetylcysteine is used to treat acetaminophen toxicity, which can also cause nonspecific symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting) in the first 24 hours after ingestion. However, this patient's history of recent pesticide ingestion does not suggest acetaminophen poisoning.

Fomepizole is used to treat methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, which can also cause nausea, abdominal pain, and QTc prolongation. However, ethylene glycol causes a sweet-smelling rather than garlic-like odor on the breath. Moreover, methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning also commonly manifest with altered mental status, headaches, and seizures.

Deferoxamine is used to treat acute iron toxicity, which also causes gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, hematemesis, diarrhea) within 6 hours of ingestion. However, this patient has no history of excessive iron ingestion and iron toxicity would not explain this patient's garlic-like odor on the breath.

Physostigmine is used to treat anticholinergic poisoning, which can also cause tachycardia and QTc prolongation. However, patients usually also have mydriasis, dry mouth, and warm and flushed skin; they do not develop garlic-like odor on the breath. Finally, this patient has no history of anticholinergic agent intake (e.g., atropine, deadly nightshade).

EDTA is used to treat acute lead poisoning, which causes constipation rather than diarrhea. Additionally, patients usually have additional signs and symptoms, including headache, seizures, muscle weakness, and paresthesias. This patient has no history of ingesting lead-containing products.

In combination with atropine, pralidoxime is used to treat organophosphate poisoning, which can also cause a garlic-like (or petrol-like) odor on the breath. Organophosphates are also found in pesticides. However, patients usually have additional signs and symptoms of cholinergic crisis such as hypotension, increased salivation, uncontrolled urination, bronchospasm, muscle fasciculations, and bradycardia (in contrast to this patient's tachycardia), none of which are present in this patient.

Arsenic toxicity results from its ability to bind strongly to sulfhydryl groups, thereby affecting the activity of different enzyme systems. Affected processes include glucose metabolism, glutathione metabolism, and cellular respiration (e.g., pyruvate dehydrogenase complex). Treatment for arsenic poisoning includes chelation therapy, cardiac monitoring (because of the risk of QTc prolongation), and fluid administration (to encourage urine output). Dimercaprol chelates several heavy metals, including arsenic, to form more stable, nontoxic, soluble compounds that are then excreted in the urine.

In cases of recent arsenic ingestion (within an hour), additional therapies include gastric lavage and activated charcoal (to absorb arsenic in the gastrointestinal tract). Dimercaptosuccinic acid (succimer) is more commonly used as chelation therapy for arsenic poisoning in children.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of two masses on her right auricle for several months. The masses appeared a few weeks after she had her ear pierced and have increased in size since then. A photograph of her right ear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of two masses on her right auricle for several months. The masses appeared a few weeks after she had her ear pierced and have increased in size since then. A photograph of her right ear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: This patient's history of trauma, followed by tissue growth beyond the boundaries of the original lesion is suggestive of keloid formation. The brownish-red color of the lesion shown supports this diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize keloid formation, and recall its histological cause.

answers.content: Implantation of epidermis into the dermis
answers.explanation_why: Implantation of the epidermis into the dermis is the pathomechanism underlying epidermoid cyst formation. Epidermoid cysts are slow-growing, firm, painless nodules and can be preceded by trauma to the skin. Unlike the lesions seen in this patient, they are usually not hyperpigmented. Implantation of the epidermis into the dermis is not associated with keloid formation.

images.title: Epidermoid cyst
images.description: A small, solitary, flesh-colored, round, nodular lesion with a small central pore.

answers.explanation_why: The proliferation of mature adipocytes is the mechanism underlying lipoma formation, which can occur in almost any part of the body (e.g., head, neck, chest, and back). Unlike the lesions seen in this patient, lipomas are usually skin-colored and rarely located in/around the ears. The proliferation of adipocytes is not associated with trauma and keloid formation.

images.title: Lipomas
images.description: Several large, ovoid, lobulated nodules are visible on the flexor surface of the forearm.The size, shape, location, and distribution of the lesions are consistent with lipomas.

answers.content: Increased production of disorganized extracellular matrix
answers.explanation_why: Keloids are formed from the hyperproliferation of fibroblasts, which results in disorganized overproduction of collagen types I and III. Keloids are most commonly seen in dark-skinned individuals. Common locations for keloids include the earlobes, face (e.g., cheeks), upper extremities, chest, and neck. See “Clinical features of hypertrophic scars and keloids” table.

Malignant transformation of keratinocytes is the pathomechanism underlying cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) formation. SCC of the skin typically develops in sun-exposed areas, such as the face and neck. Unlike the lesions seen in this patient, cSCC usually appear plaque-like, nodular, verrucous, or ulcerative, and are most commonly seen in elderly men. Malignant transformation of keratinocytes is not associated with keloid formation.

images.title: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ due to chronic arsenic exposure
images.description: A single, asymmetric cutaneous lesion with an irregular border and varied pigmentation can be seen.Histologic examination revealed squamous cell carcinoma in situ.

answers.content: Excess deposition of collagen in parallel
answers.explanation_why: Hypertrophic scars are caused by the excess formation and parallel deposition of type III collagen. Unlike the lesion seen in this patient, hypertrophic scars usually protrude above the surface of the skin but are confined within the original wound margins. Although keloid formation is also caused by the excess formation of collagen, the collagen fibers in keloid scars are typically disorganized.

images.title: Hypertrophic scar
images.description: A linear, erythematous raised scar is visible in the center of the image.These features are characteristic of a hypertrophic scar, which results from abnormal wound repair (i.e., overgrowth of fibroblastic tissues during skin healing).

images.title: Auricular keloids
images.description: The right pinna bears two well-defined, round, red swellings with a smooth surface. The swellings extend well beyond the boundary of the original defects (i.e., piercings in the scapha of the pinna).

question_text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath. She is now unable to jog for more than 10 minutes without stopping to catch her breath. Cardiac examination shows a harsh systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. The murmur increases in intensity when she moves from a squatting to a standing position and decreases when she clenches her fists. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath. She is now unable to jog for more than 10 minutes without stopping to catch her breath. Cardiac examination shows a harsh systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. The murmur increases in intensity when she moves from a squatting to a standing position and decreases when she clenches her fists. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?
hint: A systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border indicates left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. This patient's LVOT obstruction is dynamic, i.e., it increases with maneuvers that decrease venous return (standing from squatting) and decreases with maneuvers that increase afterload (clenching fists). This finding suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
learning_objective: Recognize hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Dystrophin defects are responsible for Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy. Patients with dilated cardiomyopathy can present with exertional dyspnea and a systolic mitral regurgitation (MR) murmur. However, an MR murmur would be heard loudest at the 5^th left intercostal space in the midclavicular line (mitral region), and increase in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., hand clenching). Moreover, DMD would cause rapidly progressive muscle weakness with an onset during childhood, and female individuals are very rarely affected by this X-linked recessive condition.

A fibrillin-1 defect is the cause of Marfan syndrome, which can result in mitral valve prolapse (MVP), aortic aneurysms, and/or aortic dissections. Severe MVP can cause exertional dyspnea and a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with maneuvers that decrease preload (e.g., standing up suddenly) and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., hand clenching). However, the murmur would be heard loudest at the 5^th left intercostal space in the midclavicular line (mitral region) and would typically be preceded by a midsystolic click. Also, this patient does not have any marfanoid features (e.g., arachnodactyly, tall stature, long extremities, hypermobile joints).

Mutations in the cardiac beta-myosin heavy chain gene cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is the most common hereditary cardiomyopathy. The mode of inheritance is typically autosomal dominant. Echocardiography (or examination of an autopsy specimen) would most likely demonstrate concentric left ventricular hypertrophy or hypertrophy of the interventricular septum. Microscopic analysis will show hypertrophic myocytes with disoriented myofibrils (myofibrillar disarray).
answers.explanation_but: All symptomatic patients should receive a beta blocker and be considered for an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) if there is a risk of sudden death. Positive inotropic and afterload-reducing or preload-reducing drugs (e.g., digitalis, glyceryl trinitrate, calcium channel blockers of the dihydropyridine class, ACE inhibitors) are contraindicated in cases of obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. If symptoms persist, myectomy or transcoronary ablation of septal hypertrophy are further treatment options.

images.title: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
images.description: Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

answers.explanation_why: GAA trinucleotide repeats within the frataxin gene on chromosome 9 result in Friedreich ataxia, which is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Friedreich ataxia would also manifest with impaired muscle coordination, deformities due to muscle spasticity (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, pes cavus), hearing loss, visual impairment, and/or diabetes mellitus. The absence of these features makes a GAA trinucleotide repeat disorder unlikely.

Myocyte ion channel defects are responsible for several inherited long QT syndromes (e.g., Romano-Ward syndrome, Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome), which manifest as acute episodes of palpitations and/or syncope (due to polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias). The auscultatory findings in this patient suggest LVOT obstruction, which is not caused by myocyte ion channel defects.

CTG trinucleotide repeats within the DMPK gene result in myotonic dystrophy. The typical cardiac manifestations in this condition are conduction blocks and/or tachyarrhythmias. Also, myotonic dystrophy is associated with other features such as progressive muscle weakness, myotonia, frontal balding, and/or visual impairment (due to cataracts), none of which are seen here.

A deletion in chromosome 7q occurs in Williams syndrome, which is associated with left ventricular outflow obstruction due to supravalvular aortic stenosis. Clinically, this can present with exertional dyspnea and a systolic murmur that decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., fist clenching). However, a murmur due to aortic stenosis is best heard at the 2^nd right intercostal space (aortic area), and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that decrease preload (e.g., standing up suddenly). Moreover, this patient does not have other findings indicative of Williams syndrome, such as elfin facies and mental disabilities.

question_text: A previously healthy 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of multiple nodules on his hands that first appeared a few months ago. He works as a computer game programmer. His father died of a myocardial infarction at 37 years of age, and his mother has rheumatoid arthritis. A photograph of the lesions is shown. The nodules are firm, mobile, and nontender. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism underlying this patient's skin findings?
content_preview: A previously healthy 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of multiple nodules on his hands that first appeared a few months ago. He works as a computer game programmer. His father died of a myocardial infarction at 37 years of age, and his mother has rheumatoid arthritis. A photograph of the lesions is shown. The nodules are firm, mobile, and nontender. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism underlying this patient's skin findings?
hint: The firm, skin-colored nodules on the patient's hands are tendinous xanthomas.
learning_objective: Recognize tendinous xanthomas, and recall their underlying mechanism.

answers.explanation_why: Cutaneous deposition of triglycerides may been seen in patients with hypertriglyceridemia and results in eruptive xanthomas, which can also cause nontender skin lesions. However, eruptive xanthomas are typically red or yellow soft papules that most commonly develop on the buttocks, back, and extensor surfaces of the extremities. Tendinous xanthomas are not typically associated with hypertriglyceridemia.

images.title: Eruptive xanthomas
images.description: A cluster of well-defined papules 2–5 mm in size can be seen. Most papules have a yellow apex and an erythematous border.Eruptive xanthomas are cutaneous lipid deposits typically seen in patients with type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia). They usually occur on the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the body.

answers.explanation_why: Fibrinoid necrosis is often seen on histopathologic examination of rheumatoid nodules, the most common cutaneous manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). While this patient's family history of RA puts him at higher risk of developing the condition, he has no other findings that would suggest inflammatory joint disease, such as prolonged morning stiffness and painful symmetrical joint swelling. Furthermore, RA is more common among middle-aged women and is a less likely diagnosis in this young male patient.

images.title: Rheumatoid nodules
images.description: Photograph of the hand of an elderly patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA)Multiple erythematous subcutaneous nodules are visible at the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints. Involvement of the distal interphalangeal joints and redness are possible but uncommon in patients with RA.

answers.explanation_why: Bone spurs, or osteophytes, can cause nodular thickening of the proximal interphalangeal joints (Bouchard nodes) and distal interphalangeal joints (Heberden nodes) in patients with osteoarthritis (OA). However, these nodules are typically painful. Additionally, this condition most commonly affects females and usually occurs much later in life, although this patient is at increased risk for developing OA given his occupation (involving repetitive hand movements).

images.title: Heberden and Bouchard nodes
images.description: Nodular thickening of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPJ) and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIPJ) can be seen.This appearance is characteristic of bony swellings caused by osteophyte formation in osteoarthritis. At the DIPJ these are called “Heberden nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger and both index fingers), and at the PIPJ they are called “Bouchard nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger).

answers.explanation_why: Crystallization of monosodium urate in and around the joints cause bone tophi, a classic finding in patients with chronic gout. While tophi are also hard, nontender nodules that can affect the hands, they would be unlikely to form in this young patient who has no history of joint disease. Tophi typically appear in undertreated individuals and take years to develop.

images.title: Gouty tophi
images.description: Tophi (monosodium urate crystal deposition in bones and soft tissues) are visible distributed irregularly in the fingers and metacarpus of this patient's left hand.

answers.explanation_why:
Tendinous xanthomas form from plasma lipoproteins that have extravasated and accumulated in tendons (most commonly the extensor tendons of the hands and the Achilles tendon) in patients with extremely high levels of circulating lipids. These findings and the death of this patient's father from a myocardial infarction at 37 years of age should raise suspicion for familial hypercholesterolemia, which increases the risk of developing premature coronary artery disease.

Large, perivascular infiltrates with foam cells and Touton giant cells can be seen on histopathological examination of tendinous xanthomas.

images.title: Xanthoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of tendinous tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)There are lipid-laden foam cells (histiocytes; examples indicated by arrowheads) and large cholesterol clefts (examples indicated by green overlay) throughout the tissue.These are typical histological findings in xanthoma.

images.title: Xanthoma tendinosum
images.description:
Multiple yellowish, smooth nodules are visible on the dorsum of both hands.

This appearance is suggestive of xanthoma tendinosum.

question_text: A healthy 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for advice on UV protection. She works as an archaeologist and is required to work outside for extended periods of time. She is concerned about premature skin aging. The physician recommends sun-protective clothing and sunscreen. In order to protect effectively against photoaging, the sunscreen should contain which of the following active ingredients?
content_preview: A healthy 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for advice on UV protection. She works as an archaeologist and is required to work outside for extended periods of time. She is concerned about premature skin aging. The physician recommends sun-protective clothing and sunscreen. In order to protect effectively against photoaging, the sunscreen should contain which of the following active ingredients?
hint: Sunscreens that provide protection against both ultraviolet A (UVA) and ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation are recommended to prevent premature aging of the skin.
learning_objective: Recall the active ingredients in sunscreen that protect against photoaging.

answers.explanation_why: Trolamine salicylate absorbs UVB radiation but not UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

TMP/SMX is used to treat numerous infections (i.e., UTI, acne vulgaris, toxoplasmosis, impetigo, cellulitis). Although it is effective against skin infections, the sulfonamide component causes photosensitivity and increases the risk of skin damage from UVA and UVB radiation.

Topical vitamin E can reduce skin damage from UVB radiation. However, it does not provide protection from UVA radiation and therefore would still leave this patient at risk for premature aging of the skin.
Para-aminobenzoic acid is only able to filter out UVB radiation. This patient would not be protected from UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

Mineral-based sunscreens (e.g., with zinc oxide, titanium oxide) are broad-spectrum sunscreens and provide full protection from UVA and UVB radiation by absorbing light in those spectrums, which prevents penetration into the dermis and premature aging of the skin. Sunscreens that have salicylates (e.g., trolamine salicylate), para-aminobenzoic acid, cinnamates (e.g., cinoxate), or octocrylene as the active ingredient can absorb UVB radiation but not UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

question_text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-week history of new pruritic plaques on the scalp and extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees. Ten years ago, she was diagnosed with psoriasis. Her only medication is topical calcipotriene. Physical examination shows well-demarcated, symmetrical, erythematous plaques with silvery scale. There is pitting of the nails on all fingers. Therapy with a high-potency topical medication that inhibits NF-κB and phospholipase A_2 is begun. Long-term use of this agent is most likely to result in which of the following?
content_preview: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-week history of new pruritic plaques on the scalp and extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees. Ten years ago, she was diagnosed with psoriasis. Her only medication is topical calcipotriene. Physical examination shows well-demarcated, symmetrical, erythematous plaques with silvery scale. There is pitting of the nails on all fingers. Therapy with a high-potency topical medication that inhibits NF-κB and phospholipase A2 is begun. Long-term use of this agent is most likely to result in which of the following?
hint: Corticosteroids exhibit an anti-inflammatory effect by inhibiting NF-κB and phospholipase A_2. This patient has started to use a high-potency topical corticosteroid for a relapse of plaque psoriasis.
learning_objective: Recall the long-term effects of topical corticosteroids, and recall their mechanism of action.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic, systemic corticosteroid use is associated with increased risk of developing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma but not dysplastic nevi or melanoma. Topical corticosteroid use is not known to increase the risk of any skin cancer type.

images.title: Atypical nevus
images.description: An asymmetric, pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variegation is visible over the left little finger.These are characteristic features of an atypical nevus.

answers.explanation_why: Petechiae are non-blanchable, vascular, pinpoint, red macules that can develop on the skin in patients with thrombocytopenia. Chronic topical corticosteroid use does not cause petechiae, but it is associated with an increased fragility of blood vessels which can cause larger hemorrhages presenting as purpura or ecchymoses.

images.title: Henoch-Schönlein purpura
images.description: Hand of a 30-year-old patient showing non-blanching palpable purpura and petechiae.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic topical corticosteroid increases (not decreases!) production of sebum on the skin, which can cause an acneiform eruption characterized by monomorphic inflammatory papules and pustules. This type of eruption resolves after discontinuation of corticosteroid use.

images.title: Steroid acne
images.description: Multiple pustules and erythematous papules are visible on the back of a young woman who had received high-dose methylprednisolone therapy for one week.

answers.explanation_why:
Chronic use of topical corticosteroids causes dermal collagen loss, which manifests as skin atrophy (skin thinning) and stretch marks. Skin thinning is the most common side effect of topical corticosteroid use and often causes the skin to appear translucent, making any underlying vasculature more visible. Longer duration of use, treatment with higher-strength corticosteroids (e.g., clobetasol), and use under occlusion increase the risk of adverse effects. Patients should receive directions on when to stop topical corticosteroid therapy to prevent this adverse effect.

Corticosteroids bind to intracellular glucocorticoid receptors, forming a complex that translocates into the nucleus, where it interacts with specific DNA sequences. The complex activates IκB, which inhibits the function of NF-κB, a transcription factor that normally promotes expression of numerous pro-inflammatory cytokine genes. It also inhibits production of arachidonic acid derivatives by inhibiting phospholipase A_2.

images.title: Steroid skin atrophy
images.description: The skin appears thin and translucent and the veins are unusually prominent. Purpura is visible in several places.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic corticosteroid use can cause hypertrichosis, particularly of the vellus hairs (e.g., on the upper lip among women). However, this adverse effect is usually limited to the area of corticosteroid application and is thus unlikely to occur on the upper lip in this patient with psoriatic lesions on the elbows and knees.

question_text:
A 21-year-old female college student with a history of anxiety is brought to the physician for evaluation of fatigue for the past 6 months. Over the past year, she has had extreme fluctuations in her weight and has become more distant from her friends. She admits to binge eating and induced vomiting. She appears tired and pale. Her BMI is 18.7 kg/m^2. Examination shows poor dentition. This patient is most likely to have which of the following sets of serum findings?

pH
HCO_3^- (mEq/L)
Anion Gap (mEq/L)
K^+ (mEq/L)

A
7.41
16
23
3.6

B
7.49
34
9
3.0

C
7.31
14
26
5.5

D
7.31
23
12
4.7

E
7.48
23

4.1
content_preview: A 21-year-old female college student with a history of anxiety is brought to the physician for evaluation of fatigue for the past 6 months. Over the past year, she has had extreme fluctuations in her weight and has become more distant from her friends. She admits to binge eating and induced vomiting. She appears tired and pale. Her BMI is 18.7 kg/m2. Examination shows poor dentition. This patient is most likely to have which of the following sets of serum findings? pH HCO3- (mEq/L) Anion Gap (mEq/L) K+ (mEq/L) A 7.41 16 23 3.6 B 7.49 34 9 3.0 C 7.31 14 26 5.5 D 7.31 23 12 4.7 E 7.48 23 88 4.1
hint: This patient has symptoms consistent with bulimia nervosa, and her lab results will reflect self-induced vomiting.

answers.explanation_why: These lab findings are consistent with a mixed anion-gap metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis, which we can assume given the normal pH despite markedly decreased bicarbonate. This scenario is classic for early aspirin toxicity, which causes an anion-gap metabolic acidosis but also stimulates hyperventilation, which causes a respiratory alkalosis. There is nothing in this patient's history to suggest aspirin toxicity.

These lab findings reflect a hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, which is consistent with this patient's history of frequent vomiting. Emesis leads to a loss of hydrogen ions secreted by gastric parietal cells, as well as a loss of chloride ions. Moreover, the alkalotic environment results in increased activity of cellular K^+/H^+ antiporter, which moves H^+ ions extracellularly to correct the alkalosis. In exchange, K^+ ions are being moved intracellularly, creating a state of relative hypokalemia.

These lab findings are consistent with an anion-gap metabolic acidosis, causes of which include diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), lactic acidosis, and uremia. Anion gaps are formed by the presence of unmeasured anions (i.e., anions other than Cl^- and HCO3^‑), such as ketones. The elevated serum K^+ often seen with metabolic acidosis occurs due to extracellular K^+ shifts in response to H^+ being moved intracellularly (via K^+/H^+ antiporter). This patient's frequent vomiting would not cause an anion-gap metabolic acidosis.

These lab findings are consistent with a primary respiratory acidosis (e.g., from hypoventilation due to opioid overdose), which we can assume given the normal bicarbonate value. Hypoventilation causes retention of CO_2, leading to an increase of hydrogen ions in the blood, decreasing blood pH. Serum bicarbonate levels are normal, indicating that metabolic compensation has not yet occurred. This is inconsistent with our clinical scenario.

These lab findings are consistent with a primary, acute respiratory alkalosis secondary to hyperventilation, which we can assume given the elevated pH but normal bicarbonate. Hyperventilation increases CO_2 exhalation, leading to a decreased load of hydrogen ions within the blood and alkalosis. The normal bicarbonate shows that there is no metabolic compensation, which suggests an acute process (the kidneys have not yet started to excrete bicarbonate to compensate for the alkalosis). This is not consistent with the clinical scenario seen here.

question_text: One week after starting amoxicillin for sinusitis, a 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and myalgia. She has been hospitalized multiple times for recurrent streptococcal pneumonia and meningitis. She appears tired. Examination shows a diffuse urticarial rash. Her antibiotic is discontinued. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for her recurrent infections?
content_preview: One week after starting amoxicillin for sinusitis, a 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and myalgia. She has been hospitalized multiple times for recurrent streptococcal pneumonia and meningitis. She appears tired. Examination shows a diffuse urticarial rash. Her antibiotic is discontinued. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for her recurrent infections?
hint: This girl's history of recurrent streptococcal infections and current hypersensitivity reaction is concerning for C3 deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize C3 deficiency, and recall its role in opsonization.

answers.explanation_why: Impaired leukocyte adhesion is seen in leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1, which may present with recurrent infections during childhood. However, affected children would have a history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord stump, omphalitis, and/or impaired wound healing instead of recurrent streptococcal infections.

Defective formation of the membrane attack complex occurs in terminal complement deficiency, which puts affected individuals at increased risk for Neisseria infections (e.g., Meningococcal meningitis). There is no increased susceptibility to streptococcal infections as seen in this patient.

Defective superoxide production by neutrophils and macrophages is seen in chronic granulomatous disease due to a defect in NADPH oxidase. While this condition is also characterized by recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, infection with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus) is more common, rather than the catalase-negative (e.g., Streptococcus) infections seen in this patient.

Complement factor C3 is a precursor for C3b, which plays a major role in opsonization of pathogens and immune complexes. C3 deficiency results in increased susceptibility to infections by encapsulated bacteria, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis. Patients with C3 deficiency classically present with recurring severe upper respiratory infections (e.g., sinusitis), pneumonia, and meningitis, as seen in this patient.

Patients with selective IgA deficiency are usually asymptomatic but may present with recurrent airway infections (IgA plays an important role in mucosal immunity) and anaphylactic reactions. Although this patient has recurrent upper respiratory infections and current hypersensitivity reaction, her history of recurrent streptococcal meningitis suggests impaired complement-mediated immunity. Moreover, other manifestations of selective IgA deficiency such as atopy and a history of GI infections are missing in this patient.

question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a pruritic rash on her face and extremities for the last year that increases with sun exposure. Her parents report that she often seems clumsy and has had several falls in the last two weeks. Physical examination shows an erythematous, scaly rash with hyperpigmentation over the nasal bridge and cheeks as well as on the dorsal forearms and hands. Urinalysis shows high levels of neutral amino acids. The most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition includes administration of an agent that is associated with which of the following adverse effects?
content_preview: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a pruritic rash on her face and extremities for the last year that increases with sun exposure. Her parents report that she often seems clumsy and has had several falls in the last two weeks. Physical examination shows an erythematous, scaly rash with hyperpigmentation over the nasal bridge and cheeks as well as on the dorsal forearms and hands. Urinalysis shows high levels of neutral amino acids. The most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition includes administration of an agent that is associated with which of the following adverse effects?
hint: Intestinal and renal loss of neutral amino acids (e.g., tryptophan) is characteristic of Hartnup disease. Because tryptophan is a precursor of endogenous synthesis of vitamin B3, its loss results in vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency and symptoms of pellagra (rash on sun-exposed skin, ataxia with clumsiness, and recurrent falls).
learning_objective: Recognize Hartnup disease, and recall the adverse effects of its treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Nephrocalcinosis is seen in patients with chronic hypercalcemia, which can result from vitamin D hyperalimentation. In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin D supplementation. Vitamin D deficiency occurs in patients with malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (D, E, A, and K) rather than neutral amino acids. In children, this deficiency causes rickets.

Bleeding complications such as hemorrhagic stroke or necrotizing enterocolitis (in infants) can result from vitamin E excess because large amounts of vitamin E impair absorption of procoagulatory vitamin K. In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin E supplementation. Though vitamin E deficiency may present with neurological deficits, such as ataxia and muscular weakness, it occurs in patients with impaired fat reabsorption (e.g., cystic fibrosis, celiac disease), which does not explain this patient's isolated neutral aminoaciduria.

Treatment of Hartnup disease consists of both niacin supplementation (nicotinic acid) to correct vitamin B3 deficiency and replenishing the constant loss of amino acids with a high-protein diet. One of the most prominent side effects of niacin is facial flushing due to an increase in prostaglandin synthesis (leads to cutaneous vasodilation). Aspirin or ibuprofen, taken 30–60 minutes prior to administration of niacin, helps suppress prostaglandin production by inactivating cyclooxygenase.

Other adverse effects of niacin include hyperglycemia and hyperuricemia.

images.title: Pellagra
images.description: There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the “4 D's of pellagra” alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

answers.explanation_why: Iatrogenic pseudotumor cerebri can result from chronic vitamin A toxicity (e.g., due to long-term supplementation). In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin A supplementation. Vitamin A deficiency results from impaired fat reabsorption (e.g., cystic fibrosis, celiac disease) rather than malabsorption of neutral amino acids, and manifests with dry skin, night blindness, keratomalacia, and immunosuppression.

Medication-induced, irreversible retinopathy is a side effect of hydroxychloroquine, which is used to treat systemic lupus erythematosus. SLE can also present with a rash, photosensitivity, and proteinuria, as seen in this 5-year-old patient. However, it would not explain her isolated neutral aminoaciduria, which is highly specific for Hartnup disease.

Calcium oxalate kidney stones can result from excessive supplementation of vitamin C (breaks down into oxalate). In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin C supplementation. While Vitamin C deficiency can present with generalized weakness, patients usually have other symptoms, such as swollen gums, poor wound healing, perifollicular hemorrhage, and mucosal bleeding.

question_text: A 38-year-old man with chronic hepatitis C comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of darkening of his skin and painless blisters. He started working as a landscaper 2 weeks ago. He drinks 2 beers every night and occasionally more on the weekends. Examination shows bullae and oozing erosions in different stages of healing on his arms, dorsal hands, and face. There are atrophic white scars and patches of hyperpigmented skin on the arms and face. This patient's skin findings are most likely associated with increased concentration of which of the following?
content_preview: A 38-year-old man with chronic hepatitis C comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of darkening of his skin and painless blisters. He started working as a landscaper 2 weeks ago. He drinks 2 beers every night and occasionally more on the weekends. Examination shows bullae and oozing erosions in different stages of healing on his arms, dorsal hands, and face. There are atrophic white scars and patches of hyperpigmented skin on the arms and face. This patient's skin findings are most likely associated with increased concentration of which of the following?
hint: The painless blisters on sun-exposed areas, which developed shortly after the patient started a job involving outdoor work, indicate photosensitivity. Along with his other skin findings, alcohol consumption, and chronic hepatitis C infection, this history suggests porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT).
learning_objective: Recognize porphyria cutanea tarda, and recall its associated porphyrin accumulation.

answers.explanation_why: Elevated levels of protoporphyrin can be found in iron deficiency and erythropoietic protoporphyria, which results from a deficiency of the enzyme ferrochelatase. Unlike this patient, patients with erythropoietic protoporphyria typically present with nonblistering photosensitivity.

An elevated level of porphobilinogen is a result of a defect in the early steps of heme synthesis, as seen in acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), where the defect is located in porphobilinogen deaminase. However, defects in early heme synthesis are more commonly associated with gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms rather than skin photosensitivity.

Delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) levels are increased in lead poisoning, acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), and ALA-dehydratase deficiency porphyria (ADP), all of which are associated with defects in early steps in the heme synthesis pathway. However, such defects are more commonly associated with gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms rather than skin photosensitivity.

Increased plasma and urine porphyrins, including uroporphyrinogen III, are diagnostic of PCT and are caused by a defect in uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase in the heme synthesis pathway. PCT is the most common porphyria and typically manifests in adults 40–70 years of age with blistering cutaneous photosensitivity (due to accumulation of porphyrins in the skin). The pigmentation changes and scarring in this patient likely developed from previous PCT lesions.

Another feature of PCT visible on gross examination is the color of urine, which looks tea-colored under natural light and pink under fluorescent light (e.g., Wood lamp).

images.title: Heme synthesis and corresponding diseases
images.description: Overview of heme synthesis and its key enzymes as well as the molecular causes of several diseases that interfere with heme synthesis.

answers.explanation_why: Bilirubin is a part of the heme degradation pathway, not the synthesis pathway. Elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin are caused by either increased bilirubin production (e.g., hemolysis, hematoma resorption), defective hepatic uptake of bilirubin, or conjugation disorders (e.g., Gilbert Syndrome, Crigler-Najjar syndrome). Unlike this patient, patients with these disorders typically present with jaundice.

Bilirubin is a part of the heme degradation pathway, not the synthesis pathway. Elevated level of conjugated bilirubin are due to either intrahepatic cholestasis (e.g., hepatocellular injury secondary to infection, cirrhosis, or inflammation), extrahepatic outflow obstructions (e.g., biliary obstruction by calculi, malignancies, strictures), or intracellular defective bilirubin transport disorders (e.g., Dubin-Johnson, Rotor syndrome). Unlike this patient, patients with these disorders typically present with jaundice.
answers.explanation_but: The patient might actually have increased conjugated bilirubin due to his chronic hepatitis C. However, it would not sufficiently explain his skin findings.

question_text: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. Histopathologic examination of the tumor shows a mucinous, poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. Histopathologic examination of the tumor shows a mucinous, poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's family fulfills the 3-2-1 rule of Lynch syndrome: cancer in 3 affected family members, within 2 generations, and in 1 relative under 50 years of age.
learning_objective: Recognize Lynch syndrome, and recall the associated gene mutations.

answers.explanation_why:
Germline mutations in the MLH1 gene result in defective DNA mismatch repair, the underlying cause of Lynch syndrome, which is the most common hereditary form of colorectal cancer. Patients with Lynch syndrome most often have right-sided colon cancers that are diagnosed at a relatively young age (< 50 years old). It is also associated with gastric and endometrial cancer (as seen in this patient's family), as well as ovarian cancer and urothelial cancer. Screening colonoscopy may show a limited number of polyps (usually < 10) or poorly-differentiated tumor growth, as seen in this patient. Other DNA mismatch repair genes include MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

Patients with Lynch syndrome should undergo aggressive screening, which includes annual colonoscopy, pelvic examination for women, and upper endoscopy starting at an early age.

images.title: Colorectal carcinogenesis pathways
images.description:
Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Mutation of the TP53 gene, which encodes p53, is the underlying defect that causes Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Affected patients typically develop sarcomas, breast carcinoma, leukemia, and/or adrenocortical carcinoma. Mutation of the TP53 gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of Lynch syndrome.

Mutation of the DCC gene is responsible for the development of colon cancer. However, it is not linked to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.
Mutation of the KRAS gene is linked to the development of colon, lung, and pancreatic cancer, not to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.

Mutation of the APC gene causes familial adenomatous polyposis. Affected patients have hundreds of colonic polyps that develop in childhood. These can develop into colorectal cancer, often at an early age. However, FAP does not predispose to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which is more commonly seen in patients with Lynch syndrome.

question_text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of blisters and brownish discoloration of urine. His symptoms appeared after he returned from a 4-day trip with his friends in Florida. He has had similar episodes of blistering twice in the past 3 years. Each episode resolved spontaneously after a few weeks. Examination shows vesicles and bullae on the face and the dorsal surfaces of his hands and forearms. His condition is most likely caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of blisters and brownish discoloration of urine. His symptoms appeared after he returned from a 4-day trip with his friends in Florida. He has had similar episodes of blistering twice in the past 3 years. Each episode resolved spontaneously after a few weeks. Examination shows vesicles and bullae on the face and the dorsal surfaces of his hands and forearms. His condition is most likely caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?
hint: This patient with recurrent blisters on the face and dorsum of hands and forearms, and dark urine following sunlight exposure, likely has porphyria cutanea tarda.
learning_objective: Recognize porphyria cutanea tarda, and recall the enzyme deficiency it involves.

answers.explanation_why: A defect in aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase leads to ALA dehydratase porphyria. While there are forms of porphyria that cause dermatological and urinary manifestations, ALA dehydratase porphyria is not one of them. Instead, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, polyneuropathy, and/or psychological disturbances are expected.

A defect in uroporphyrinogen III synthase can lead to congenital erythropoietic porphyria. While CEP can lead to severe photosensitivity and dark urine, it is an incredibly rare disorder that typically manifests in childhood.

A defect in porphobilinogen deaminase causes acute intermittent porphyria. Although AIP may explain this patient's brownish discoloration of urine, it does not cause dermatological manifestations. Additionally, other symptoms, such as a painful abdomen, polyneuropathy, and/or psychological disturbances, are expected.

Insufficiency in uroporphyrinogen III decarboxylase leads to porphyria cutanea tarda. The blistering pattern in this patient is expected for this diagnosis, and his dark urine is a likely result of increased uroporphyrin. As the acquired type of this disease typically manifests in men with liver disease, he should be tested for HIV and HCV as well as fully evaluated for risk factors of alcoholic cirrhosis.

The photosensitivity of patients with cutaneous porphyrias results from activation of porphyrins in the skin by ultraviolet light.

images.title: Heme synthesis and corresponding diseases
images.description: Overview of heme synthesis and its key enzymes as well as the molecular causes of several diseases that interfere with heme synthesis.

answers.explanation_why: A defect in aminolevulinic acid synthase leads to X-linked sideroblastic anemia, which manifests with symptoms typical for anemia (fatigue, lethargy, pallor). It is not expected to cause any dermatological or urinary manifestations.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of crampy abdominal pain, recurrent watery diarrhea, and a 2.5-kg (5.5-lb) weight loss. Her husband has noticed that after meals, her face and neck sometimes become red, and she develops shortness of breath and starts wheezing. Examination shows a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of crampy abdominal pain, recurrent watery diarrhea, and a 2.5-kg (5.5-lb) weight loss. Her husband has noticed that after meals, her face and neck sometimes become red, and she develops shortness of breath and starts wheezing. Examination shows a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
hint: Watery diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, episodic cutaneous flushing triggered by eating or emotional events, asthma-like attacks, and a murmur indicative of tricuspid regurgitation are highly suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. Neuroendocrine neoplasms are highly metabolically active and can secrete excess amounts of serotonin.
learning_objective: Recognize carcinoid syndrome, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Increased gastric pH levels are not associated with carcinoid syndrome but are seen in achlorhydria, which is a key feature of WDHA syndrome (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria) seen in VIPomas. The unregulated production of VIP leads to excessive secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Cutaneous flushing is seen in about 20% of patients with VIPoma. However, abdominal pain is usually mild or absent. Furthermore, this etiology does not explain why the patient also presents with a tricuspid murmur and asthma, neither of which are typical findings of VIPomas.

Laryngeal edema is not associated with carcinoid syndrome but commonly occurs in hereditary angioedema, a bradykinin-mediated reaction that can also cause colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, episodic cutaneous flushing and a tricuspid regurgitation murmur would not be expected. Although mast cell-mediated angioedema can cause flushing, it does not present with abdominal pain or diarrhea.

Dermatitis is a characteristic feature of pellagra, or niacin deficiency; other key findings include dementia and diarrhea (i.e., the “three Ds”). Dermatitis in patients with pellagra is characterized by a symmetrical, pigmented, scaly thickening of the skin in sun-exposed areas, such as the limbs and around the neck (casal necklace). The increased metabolism of serotonin in neuroendocrine neoplasms depletes the amount of tryptophan precursors available for other organic compounds, including niacin. A lack of niacin leads to decreased production of the coenzymes NAD+ and NADP+, which are essential in redox reactions throughout cellular metabolism. Diagnosis is confirmed via 24-hour urine testing for 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), the end product of serotonin metabolism.

In developed countries, pellagra is most commonly seen in patients with alcohol use disorder or as a complication of malabsorption. It can also occur in Hartnup disease (due to renal and intestinal loss of tryptophan) or after prolonged use of isoniazid (due to decreased levels of vitamin B6, which is essential for the production of niacin).

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

answers.explanation_why: Megaloblastic anemia is not caused by carcinoid syndrome but is usually due to folate deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency and is commonly associated with malnutrition or malabsorption. Specific causes for folate deficiency include the use of folate antagonists, whereas vitamin B12 deficiency is seen in pernicious anemia or after gastrectomy. Although malabsorption can occur in carcinoid syndrome, it is usually not severe enough to cause folate or vitamin B12 deficiency. Another complication is more likely to affect this patient.

Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is not associated with carcinoid syndrome but is a complication of celiac disease. Although this patient has had weight loss and diarrhea, she lacks other typical manifestations of celiac disease, such as steatorrhea, malabsorption symptoms (e.g., anemia), and dermatitis herpetiformis. Furthermore, celiac disease does not explain this patient's tricuspid murmur, asthma, and flushing.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. She takes lisinopril for hypertension. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. She takes lisinopril for hypertension. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
hint: This woman has carcinoid syndrome, which manifests with abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and episodic cutaneous flushing and palpitations triggered by food ingestion. The diagnosis is confirmed by laboratory testing that shows an increased urine concentration of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is a product of serotonin metabolism.
learning_objective: Recognize carcinoid syndrome, and recall its cardiac manifestations.

answers.explanation_why: Achlorhydria is seen in patients with VIPoma, a condition that manifests with watery diarrhea, tea-colored stools, and hypokalemia. Although approximately 20% of patients experience flushing symptoms, they typically do not have abdominal pain. Moreover, VIPoma is associated with increased serum concentrations of vasoactive intestinal peptide, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.

Pheochromocytoma can manifest as an adrenal medullary mass and cause episodic hypertension, palpitations, tachycardia, and sweating. However, this malignancy does not typically cause abdominal cramps or diarrhea. Moreover, laboratory changes associated with pheochromocytoma include increased urine concentrations of catecholamines and metanephrines, not increased urine 5-HIAA.

Purple-red colored urine is observed in patients with acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), which also manifests with abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and, during acute attacks, hypertension and tachycardia. In addition, alcohol can precipitate attacks of AIP. However, affected patients typically experience neurological symptoms (e.g., sensory and motor neuropathy, neuropsychiatric symptoms). Moreover, laboratory changes associated with AIP include increased serum and urine concentrations of porphobilinogen, delta-aminolevulinic acid, and porphyrins, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.

Multiple peptic ulcers can result from excessive gastrin secretion due to a gastrinoma, which also manifests with severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. However, this woman has episodic palpitations and facial flushing triggered by food and alcohol, which are not features of a gastrinoma. Moreover, gastrinoma is associated with increased serum concentrations of gastrin and chromogranin A, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.

Pulmonic valve stenosis is a manifestation of carcinoid heart disease, a condition that eventually affects > 50% of patients with carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid heart disease typically develops as a result of chronic exposure of the heart to serotonin from liver metastases. Serotonin enters the inferior vena cava and reaches the right side of the heart, where it induces valvular and myocardial fibrosis. This can lead to pulmonary valve stenosis, tricuspid insufficiency, and right-sided heart failure.

images.title: Carcinoid syndrome
images.description:
Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after suddenly losing consciousness while playing in a soccer tournament. The patient has had 2 episodes of syncope without a discernable trigger over the past year. He has been otherwise healthy. His father died suddenly at the age of 37. He reports lightheadedness and suddenly loses consciousness when physical examination is attempted. Radial pulses are not palpable. An ECG shows ventricular tachycardia with peaks of the QRS twisting around the isoelectric line. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after suddenly losing consciousness while playing in a soccer tournament. The patient has had 2 episodes of syncope without a discernable trigger over the past year. He has been otherwise healthy. His father died suddenly at the age of 37. He reports lightheadedness and suddenly loses consciousness when physical examination is attempted. Radial pulses are not palpable. An ECG shows ventricular tachycardia with peaks of the QRS twisting around the isoelectric line. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Torsades de pointes arrhythmia on ECG (peaks of the QRS twisting around the isoelectric line), a history of unexplained syncope, and a suspected family history of sudden cardiac death are most concerning for Romano-Ward syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Romano-Ward syndrome, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.content: Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery
answers.explanation_why: Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery (ALCAPA) is a congenital anomaly that typically manifests in infants with pallor, irritability, and diaphoresis after feeding and can progress to heart failure. Rarely, some infants outgrow these symptoms and are asymptomatic until adulthood, when they present with syncope or sudden cardiac death. ALCAPA is unlikely to cause torsades de pointes and cannot explain this patient's family history of sudden cardiac death.

An accessory atrioventricular conduction pathway (bundle of Kent) is the pathophysiology of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW), which can present with syncope. However, ECG of a patient with WPW syndrome would be unlikely to reveal torsades de pointes. Instead, it typically shows a decreased PR interval, delta wave (i.e., slurring slow rise of the initial portion of the QRS), and QRS prolongation. Furthermore, WPW syndrome is typically sporadic and only follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance in rare cases.

images.title: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome and pattern
images.description: Conduction pathways and characteristic ECG findings in normal impulse transmission and in WPW syndrome. Note that the condition is referred to as WPW syndrome only if the characteristic ECG findings are present and the patient is also symptomatic or there is evidence of arrhythmia; if the characteristic ECG findings are present without these additional features, the condition is referred to as “WPW pattern.”Left (normal impulse transmission and normal ECG findings): PR interval 120–200 ms; QRS duration < 100 msRight (WPW impulse transmission and characteristic ECG findings): short PR interval < 120 ms; slurred upstroke (delta wave) at the start of the QRS complex with widened QRS ≥ 120 ms

answers.explanation_why: Myofibrillar disarray of the cardiac septum is a feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which is a common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes, and can present with dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope, as seen in this patient. Furthermore, it should be suspected in a patient with a family history of sudden cardiac death, as it follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance in approx. 50% of cases. However, HCM is unlikely to cause torsades de pointes arrhythmia.

A bicuspid aortic valve can cause congenital or acquired aortic stenosis (AS), which can present with syncope on exertion. However, syncope typically occurs in the severe form of AS, and patients would usually have gradual onset of symptoms such as exertional dyspnea, exertional chest pain, easy fatigability, and exercise intolerance. Furthermore, AS is typically sporadic (unlikely to explain this patient's family history of sudden cardiac death), and torsades de pointes arrhythmia is not a typical feature of AS.

A defect in the interatrial septum (i.e., atrial septal defect) is sometimes seen in atrial arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation and/or atrial flutter. However, ASD would not explain this patient's torsades de pointes arrhythmia, nor would it account for his family history of sudden cardiac death.

Torsades de pointes is most often due to long QT syndrome, which may be acquired or congenital. Congenital long QT syndrome can be caused by mutations of genes coding for cardiac potassium, sodium, or calcium ion channels. These mutations cause ventricular action potentials to be prolonged, leading to a lengthened QT interval on ECG. The two most common long QT syndromes are Romano-Ward syndrome and Jervell and Lange-Nielsen (JLN) syndrome.

Jervell and Lange-Nielsen (JLN) syndrome follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance and is associated with congenital deafness. Romano-Ward syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and is not associated with deafness.

images.title: Torsades de pointes
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Bursts of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT; rate ∼ 220/min) alternating with sinus beats
– During the VT phases, the QRS complexes are wide (∼ 200 ms) and appear to be twisting around the isoelectric line, producing a spindle-shaped pattern (best seen in V_1 rhythm strip; indicated by green ellipse).These findings are characteristic of torsades de pointes (TdP), a subtype of polymorphic VT.Note how the sinus rhythm converts to VT/TdP as a result of the R-on-T phenomenon (best seen in rhythm strip V_6): a premature ventricular complex (PVC; red line) occurs in the downslope of the preceding T wave, initiating VT/TdP.

question_text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his parents are concerned that he has been unable to keep up with his classmates at school. He is at the 4^th percentile for height and at the 15^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows dysmorphic facial features. Psychologic testing shows impaired intellectual and adaptive functions. Genetic analysis shows a deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
content_preview: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his parents are concerned that he has been unable to keep up with his classmates at school. He is at the 4th percentile for height and at the 15th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows dysmorphic facial features. Psychologic testing shows impaired intellectual and adaptive functions. Genetic analysis shows a deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
hint: Many genetic conditions are associated with failure to thrive, intellectual disability, and dysmorphic facial features. Genetic analysis in this patient shows a chromosome 7q deletion, which confirms the diagnosis of Williams syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Williams syndrome, and recall its associated cardiac abnormalities.

answers.explanation_why: Hand flapping movements are associated with Angelman syndrome, not Williams syndrome. Although individuals with Angelman syndrome have intellectual disability, the underlying genetic defect is mutation or deletion of the maternally-inherited UBE3A gene on chromosome 15, not deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. Typical facial characteristics of individuals with Angelman syndrome include microcephaly and mouthing behaviors.

Brushfield spots are characteristic of Down syndrome, not Williams syndrome. Although individuals with Down syndrome also have intellectual disability and short stature, the underlying genetic defect is a third copy of chromosome 21, not deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. Typical facial characteristics of individuals with Down syndrome include flat facies and prominent epicanthal folds.

Testicular enlargement is seen in older patients (usually > 8 years) with fragile X syndrome. Additional characteristic findings include intellectual disability, low-set ears, and a long face with an elongated forehead, as seen in this boy. However, affected patients typically have a large body habitus. Also, the underlying genetic defect is in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome, not chromosome 7. Testicular enlargement is not associated with Williams syndrome.

An absent thymus gland is seen in DiGeorge syndrome, not Williams syndrome. Although individuals with DiGeorge syndrome have intellectual disability, the underlying genetic defect is deletion of a portion of chromosome 22 (22q11.2 microdeletion), not chromosome 7. Typical facial characteristics of individuals with DiGeorge syndrome include a prominent nasal bridge, a hypoplastic nose, dysplastic ears, and micrognathia.

images.title: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: A high-pitched, cat-like cry is a distinctive finding in patients with cri-du-chat syndrome, not Williams syndrome. Although individuals with cri-du-chat syndrome have intellectual disability, the underlying genetic defect is deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5, not the long arm of chromosome 7. Typical facial characteristics of individuals with cri-du-chat syndrome include prominent epicanthal folds and ocular hypertelorism.

images.title: Cri-du-chat syndrome (Cat cry syndrome) fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Supravalvular aortic stenosis is classically associated with Williams syndrome. This cardiac abnormality results from loss of the elastin gene that occurs with microdeletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. The dysmorphic facial features seen in Williams syndrome are often described as elfin-like, with a broad forehead, wide mouth, full cheeks and lips, and a long, smooth philtrum. Good verbal skills and friendliness towards strangers (hypersociability) are unique findings of Williams syndrome and are thought to result from deletion of the GTF2I gene.

question_text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He has no history of serious illness. His older sister had an eye disease that required removal of one eye at the age of 3 years. Examination shows inward deviation of the right eye. Penlight examination shows a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He has no history of serious illness. His older sister had an eye disease that required removal of one eye at the age of 3 years. Examination shows inward deviation of the right eye. Penlight examination shows a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
hint: This patient has a unilateral white light reflex (leukocoria), which can be a sign of retinoblastoma. The family history of an eye condition that required enucleation strongly suggests a germline mutation in the retinoblastoma gene.
learning_objective: Recognize retinoblastoma, and recall its associated malignancies.

answers.explanation_why: Neuroblastoma is the most common malignancy in infants. About half of all cases are associated with amplification and overexpression of oncogene MYCN caused by deletions of the short arm of chromosome 1. A higher incidence of neuroblastoma has been described in patients with Hirschsprung disease, neurofibromatosis type 1, and Turner syndrome. However, there is no association with hereditary retinoblastoma.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common hematologic malignancy in children. As a secondary malignancy in patients with hereditary retinoblastoma, however, it is extremely rare. Genetic diseases that increase the risk for development of ALL include Down syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, and ataxia-telangiectasia.

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common cutaneous malignancy and associated with sun exposure. While hereditary retinoblastoma is associated with a higher risk of malignant melanoma, it is not associated with an increased risk for basal cell carcinoma.

Patients with inherited retinoblastoma gene mutations (Rb gene mutations) have a significantly increased risk of developing osteosarcomas. Usually, a germline mutation takes place in one of the alleles of the Rb gene only and development of retinoblastoma does not occur until a spontaneous mutation of the second, priorly functioning allele results in a nonfunctioning Rb gene (two-hit hypothesis). Sporadic retinoblastomas, on the other hand, are caused by two spontaneous mutations in the same retinal cell, affecting both Rb alleles.

All children who present with leukocoria should be considered to have retinoblastoma until proven otherwise and should undergo prompt fundus examination. Molecular genetic testing is recommended in all patients with retinoblastoma to identify germline mutations, as family members may also be at risk.

images.title: Pathophysiology of retinoblastoma
images.description:
In most cases, retinoblastoma is caused by a loss of function mutation in both alleles of RB1 (tumor suppressor gene).Hereditary retinoblastoma (top): Due to a germline mutation (more often de novo than inherited), one altered allele is present in all cells. Retinoblastoma develops if a mutation occurs in the second allele (“second hit”).

Sporadic retinoblastoma (bottom): Initially, both alleles are normal. A mutation must occur in both alleles in the same cell for retinoblastoma to develop.

answers.explanation_why: Most gastric cancers are sporadic; only a minority of cases are associated with hereditary factors (e.g., hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer). There is no increased risk for patients with inherited retinoblastoma gene mutations. Moreover, gastric cancer is extremely rare in children.

Nephroblastoma is the most common renal malignancy in children. Only a minority of cases are associated with loss of function mutations (esp. WT1 gene on chromosome 11) and specific syndromes (e.g., WAGR syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome). There is no increased risk for patients with inherited retinoblastoma gene mutations.
