question_text: A previously healthy 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of anxiety, diarrhea, and a 4.1-kg (9-lb) weight loss. On questioning, he also reports that he noticed a painless mass on his left testicle 2 weeks ago. His pulse is 110/min and irregular and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. Examination shows diaphoresis and a fine tremor of the outstretched fingers. Testicular examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender mass on the left scrotum that does not transilluminate. This patient's underlying condition is most likely to be associated with which of the following findings?
content_preview: A previously healthy 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of anxiety, diarrhea, and a 4.1-kg (9-lb) weight loss. On questioning, he also reports that he noticed a painless mass on his left testicle 2 weeks ago. His pulse is 110/min and irregular and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. Examination shows diaphoresis and a fine tremor of the outstretched fingers. Testicular examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender mass on the left scrotum that does not transilluminate. This patient's underlying condition is most likely to be associated with which of the following findings?
hint: The incidental finding of a testicular mass that does not transilluminate should raise suspicion for testicular cancer. Additionally, the patient's symptoms (anxiety, diarrhea, and weight loss) and other physical examination findings (tachyarrhythmia, hypertension with widened pulse pressure, diaphoresis, fine tremor) are classic features of hyperthyroidism. Paraneoplastic hyperthyroidism is a possible complication of testicular choriocarcinomas.
learning_objective: Recognize testicular cancer presenting with hyperthyroidism, and recall its paraneoplastic syndromes.

answers.explanation_why: Proptosis is associated with hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease. While this patient's symptoms are suggestive of hyperthyroidism, he has no evidence of Graves disease (e.g., diffuse goiter or pretibial myxedema). Furthermore, Graves disease would not account for his testicular mass.

Elevated serum AFP levels are seen in men with certain nonseminomatous germ cell tumors, mainly yolk sac tumors and, less commonly, embryonal carcinoma. While this patient's testicular mass is highly suggestive of a testicular tumor, AFP-producing testicular tumors would not account for his symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

Elevated serum TSH is seen in primary hypothyroidism. This patient has symptoms of hyperthyroidism, which would be associated with low serum TSH. High circulating levels of thyroid hormones in patients with hyperthyroidism suppress secretion of TSH through feedback inhibition.

Central hyperthyroidism would cause elevated levels of serum TSH, but it would not account for this patient's testicular mass.

Positive urine metanephrines are seen in pheochromocytoma, which is associated with symptoms of adrenergic overactivity. The classic symptom triad of pheochromocytoma (episodic headache, sweating, and tachycardia) overlaps with the symptoms of hyperthyroidism present in this patient. However, this patient's testicular mass should raise suspicion for testicular cancer, which would not cause urine metanephrines to be elevated.

Testicular tumors can produce elevated circulating levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). Because the alpha subunits of hCG and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) are identical and the beta subunits of these hormones are structurally very similar, hCG is able to weakly stimulate TSH receptors, resulting in the release of thyroid hormones. In rare cases, conditions with extremely high levels of hCG (e.g., choriocarcinoma, as is the likely diagnosis in this man, or gestational trophoblastic disease in women) may be associated with paraneoplastic hyperthyroidism.

The alpha subunit of hCG is also identical to the alpha subunits of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).

question_text: A 10-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent red urine. During the past 2 years, he has had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His uncle died of kidney disease in his twenties. His blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.5 g/dL, urea nitrogen concentration of 40 mg/dL, and creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 5–7 RBC/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 10-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent red urine. During the past 2 years, he has had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His uncle died of kidney disease in his twenties. His blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.5 g/dL, urea nitrogen concentration of 40 mg/dL, and creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 5–7 RBC/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with features of nephritic syndrome, including hematuria, hypertension, and recurrent edema of the face and feet, and other signs of renal damage (elevated BUN, elevated creatinine). Sensorineural hearing loss in a patient with renal disease and a positive family history is indicative of Alport syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Alport syndrome, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Type IV collagen, which forms a component of basement membranes, plays an important role in the function of glomeruli and inner ear structures (particularly the organ of Corti). An X-linked defect in type IV collagen is responsible for most cases of Alport's syndrome, which results in progressive sensorineural hearing loss (with high-frequency sounds affected first) and hematuria. Episodes of gross hematuria are sometimes preceded by upper respiratory tract infections. Patients with Alport's syndrome also commonly develop an anterior lenticonus since type IV collagen is the predominant collagen fiber in the lens capsule. A family history of renal disease among males is common in patients with Alport's syndrome.

images.title: Alport syndrome
images.description: Electron micrograph of a kidney biopsy sample.The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) demonstrates an irregular thickness, with splitting and a basket-weave appearance (black arrow).These findings are consistent with Alport syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: A WT1 gene mutation is one of the causes of Wilms tumor, which can result in hematuria, hypertension, and anemia. However, Wilms tumor would manifest in early childhood (usually before the age of 5 years) and patients almost always have a palpable abdominal or flank mass on physical examination. It also does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

An autosomal-recessive gene defect in fibrocystin is the cause of autosomal-recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which leads to the development of multiple bilateral kidney cysts. Hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and raised creatinine in a 10-year-old child with an onset of symptoms during infancy and a positive family history might suggest a diagnosis of ARPKD. However, ARPKD does not account for sensorineural deafness. Instead, patients with ARPKD who survive to adolescence usually have evidence of cirrhosis and portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, splenomegaly).

Antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors on podocytes are responsible for membranous nephropathy, which typically presents between the ages of 30 and 50 years with nephrotic syndrome, unlike this 10-year-old boy child with nephritic syndrome. It also does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

Pharyngitis caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS) is common in children 5–15 years of age and can cause poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) 1–3 weeks after the infection. This patient could have had an episode of febrile pharyngitis due to GAS. However, while PSGN would present with nephritic syndrome, it does not explain the 2-year history of intermittent edema or the presence of sensorineural deafness in this patient.

Deposition of IgA in the glomeruli is seen in IgA nephropathy and in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), both of which may present with nephritic syndrome. However, a purpuric rash would typically precede the onset of renal disease in patients with HSP, and other symptoms such as abdominal pain and/or joint pain would be expected. Moreover, both HSP and IgA nephropathy do not explain the sensorineural deafness in this patient.

question_text:
A 65-year-old man with chronic myelogenous leukemia comes to the physician because of severe pain and swelling in both knees for the past day. He finished a cycle of chemotherapy 1 week ago. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F). Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of both knees and the base of his left big toe. Laboratory studies show:

Leukocyte count
13,000/mm^3

Serum

Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL

Calcium
8.2 mg/dL

Phosphorus
7.2 mg/dL

Arthrocentesis of the involved joints is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man with chronic myelogenous leukemia comes to the physician because of severe pain and swelling in both knees for the past day. He finished a cycle of chemotherapy 1 week ago. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F). Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of both knees and the base of his left big toe. Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 13,000/mm3 Serum Creatinine 2.2 mg/dL Calcium 8.2 mg/dL Phosphorus 7.2 mg/dL Arthrocentesis of the involved joints is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with elevated creatinine, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia one week after chemotherapy. This is consistent with tumor lysis syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize tumor lysis syndrome-induced acute gout, and recall the expected arthrocentesis findings.

answers.explanation_why: Granulocytes with cytoplasmic inclusion bodies, also known as ragocytes, would be consistent with autoimmune-related arthropathies, including rheumatoid arthritis and SLE. They are not seen in tumor lysis syndrome.

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs when there is widespread lysis of cancer cells (e.g., from chemotherapy), resulting in the release of large amounts of intracellular components such as nucleic acid, which is further broken down to monosodium urate (uric acid). The subsequent hyperuricemia can lead to the precipitation of monosodium urate crystals in the renal tubules and joints, causing acute kidney injury and triggering gout, as seen in this patient. Arthrocentesis of the involved joints would reveal needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals.

images.title: Tumor lysis syndrome
images.description: Tumor lysis syndrome results from the rapid destruction of tumor cells and subsequent massive release of intracellular components. It occurs most commonly in patients with hematologic malignancies (e.g., ALL, AML, or NHL) at the beginning of cytotoxic treatment, but may also occur spontaneously. The accumulation of uric acid crystals can cause acute kidney injury, and the electrolyte imbalances can have life-threatening consequences such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.

answers.explanation_why: Deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals within the joint space is the pathomechanism of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease. Arthritis in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease commonly affects only one joint (usually the knee), and arthroscopy typically reveals rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. The disease is usually idiopathic, but can be caused by hemochromatosis, hyperparathyroidism, or trauma to the joint. Calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition is not a sequela of tumor lysis syndrome.

images.title: Synovial fluid crystals in pseudogout
images.description: Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopyCalcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals with typical rhomboid shapes. They appear blue when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer and yellow when their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer (positive birefringence). The overall birefringence of CPP crystals is weak compared to monosodium urate crystals.

answers.explanation_why: Calcium phosphate crystals are non-birefringent, globular crystals associated with degenerative joint diseases, such as osteoarthritis. Patients with this condition have chronic joint disease of the weight-bearing joints and morning stiffness lasting less than 30 minutes. While tumor lysis syndrome can lead to deposition of calcium phosphate crystals in the kidneys (predisposing to acute kidney injury), deposition of these crystals in the joints is not a sequela of tumor lysis syndrome.

Gram-negative diplococci in the synovial fluid culture would be concerning for gonococcal arthritis, a type of oligoarthritis commonly seen in sexually active adults. It presents either as monoarthritis (e.g., of the knee), or as polyarthralgia with dermatitis and tenosynovitis. Tumor lysis syndrome does not predispose to gonococcal arthritis.

Gram-positive cocci in clusters in the joint space would be consistent with septic arthritis due to Staphylococcus aureus. Patients typically present with acute monoarticular joint pain, swelling, and fever. Risk factors include prosthetic joints, skin infection, or IV drug abuse. Tumor lysis syndrome does not predispose to septic arthritis.

question_text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of easy bruising and fatigue. She appears pale. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows a palm-sized hematoma on her left leg. Abdominal examination shows an enlarged liver and spleen. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,300/mm^3, platelet count is 55,000/mm^3, and fibrinogen concentration is 120 mg/dL (N = 150–400). Cytogenetic analysis of leukocytes shows a reciprocal translocation of chromosomes 15 and 17. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient at this time?
content_preview: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of easy bruising and fatigue. She appears pale. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows a palm-sized hematoma on her left leg. Abdominal examination shows an enlarged liver and spleen. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,300/mm3, platelet count is 55,000/mm3, and fibrinogen concentration is 120 mg/dL (N = 150–400). Cytogenetic analysis of leukocytes shows a reciprocal translocation of chromosomes 15 and 17. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient at this time?
hint: A chromosomal t(15;17) translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (M3).
learning_objective: Recognize acute promyelocytic leukemia, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Platelet transfusion would be indicated in the case of serious bleeding with a platelet count < 50,000/mm^3 and in asymptomatic patients with a platelet count < 10,000/mm^3, neither of which is the case here.

Rituximab, an anti-CD-20 monoclonal antibody that targets B cells, is used to treat autoimmune diseases and leukemias/lymphomas (e.g., chronic lymphocytic leukemia; CLL). CLL is typically a disease that affects older individuals and manifests with B symptoms, splenomegaly, painless lymphadenopathy, and laboratories showing extreme leukocytosis. Finally, CLL does not explain the reciprocal translocation of chromosomes 15 and 17 in her leukocytes.

Retinoic acid binds its nuclear receptors to stimulate histone acetylation, which promotes gene expression that regulates the maturation and proliferation of granulocytes. The t(15;17) translocation causes acute promyelocytic leukemia by altering the retinoic acid receptor such that physiologic levels of retinoic acid no longer activate it. High-dose all-trans retinoic acid activates the mutated receptor and thereby restores maturation of otherwise malignant granulocytes.

Some subtypes of AML (especially M3) exhibit characteristic Auer rods, which are pinkish-red, rod-shaped granular components within the cytoplasm.

The tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib is appropriate as first-line targeted therapy for patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). CML may present with splenomegaly and B symptoms, as seen here. However, in > 90% of cases, CML is caused by a chromosomal t(9;22) translocation, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, rather than a chromosomal t(15;17) translocation.

Cyclophosphamide is used for induction therapy in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and other conditions requiring myelosuppression, such as autoimmune diseases. Alkylating agents such as cyclophosphamide may increase the risk of developing AML, but they are usually not part of first-line treatment in patients with acute leukemias.

question_text:
A 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) female newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The mother had regular prenatal visits throughout the pregnancy. The newborn's blood pressure is 53/35 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion. One day later, serum studies show:

Na^+
131 mEq/L

K^+
5.4 mEq/L

Cl^−

102 mEq/L

Urea nitrogen
15 mg/dL

Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL

Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis shows a normal uterus and ovaries. Further evaluation of the newborn is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) female newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The mother had regular prenatal visits throughout the pregnancy. The newborn's blood pressure is 53/35 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion. One day later, serum studies show: Na+ 131 mEq/L K+ 5.4 mEq/L Cl− 102 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 15 mg/dL Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis shows a normal uterus and ovaries. Further evaluation of the newborn is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This female newborn presents with hypotension, ambiguous external genitalia (clitoromegaly with labial fusion), hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, all of which are characteristic of the salt-losing form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) is a direct precursor for estrogen and testosterone biosynthesis, and therefore, will be elevated (not decreased) in patients with hyperandrogenism due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Increased levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone, the physiological substrate for 21-hydroxylase, confirm the diagnosis of 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This enzyme deficiency is the most common cause of CAH and results in decreased synthesis of mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone) and glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisone). Hypoaldosteronism causes hypotension and hyperkalemia and hypocortisolism leads to an increase in the secretion of ACTH from the pituitary gland. Stimulation of the adrenal cortex by ACTH results in adrenal hyperplasia and increased production of adrenal androgens from steroid precursors such as 17-hydroxyprogesterone, thereby causing virilization in female individuals.

images.title: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia on steroid pathway and affecting drugs

answers.explanation_why: Increased levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone are seen in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency (another cause of CAH), which also manifests with female virilization. However, 11β-hydroxylase deficiency typically manifests with hypertension and hypokalemia rather than hypotension and hyperkalemia. In addition, 11-deoxycorticosterone is synthesized by 21-hydroxylase from progesterone in the aldosterone synthesis pathway and would thus be decreased, not increased, in this patient.

The lack of aldosterone in patients with 21-hydroxylase deficiency leads to decreased Na^+ resorption (hyponatremia), decreased K^+  secretion (hyperkalemia), and decreased H^+ secretion (metabolic acidosis). Therefore, serum bicarbonate would be decreased, not increased in this patient, in an effort to buffer the lower pH.

Levels of increased corticosterone, 11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC), and other precursors of the aldosterone synthesis pathway, are seen in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. These patients also present with hypocortisolism and hypoaldosteronism, but are typically hypertensive and have hypoandrogenism. Unlike this patient's condition, 17α-hydroxylase deficiency causes hypokalemia, and affected girls have normal external genitalia at birth, but delayed or absent puberty later in life. Although an increase in aldosterone would be expected in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, high levels of DOC (which has aldosterone-like activity) inhibit renin and therefore aldosterone production. Hypertension occurs despite hypoaldosteronism because DOC possesses mineralocorticoid activity.

Plasma renin activity is increased, not decreased, in patients with 21-hydroxylase deficiency as a result of the low blood pressure and salt-wasting induced by the lack of aldosterone production. Decreased renin activity is seen in patients with 11β-hydroxylase deficiency.

question_text:
A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after his neighbor found him collapsed on his front porch in a pool of vomitus. On arrival, he is oriented only to self. His pulse is 103/min and respirations are 30/min. Neurologic examination shows muscle spasms in the arms and jaw. Serum studies show:

Na^+

137 mEq/L

Cl^-

99 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

8 mEq/L

Osmolality
328 mOsmol/kg H_2O

The difference between the calculated and observed serum osmolality is 32 mOsmol/kg H_2O. Urinalysis shows oxalate crystals. This patient is most likely experiencing toxicity from which of the following substances?
content_preview: A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after his neighbor found him collapsed on his front porch in a pool of vomitus. On arrival, he is oriented only to self. His pulse is 103/min and respirations are 30/min. Neurologic examination shows muscle spasms in the arms and jaw. Serum studies show: Na+ 137 mEq/L Cl- 99 mEq/L HCO3- 8 mEq/L Osmolality 328 mOsmol/kg H2O The difference between the calculated and observed serum osmolality is 32 mOsmol/kg H2O. Urinalysis shows oxalate crystals. This patient is most likely experiencing toxicity from which of the following substances?
hint: This patient presents with acute encephalopathy, signs of tetany (muscle spasms), and hyperventilation. His laboratory studies are notable for an elevated anion gap AG = 137 - (99 + 8) = 30 and an elevated osmolar gap (32 mOsmol/kg H_2O). The presence of oxalate crystals in the urine indicates that he ingested a substance that is metabolized to oxalate.
learning_objective: Recognize ethylene glycol toxicity, and recall its metabolic products.

answers.explanation_why: Methanol is an alcohol that is metabolized to formate, a toxic substance that can cause end-organ damage. Although methanol poisoning would explain many of this man's symptoms (anion gap, altered mental status, increased serum osmolar gap), the key distinguishing feature in this patient is the formation of urine oxalate crystals, which is not seen with methanol toxicity.
answers.explanation_but: Methanol poisoning classically causes optic neuropathy with resulting optic disc hyperemia (blurred vision or blindness).

answers.explanation_why: Ethylene glycol is enzymatically oxidized by alcohol dehydrogenase, then aldehyde dehydrogenase, to form oxalate, glyoxylate, and glycolate. These metabolites collect in the renal system and are detectable in the urine as oxalate crystals, which can cause flank pain, hematuria, oliguria, and acute kidney injury. Hypocalcemia, the cause of this patient's tetany, is a result of calcium being consumed by oxalate to form calcium oxalate. Other signs of ethylene glycol poisoning include altered mental status and tachypnea (due to respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis). Treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning consists of fomepizole to competitively inhibit alcohol dehydrogenase, as ethylene glycol itself is not nearly as toxic as its metabolites.

Parathion is an organophosphate that can cause cholinergic toxicity. Although this patient's altered mental status and vomiting may also be seen in organophosphate poisoning, oxalate crystals would not be seen. Additionally, he lacks the other classic symptoms of cholinergic toxicity (e.g., miosis, bradycardia, and diaphoresis), which makes this an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

Isopropyl alcohol ingestion can cause altered mental status and elevated osmolar gap, which are seen in this patient. However, it would not explain the elevated anion gap or oxalate crystals in the urine.

Aspirin toxicity can cause altered mental status, vomiting, tachypnea, and an anion gap, which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, this condition would not explain the urine oxalate crystals.
answers.explanation_but: Aspirin toxicity causes early respiratory alkalosis because the drug stimulates the respiratory center of the CNS, resulting in tachypnea. It then causes late elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis because the drug itself is acidic.

question_text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue, constipation, and a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight gain. Menses occur irregularly in intervals of 40–50 days. Her pulse is 51/min, and blood pressure is 145/86 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and cool, dry skin. There is mild, nonpitting periorbital edema. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration is 8.1 μU/mL. Treatment with the appropriate pharmacotherapy is initiated. After several weeks of therapy with this drug, which of the following hormonal changes is expected?
content_preview: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue, constipation, and a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight gain. Menses occur irregularly in intervals of 40–50 days. Her pulse is 51/min, and blood pressure is 145/86 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and cool, dry skin. There is mild, nonpitting periorbital edema. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration is 8.1 μU/mL. Treatment with the appropriate pharmacotherapy is initiated. After several weeks of therapy with this drug, which of the following hormonal changes is expected?
hint: The patient's signs and symptoms of fatigue, constipation, weight gain, menstrual irregularities, bradycardia, hypertension, dry skin, and periorbital edema are all suggestive of hypothyroidism. The increased serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentration indicates that she has primary hypothyroidism, for which the treatment is hormone replacement with levothyroxine.
learning_objective: Recognize primary hypothyroidism treatment, and recall the expected hormonal changes post-therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Levothyroxine a synthetic form of thyroxine (T4). The level of T4 would therefore be expected to increase with levothyroxine therapy.

Levothyroxine is a synthetic form of T4, which is converted to reverse T3 (biologically inactive) and T3 (biologically active) by a deiodinase in the blood. Since an increase of reactants leads to an increase in products, rT3 would be expected to increase after several weeks of levothyroxine therapy. T3 and T4 negatively regulate the secretion of TRH from the hypothalamus and of TSH from the anterior pituitary.

Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) is produced by the liver and, together with other serum binding proteins (transthyretin, albumin, lipoproteins), it is responsible for transporting T3 and T4 and maintaining their serum concentrations within narrow limits. Only the serum-free concentration of thyroid hormones (< 0.5%) is biologically active. TBG is not affected by levothyroxine therapy. TBG level is typically elevated by factors that increase estrogen such as pregnancy and OCP use, whereas TBG level is decreased in hepatic failure, nephrotic syndrome, and in response to elevated corticosteroids.

Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) is typically elevated in uncorrected primary hypothyroidism due to the loss of thyroxin feedback inhibition. Levothyroxine would exert feedback inhibition on the secretion of TRH from the hypothalamus, resulting in decreased levels of TRH.

Levothyroxine is a synthetic form of T4, which is converted to T3 (biologically active) by a deiodinase in the blood. Since an increase of reactants leads to an increase in product, T3 would be expected to increase after several weeks of levothyroxine therapy.

question_text:
A 4-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of lethargy and vomiting since he woke up 1 hour ago. The mother says that he last breastfed the previous evening and slept through the night for the first time. His family recently immigrated from Bolivia. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and enlarged, reddened tonsils. Serum studies show:

Glucose
42 mg/dL

Ketones

0.2 mg/dL (N ≤ 1)

AST
76 U/L

ALT
120 U/L

Ammonia

80 μg/dL (N = 15–45)

Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
content_preview: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of lethargy and vomiting since he woke up 1 hour ago. The mother says that he last breastfed the previous evening and slept through the night for the first time. His family recently immigrated from Bolivia. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and enlarged, reddened tonsils. Serum studies show: Glucose 42 mg/dL Ketones 0.2 mg/dL (N ≤ 1) AST 76 U/L ALT 120 U/L Ammonia 80 μg/dL (N = 15–45) Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
hint: This patient's presentation of vomiting, lethargy, hypoglycemia, and hyperammonemia without compensatory ketosis after both night-time fasting and a presumed URTI (fever, enlarged and reddened tonsils) indicates a problem with the metabolism of a ketone precursor.
learning_objective: Recognize medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency, and recall its metabolic effects.

answers.explanation_why: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes classic phenylketonuria due to a toxic build-up of phenylalanine. The disease has an insidious onset and causes a pale skin (due to lack of tyrosine), musty body odor, failure to thrive, loss of motor control, intellectual disability, and seizure. This patient does not have these features.

images.title: Classic phenylketonuria vs. tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency (malignant PKU)

answers.explanation_why:
Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) degrades medium-chain fatty acids into acetyl-CoA in the mitochondria (β-oxidation). Acetyl-CoA is used for allosteric modulation of pyruvate carboxylase (to promote gluconeogenesis), ATP generation (in Krebs cycle), or ketone body formation. When glucose and glycogen stores are depleted, for example, after this patient's fasting (e.g., during weaning, skipping nightly feeds) or a state of increased metabolic demand (e.g., infection, exercise), the body normally relies on fatty acid metabolism. But in patients with MCAD deficiency, a deficit of acetyl-CoA develops, which leads to hyperammonemia, hypoglycemia without ketosis, vomiting, and lethargy, as seen in this patient. Without intervention, the condition can progress to seizure and coma.

Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency is routinely screened in neonates. To prevent symptoms, patients are advised to adopt a diet consisting of frequent high-carbohydrate and low-fat meals and avoid fasting or metabolic decompensation.

Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency causes Hurler syndrome, a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by intracellular glycosaminoglycan accumulation. Patients present with developmental delay, corneal clouding, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated urine glycosaminoglycan concentration. This patient does not have these features.

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency causes classic galactosemia; this enzyme converts galactose-1-phosphate into uridine diphosphate galactose (UDP-galactose). Hence, galactose-1-phosphate and its toxic byproducts (galactitol) will accumulate inside cells when infants start breastfeeding. Presenting features include nausea, vomiting, cataracts, hepatosplenomegaly, seizure, and failure to thrive. Although this patient has vomiting and lethargy, he lacks other clinical features despite breastfeeding.

Propionyl-CoA carboxylase catalyzes the conversion of propionyl-CoA, which is a catabolic byproduct of odd-chain fatty acid and certain essential amino acids (valine, isoleucine, methionine, threonine), into methylmalonyl-CoA. Hence, deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of propionic acid and ammonia. Although patients with propionyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency present with vomiting, lethargy, and hyperammonemia, they have ketoacidosis, unlike this patient.

Lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase deficiency causes Pompe disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of lysosomal glycogen-like inclusions. The disease predominantly affects tissues with high glycogen stores such as liver, muscle, and heart. Hence, the presenting clinical features include hypotonia, exercise intolerance, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which are not present in this patient.

question_text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her son says that she frequently stumbles into the nightstand when she gets up to go to the bathroom at night. She has a history of celiac disease and frequent bouts of diarrhea. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows generalized dry skin, multiple bruises on the shins, and triangular keratin plaques on the temporal conjunctiva. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her son says that she frequently stumbles into the nightstand when she gets up to go to the bathroom at night. She has a history of celiac disease and frequent bouts of diarrhea. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination shows generalized dry skin, multiple bruises on the shins, and triangular keratin plaques on the temporal conjunctiva. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
hint: This patient's dry skin, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva, as well as stumbling at night and a history of celiac disease are consistent with a specific vitamin deficiency.
learning_objective: Recall the clinical manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is an antioxidant and enzymatic cofactor that helps to enhance iron absorption in redox and hydroxylation reactions. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) can lead to bruising and immunosuppression, the latter of which is consistent with this patient's 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. However, immunosuppression is not specific to scurvy and this patient does not have other dermatological manifestations of scurvy such as perifollicular hemorrhages, petechiae, and corkscrew hairs. Her history of frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva suggest a different deficiency.

Vitamin A deficiency (retinol deficiency) can be seen in conditions of fat malabsorption, such as inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn disease), celiac disease, cystic fibrosis, and pancreatic insufficiency. Because vitamin A is involved in epithelial cell differentiation and retinal pigmentation, retinol deficiency results in dermatological and ophthalmological manifestations, such as xerosis cutis and Bitot spots. A deficiency in vitamin A can also cause immunosuppression, which explains this patient's recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Moreover, this patient's recent history of stumbling in the dark most likely results from night blindness (nyctalopia), another common manifestation of vitamin A deficiency.

Zinc is an essential mineral required for the function of many enzymes. Zinc deficiency can cause diarrhea and immunosuppression. While zinc deficiency has dermatological manifestations, it causes acrodermatitis enteropathica rather than xerosis cutis. This patient does not have other expected symptoms of zinc deficiency, such as delayed wound healing, dysgeusia, and anosmia. Moreover, her frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva suggest a different deficiency.

Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B_5) is a cofactor in acyl transfer reactions and fatty acid synthesis. While vitamin B_5 deficiency manifests with nonspecific symptoms including dermatitis and diarrhea, it also causes alopecia and adrenal insufficiency, which are not observed in this patient. Furthermore, vitamin B_5 deficiency would not explain this patient's frequent stumbling at night or recurrent infections.

Riboflavin (vitamin B_2) is a cofactor in redox reactions, such as those involved in the tricarboxylic acid cycle. Riboflavin deficiency causes cheilosis and corneal vascularization. This patient has neither of these findings, and the presence of frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva point to a different vitamin deficiency.

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a cofactor in redox reactions and is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Niacin deficiency causes glossitis and can lead to pellagra in severe cases. Pellagra typically causes dermatitis involving the C3 and C4 dermatomes around the neck rather than generalized dry skin. Pellagra can also cause diarrhea, but this patient's diarrhea is likely due to celiac disease. Also, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva and frequent stumbling at night suggest a different vitamin deficiency.

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

question_text: An 8-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting and poor feeding. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and he was born at full term. He appears pale and lethargic. Physical examination shows diffusely increased muscle tone. His urine is noted to have a sweet odor. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by the accumulation of which of the following?
content_preview: An 8-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting and poor feeding. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and he was born at full term. He appears pale and lethargic. Physical examination shows diffusely increased muscle tone. His urine is noted to have a sweet odor. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by the accumulation of which of the following?
hint: Poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and hypertonia are nonspecific symptoms; however, the presence of a sweet-smelling urine strongly raises the suspicion of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).
learning_objective: Recognize maple syrup urine disease, and recall the amino acids that accumulate.

answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (valine, leucine, isoleucine) due to a deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase causes MSUD. If untreated, affected neonates develop severe CNS damage, which can lead to coma and death. MSUD can be diagnosed by the presence of alpha-ketoacids of branched chain amino acids in serum. Treatment involves avoidance of dietary branched-chain amino acids and thiamine supplementation.

Phytanic acid accumulation occurs in patients with Refsum disease. Patients with this condition typically develop scaly skin, ataxia, sensorineural hearing loss, and vision loss during adolescence but are asymptomatic during childhood. Refsum disease does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

Homogentisic acid accumulation occurs in patients with homogentisate oxidase deficiency (alkaptonuria). Patients with this condition can develop ochronosis as adults but are typically asymptomatic during childhood. Urine may become darker on prolonged exposure to air but alkaptonuria does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

Homocysteine accumulation occurs with hereditary deficiency of cystathionine synthase or methionine synthase. Neonates with either of these deficiencies are typically asymptomatic but older children can present with osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease (e.g., stroke, coronary artery disease), and/or failure to thrive. Homocystinuria does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

Phenylalanine accumulation occurs in patients with phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency (phenylketonuria). This condition causes a musty odor in the urine, not a sweet-smelling odor. Moreover, symptoms of phenylketonuria (e.g. seizures, delayed development, intellectual disability, eczema) do not manifest until 2–4 weeks after birth due to the presence of maternal phenylalanine hydroxylase in the baby's serum.

question_text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of recurrent vomiting and yellowing of his eyes. The mother says that he has been eating poorly since she started weaning him off of breast milk 5 days ago. At this time, mashed vegetables and fruits were added to his diet. Examination shows scleral jaundice and dry mucous membranes. The tip of the liver is palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin. His serum glucose concentration is 47 mg/dL, serum alanine aminotransferase is 55 U/L, and serum aspartate aminotransferase is 66 U/L. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient?
content_preview: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of recurrent vomiting and yellowing of his eyes. The mother says that he has been eating poorly since she started weaning him off of breast milk 5 days ago. At this time, mashed vegetables and fruits were added to his diet. Examination shows scleral jaundice and dry mucous membranes. The tip of the liver is palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin. His serum glucose concentration is 47 mg/dL, serum alanine aminotransferase is 55 U/L, and serum aspartate aminotransferase is 66 U/L. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient?
hint: Given this infant's liver enlargement, low serum glucose, elevated liver enzymes, and jaundice after the addition of new foods while weaning, he likely has hereditary fructose intolerance.
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary fructose intolerance, and recall the enzyme deficiency associated with it.

answers.explanation_why: Galactokinase deficiency develops during infancy while breastfeeding, since galactose is present in breast milk. This patient's age is consistent with this condition, but it does not manifest during weaning. Galactokinase deficiency cause cataracts in early infancy because of accumulation of galactitol in the lenses. It does not manifest with hypoglycemia and abnormal liver function tests, as seen in this patient.

Deficiency of the glycogen debranching enzyme causes type III glycogen storage disease (Cori disease). It manifests with hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, which are seen in this patient. However, it is not associated with weaning. It also causes generalized muscle weakness and/or cramps, hyperlipidemia, and fasting intolerance (mild hypoglycemia and ketosis), none of which are seen here.

Deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase causes classic galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism that results in hepatomegaly, jaundice, poor feeding, vomiting, and hypoglycemia, which are all seen in this patient. However, this condition manifests soon after birth, since galactose is present in breast milk and formula.

Aldolase B deficiency causes hereditary fructose intolerance, which manifests with vomiting, poor feeding, hypoglycemia, jaundice, and hepatomegaly. Aldolase B normally catalyzes the breakdown of fructose-1-phosphate to glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone phosphate. Symptoms manifest around the time of weaning, as food containing fructose and/or sucrose is added to the diet at that time. Treatment of this condition involves a lifelong fructose-free and sucrose-free diet.

images.title: Mechanisms of fructose intolerance
images.description: (1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Fructokinase deficiency causes essential fructosuria, which manifests with asymptomatic accumulation of fructose, leading to excretion of fructose in urine. Essential fructosuria does not cause liver enlargement, low serum glucose, elevated liver enzymes, or jaundice.

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke disease), a glycogen storage disease, causes hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia in infants around 3–6 months of age, which would be consistent with this patient. However, weaning plays no role in this disease process, which also causes severe hyperlipidemia, failure to thrive, poor fasting tolerance with mild ketosis, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.

question_text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of poor feeding and irritability. She is at the 15^th percentile for height and 5^th percentile for weight. Examination shows hypotonia and wasting of skeletal muscles. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is hepatomegaly. Her serum glucose is 61 mg/dL, creatine kinase is 100 U/L, and lactic acid is within the reference range. Urine ketone bodies are elevated. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
content_preview: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of poor feeding and irritability. She is at the 15th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Examination shows hypotonia and wasting of skeletal muscles. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is hepatomegaly. Her serum glucose is 61 mg/dL, creatine kinase is 100 U/L, and lactic acid is within the reference range. Urine ketone bodies are elevated. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
hint: This infant's combination of failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, muscle wasting, mild hypoglycemia, and ketosis indicates Cori disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Cori disease, and recall the deficient enzyme involved.

answers.explanation_why: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to the development of McArdle disease. It presents during adolescence or early adulthood with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, weakness, myoglobinuria and elevated creatine kinase level. Although this patient has hypotonia, her early presentation, hepatomegaly, and hypoglycemia are inconsistent with McArdle disease.

Acid alpha-glucosidase (lysosomal acid maltase) deficiency causes Pompe disease, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by lysosomal glycogen-like inclusion bodies. It presents in the first 2 months of life with muscle weakness, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, respiratory distress, failure to thrive, and hearing loss. Although this patient has hypotonia and hepatomegaly, she does not have cardiac involvement, which is a cardinal feature of Pompe disease. Moreover, Pompe disease does not present with hypoglycemia.

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leads to the development of von Gierke disease, which presents with hepatomegaly and mild ketosis. However, other key clinical features of this disease, such as severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia, are absent in this patient.

Glucocerebrosidase deficiency causes Gaucher disease, a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by intracellular accumulation of glucocerebroside. It presents with hepatosplenomegaly, fractures, neurological symptoms, pancytopenia, and macrophages with crumpled paper-like inclusions (Gaucher cells). Despite having hepatomegaly, this patient lacks other presenting features of Gaucher disease.

Cori disease is an autosomal recessive glycogen storage disorder resulting from a deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme, which performs 2 functions as α-1,6-glucosidase and 4-α-D-glucanotransferase. It presents with hypotonia, muscle wasting, mild hypoglycemia, and ketosis, as observed in this patient.

question_text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of right flank pain that radiates to the groin. She has no history of major medical illness. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. A urine dipstick is positive for blood. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following sets of laboratory findings?

Serum Ca^2+

Serum uric acid
Urine Ca^2+

Urine pH
Urine cystine

A
Normal
normal
increased
decreased
normal

B
Normal
normal
normal
normal
normal

C
Normal
normal
normal
increased
normal

D
Normal
increased
normal
decreased
normal

E
Increased
normal
increased
increased
normal

F
Normal
normal
normal
decreased
increased
content_preview: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of right flank pain that radiates to the groin. She has no history of major medical illness. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. A urine dipstick is positive for blood. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following sets of laboratory findings? Serum Ca2+ Serum uric acid Urine Ca2+ Urine pH Urine cystine A Normal normal increased decreased normal B Normal normal normal normal normal C Normal normal normal increased normal D Normal increased normal decreased normal E Increased normal increased increased normal F Normal normal normal decreased increased
hint: This patient's flank pain and hematuria are most likely due to nephrolithiasis. Urinary stones are most commonly composed of calcium oxalate.
learning_objective: Recognize nephrolithiasis, and recall the laboratory findings associated with the most common type of urinary stones.

answers.explanation_why: Calcium oxalate stones are overall the most common stone seen in nephrolithiasis and idiopathic hypercalciuria is the most common risk factor for this type of stone formation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show hypercalciuria and decreased urine pH; serum calcium and uric acid would be expected to be normal. Other risk factors for the development of calcium oxalate stones include Crohn disease, ethylene glycol toxicity, hypocitraturia, and vitamin C toxicity.

images.title: Calcium oxalate crystals in urine
images.description: Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

answers.explanation_why: Renal stones typically form when there are one or more predisposing factors favoring precipitation of salts (e.g., urinary supersaturation due to ↓ urinary flow or ↑ renal excretion of solutes, alterations in normal urinary pH due to hyperuricemia, drugs, or infections). Healthy individuals who are not on any medication and who have normal levels of serum calcium, serum uric acid, urine calcium, and urine cystine, as well as a normal urine pH, are unlikely to develop renal stones.

Alkaline urine with otherwise normal lab values would be consistent with a patient with struvite stones. Alkaline urine is typically seen in patients with UTIs caused by urease-producing organisms, which convert urea to the basic compound ammonia. Ammonia combines with water to form ammonium, which under basic conditions combines with phosphate and magnesium to form struvite stones. Struvite stones are rare and only account for 5–10% of all kidney stones. This patient lacks a history of recurrent UTI or indwelling urinary catheter and therefore is unlikely to have struvite stones.

images.title: Struvite crystals
images.description:
Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 9 (light microscopy)Multiple coffin-shaped clear rectangular prisms are visible.
Numerous RBCs (biconvex anucleate cells) and WBCs (round nucleated cells) are also visible, indicating a concurrent UTI.These coffin-shaped crystals are struvite crystals, which typically develop in alkaline urine.

answers.explanation_why: These lab results would be seen in patients with uric acid stones, an uncommon type of nephrolithiasis (∼ 5-10%) primarily seen in patients with underlying hyperuricemia (e.g., tumor lysis syndrome, gout) and hyperuricosuria. Low urine pH favors the formation of uric acid stones. This patient does not have a history of any condition that would predispose her to uric acid stone formation and a different set of findings is more likely.

images.title: Uric acid crystals
images.description: Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

answers.explanation_why: These lab results would be seen in a patient with calcium phosphate stones, the second most common type of calcium kidney stone. Etiological factors for calcium phosphate stones include hypercalciuria (e.g., idiopathic or due to hyperparathyroidism) and hypocitraturia. Serum calcium is usually normal in patients with calcium stones, but it can be elevated, especially if hyperparathyroidism is the underlying cause. Calcium phosphate stones precipitate in alkaline urine (e.g., as in renal tubular acidosis). This patient does not have any history of risk factors for calcium phosphate stone formation and a different set of findings is more likely.

These lab results would be seen in patients with cystine stones, which account for ∼ 1% of kidney stones and are typically only seen in patients with cystinuria. Cystinuria classically presents with recurrent nephrolithiasis beginning in childhood and is also characterized by impaired reabsorption of ornithine, arginine, and lysine. Cystine precipitates in acidic urinary pH and may form staghorn calculi. The absence of a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis or positive family history makes this set of findings unlikely in this patient.

question_text: A newborn is delivered at term to a 38-year-old woman after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The newborn's blood pressure is 142/85 mm Hg. Examination shows clitoral enlargement and labioscrotal fusion. Serum studies show a sodium of 151 mg/dL and a potassium of 3.2 mg/dL. Karyotype analysis shows a 46, XX karyotype. The patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that is normally responsible for which of the following reactions?
content_preview: A newborn is delivered at term to a 38-year-old woman after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The newborn's blood pressure is 142/85 mm Hg. Examination shows clitoral enlargement and labioscrotal fusion. Serum studies show a sodium of 151 mg/dL and a potassium of 3.2 mg/dL. Karyotype analysis shows a 46, XX karyotype. The patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that is normally responsible for which of the following reactions?
hint: This genotypically female newborn presents with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension, and electrolyte abnormalities consistent with excess mineralocorticoids (hypernatremia, hypokalemia), which should raise suspicion for a certain type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Further evaluation is likely to show decreased serum renin activity.
learning_objective: Recognize 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, and recall the enzyme's role in steroidogenesis.

answers.explanation_why: 21β-hydroxylase converts progesterone to 11-deoxycorticosterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to 11-deoxycortisol. Genotypically female patients with 21β-hydroxylase deficiency experience virilization due to excess androgen production. These patients are mineralocorticoid deficient due to lack of aldosterone precursor production and therefore experience sodium wasting (hyponatremia, hypotension) and potassium retention (hyperkalemia). This patient is hypertensive and hypokalemic, suggesting a different enzyme deficiency.

This patient's findings are consistent with 11β-hydroxylase deficiency. Normally, 11β-hydroxylase converts 11-deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone and 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol. 11β-hydroxylase deficiency causes excess 11-deoxycorticosterone and 11-deoxycortisol build up. 11-deoxycorticosterone is a mineralocorticoid precursor that possesses aldosterone-like properties. Increased levels therefore cause sodium retention (hypernatremia, hypertension) and potassium wasting (hypokalemia). Genotypically female patients also experience virilization (ambiguous genitalia) due to excess androgen production.

images.title: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia on steroid pathway and affecting drugs

answers.explanation_why: Aromatase converts androstenedione to estrone, and thus is responsible for the conversion of androgens to estrogens. Genotypically female (XX) patients with aromatase deficiency are born with ambiguous external genitalia but normal female internal genitalia. They experience primary amenorrhea and impaired maturation of secondary sex characteristics due to insufficient estrogen production. While this genotypically female patient does have ambiguous external genitalia, she also has electrolyte abnormalities that suggest a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

5α-reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT is responsible for virilization of the genitalia. Patients with 5α-reductase deficiency are usually genotypically male (XY) and have female external genitalia at birth with intra-abdominal testicles. This genotypically female patient has virilized genitalia and thus does not have 5α-reductase deficiency.

17α-hydroxylase converts progesterone to 17-hydroxyprogesterone. 17α-hydroxylase deficiency causes insufficient androgen production. Female (XX) patients with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency are born with normal female genitalia but experience delayed puberty because of low androgen production. Mineralocorticoid precursor hormones also build up, resulting in sodium retention (hypertension) and potassium wasting (hypokalemia). This genotypically female patient has ambiguous genitalia and thus does not have 17α-hydroxylase deficiency.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of colicky abdominal pain for 1 day. She has had two similar episodes in the past. Urinalysis shows red blood cells and hexagonal-shaped crystals. Urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test is positive. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of colicky abdominal pain for 1 day. She has had two similar episodes in the past. Urinalysis shows red blood cells and hexagonal-shaped crystals. Urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test is positive. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Colicky abdominal pain in a child with a positive sodium cyanide nitroprusside test, hexagonal-shaped crystals, and hematuria indicates cystine stones due to cystinuria.
learning_objective: Recognize cystinuria, and recall its associated defect in amino acid transport.

answers.explanation_why: Increased stool fat content is a sign of decreased absorption of bile salts and can be caused by Crohn disease or short bowel syndrome. When there is increased stool fat content, calcium, which normally chelates free oxalate, binds free lipids instead. More free oxalate is absorbed, which promotes the formation of renal calcium oxalate stones. Oxalate stones are envelope-shaped and do not cause a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test, unlike what is seen in this case. In addition, this patient's young age and lack of fitting history rule out Crohn disease and short bowel syndrome.

answers.content: Inability of intercalated cells to secrete H^+
answers.explanation_why: The inability of intercalated cells to secrete H^+ can be seen in distal renal tubular acidosis. Patients with this condition are at increased risk for renal calcium phosphate stones due to an increased urine pH and increased bone turnover. Calcium phosphate stones are wedge-shaped prisms and do not explain a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test.

Homocystinuria is caused by enzyme deficiencies that increase blood and urine homocysteine levels. Although homocystinuria causes a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test, the condition is not associated with kidney stone formation.

Autosomal recessive cystinuria is a hereditary defect of proximal convoluted tubule and small intestine amino acid transport proteins. These defects prevent proper reabsorption of ornithine, cystine, lysine, and arginine in the small intestine and the kidneys. This leads to the precipitation of hexagonal-shaped cystine stones in urine and a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test.

answers.content: Urease-positive bacteria in the renal pelvis
answers.explanation_why: Urease-producing bacteria are a group of pathogens that can cause urinary tract infection and are responsible for forming ammonium magnesium phosphate stones, also called struvite stones. They account for about 15% of kidney stones and can even form staghorn calculi. Although this patient's abdominal pain could be a sign of a UTI, urease-producing bacteria show a negative urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test. Moreover, struvite stones are coffin lid shaped, rather than the hexagonal-shaped crystals seen here.

question_text: A 76-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One week ago, he was prescribed azithromycin for acute bacterial sinusitis. He has a history of atrial fibrillation treated with warfarin and metoprolol. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Compared to one month ago, laboratory studies show a mild increase in INR. Which of the following best explains this patient's laboratory finding?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One week ago, he was prescribed azithromycin for acute bacterial sinusitis. He has a history of atrial fibrillation treated with warfarin and metoprolol. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Compared to one month ago, laboratory studies show a mild increase in INR. Which of the following best explains this patient's laboratory finding?
hint: Warfarin is a competitive antagonist of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which reduces vitamin K. Reduced vitamin K is required for the activation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. Decreased activation of these clotting factors is responsible for the prolongation of INR that occurs with warfarin.
learning_objective: Recall the effect of broad-spectrum antibiotics on vitamin K levels and warfarin activity.

answers.explanation_why:
Gut bacteria produce about half of the vitamin K required by the body. Therapy with broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., macrolides) can deplete vitamin K stores in the body by destroying gut flora. Since vitamin K competes with warfarin for binding to the active site of vitamin K epoxide reductase, depletion of vitamin K would augment the effects of warfarin and further increase INR.

Newborns have low vitamin K levels due to a lack of gut colonization by vitamin K-producing bacteria and are therefore at increased risk for bleeding. Newborns receive an intramuscular vitamin K shot at birth to mitigate this risk.

Warfarin is metabolized by the cytochrome-P450 system. Induction of p450 enzymes can lead to lower warfarin levels, which would decrease (not increase) INR. Moreover, while certain macrolides (e.g., erythromycin, clarithromycin) inhibit cytochrome p450 enzymes, azithromycin uniquely does not affect p450 enzyme activity.

Warfarin is highly protein-bound in the serum. Other highly protein-bound drugs (e.g., aspirin and sulfa drugs) can compete with warfarin and further displace it from albumin binding sites; this leads to higher levels of unbound (effective) warfarin and a subsequent increase in INR. Azithromycin, however, is not a highly protein-bound drug.

Acute cholestatic hepatitis caused by macrolides (e.g., azithromycin) can increase INR as a result of hepatocyte injury (the liver produces almost all clotting factors) and/or vitamin K deficiency (cholestasis decreases absorption of fat-soluble vitamins such as vitamin K). However, patients with acute cholestatic hepatitis would typically have features such as jaundice, fatigue, pruritis, nausea, and/or vomiting.

Drugs that decrease intestinal motility (e.g., anticholinergics, opiates) can increase gastrointestinal absorption of other orally administered drugs (e.g., warfarin) by increasing the residence time of the drug in the gut. Macrolides (e.g., azithromycin) would decrease the residence time because they act as motilin agonists and increase intestinal motility.

question_text: A 3500-g (7-lb 11-oz) healthy female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) in the first trimester showed a trisomy of chromosome 21 but the pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Physical examination of the newborn is normal. Chromosomal analysis at birth shows a 46, XX karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the prenatal chromosomal abnormality?
content_preview: A 3500-g (7-lb 11-oz) healthy female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) in the first trimester showed a trisomy of chromosome 21 but the pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Physical examination of the newborn is normal. Chromosomal analysis at birth shows a 46, XX karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the prenatal chromosomal abnormality?
hint: This genetic phenomenon occurs in about 1–2% of all pregnancies in which chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is performed.
learning_objective: Recall the concept of confined placental mosaicism.

answers.explanation_why: Locus heterogeneity occurs when mutations in genes at different chromosomal loci cause the same phenotype. This means that two individuals with the same disease might have a different genotype; however, this would not cause a genetic discrepancy within an individual's tissue and does not explain the normal phenotype of the newborn.

Maternal uniparental disomy is a genetic anomaly in which the individual inherits two of the same chromosomes from one parent and none from the other. Uniparental disomy does not lead to polysomy and therefore would not explain the presence of trisomy 21 in the placental tissue.

Trisomy 21 is an example of phenotypic pleiotropy, in which one gene contributes to different phenotypic effects. Affected patients may display several developmental deformities, such as a palmar crease, upward slanting palpebral fissure, and cardiac defects. However, pleiotropy would not explain this patient's normal phenotype or the discrepancy between her placental and actual genotype.

Incomplete penetrance is the phenomenon by which not all individuals with a mutant genotype express the corresponding phenotype. However, trisomy 21 is typically not associated with incomplete penetrance. Furthermore, it would not explain the chromosomal discordance between the chorionic villus sample and the newborn tissue.

Maternal heteroplasmy refers to the presence of heterogeneous mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in an individual. Because all mitochondria are inherited from the mother, mitochondrial diseases that develop in utero are a result of unequal distribution of normal and mutated mtDNA molecules during mitosis. Thus, genetic discrepancies in a patient can be observed depending on which cells are sampled. However, trisomy 21 is a polysomy that affects the nuclear genome, not the mitochondrial genome.

images.title: Heteroplasmy
images.description: Following de novo mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), cells have both mutated and normal mitochondria, which is known as heteroplasmy. When there is heteroplasmy in the parental cell (P), levels of heteroplasmy can increase, decrease, or stay the same in subsequent filial generations (F1, F2), resulting in variable disease expression. Severity often correlates with the proportion of mutated mtDNA. In some conditions, the disease phenotype is only expressed once the proportion of mutated mtDNA is above a certain threshold.

answers.explanation_why: Variable expressivity is the mechanism by which mutations result in varying degrees of phenotypic severity. Patients with trisomy 21 often have varying degrees of clinical severity despite having the same genetic anomaly. However, variable expressivity does not explain the genetic discordance between the newborn and placental tissue.

In CVS, a sample from the placenta is taken to test for chromosomal abnormalities, rather than direct fetal tissue. In rare cases, there is a discrepancy between the sampled placental genotype and that of the fetus (mosaicism of the placenta). In confined placental mosaicism, the CVS may show an abnormal genotype but the fetus has a normal genotype, as seen here.

question_text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician because of a 6-month history of diarrhea. She has not received recommended well-child examinations. Her stools are foul-smelling and nonbloody. There is no family history of serious illness. She is at the 15^th percentile for height and 5^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows abdominal distension. Her serum triglyceride concentration is 5 mg/dL. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the gene that encodes microsomal triglyceride transfer protein. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician because of a 6-month history of diarrhea. She has not received recommended well-child examinations. Her stools are foul-smelling and nonbloody. There is no family history of serious illness. She is at the 15th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows abdominal distension. Her serum triglyceride concentration is 5 mg/dL. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the gene that encodes microsomal triglyceride transfer protein. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a rare, autosomal recessive condition caused by a mutation in the gene that encodes microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP). Manifestations of this condition include fat malabsorption (which causes steatorrhea and failure to thrive), hepatomegaly (which causes abdominal distension), and very low or absent serum lipid concentrations.
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, and choose the most appropriate dietary modification.

answers.explanation_why: Avoidance of dairy products is used to treat patients with lactose intolerance. This condition manifests with watery, bulky, and frothy stools (not foul-smelling stools) after the consumption of lactose-containing foods. Moreover, it is not associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which the avoidance of dairy products has no role in treatment.

Nicotinic acid supplementation, in combination with a high-protein diet, is used to treat patients with Hartnup disease. This autosomal recessive condition causes pellagra-like symptoms, which include diarrhea, altered mental status, and a photosensitive rash. It is not associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which nicotinic acid supplementation has no role in treatment.

Avoidance of dietary gluten is used to treat patients with celiac disease. This condition can cause steatorrhea and failure to thrive, but it is not associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which the avoidance of dietary gluten has no role in treatment.

Hereditary abetalipoproteinemia results in the absence of production of apolipoprotein B (apo B). Accordingly, no lipoproteins that contain apo B (e.g., chylomicrons, LDL, VLDL) are present in serum, which leads to fat malabsorption. Because dietary intake of fats exacerbates hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, treatment includes a low-fat diet with restriction of long-chain fatty acids. Patients also require supplementation with fat-soluble vitamins.

Late manifestations of hereditary abetalipoproteinemia include retinitis pigmentosa, coagulopathy, myopathy, and spinocerebellar degeneration (due to vitamin E deficiency).

Long-term antibiotic therapy is used to treat several conditions, including tropical sprue and Whipple disease. Though both of these conditions cause steatorrhea, they typically develop among adults and do not cause failure to thrive in infancy. Moreover, neither of these conditions is associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which long-term antibiotic therapy has no role in treatment.

Pancreatic enzyme replacement is used to treat patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., due to cystic fibrosis). Pancreatic insufficiency can cause steatorrhea and failure to thrive, but it is not associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which pancreatic enzyme replacement has no role in treatment.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressive weight loss. Physical examination shows jaundice and a nontender, palpable gallbladder. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an ill-defined mass in the pancreatic head. She is scheduled for surgery to resect the pancreatic head, distal stomach, duodenum, part of the proximal jejunum, gallbladder, and common bile duct and anastomose the jejunum to the remaining stomach, pancreas, and bile duct. Postsurgically, this patient is at greatest long-term risk for which of the following?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressive weight loss. Physical examination shows jaundice and a nontender, palpable gallbladder. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an ill-defined mass in the pancreatic head. She is scheduled for surgery to resect the pancreatic head, distal stomach, duodenum, part of the proximal jejunum, gallbladder, and common bile duct and anastomose the jejunum to the remaining stomach, pancreas, and bile duct. Postsurgically, this patient is at greatest long-term risk for which of the following?
hint: Resection of the duodenum during Whipple procedure increases the risk of developing a specific nutrient deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize the Whipple procedure, and recall its long-term complications.

answers.explanation_why: A hypercoagulable state may either result from inherited gene mutations or insufficient inhibitors of the coagulation cascade, neither of which this patient has. However, Whipple procedure involves resection of the proximal part of the jejunum, which is responsible for the absorption of vitamin K, and it may therefore lead to coagulopathy and increased bleeding risk due to a deficiency of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.

Surgical resection of the duodenum is associated with a risk of developing iron deficiency, as iron is solely absorbed in this part of the gastrointestinal tract. Iron deficiency, in turn, can lead to microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Treatment of iron deficiency anemia following duodenal resection consists of intravenous iron supplementation.

Calcium absorption is mediated through active transport and passive diffusion with the greatest amount being absorbed in the duodenum. When this patient's duodenum is removed, she will have diminished intestinal calcium uptake, which leads to increased reabsorption of calcium in the kidney to maintain normal serum levels. As a result, urinary calcium is low, which decreases the likelihood of calcium oxalate stone formation.

The finding of wide-based gait is commonly associated with long-standing vitamin B_12 deficiency, which leads to diminished proprioception in the lower extremities. Common causes of vitamin B_12 deficiency include pernicious anemia, malnutrition, or gastrectomy. Whipple procedure does not alter vitamin B_12 absorption as this vitamin is absorbed in the terminal ileum. Moreover, the function of intrinsic factor (IF), which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B_12, is also unaffected following this procedure since IF is produced in the gastric cardia and fundus rather than the distal stomach.

Bile acids play a pivotal role in the metabolism of lipids and fat-soluble vitamins as well as cholesterol excretion. Bile excretion into the duodenum is stimulated by food intake, which is followed by reabsorption of up to 95% of bile acids in the ileum, not the duodenum. This cycle is known as enterohepatic circulation. Thus, bile synthesis remains unaffected by pancreaticoduodenectomy.
