question_text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of progressive nausea, vomiting, and right-sided flank pain for 2 days. The pain is colicky and radiates to the groin. He has a history of gout and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications are metformin and allopurinol. He recently began taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement after he read on the internet that it may help to prevent gout attacks. Physical examination shows right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Oral examination shows dental erosions. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an 8-mm stone in the right proximal ureter. Microscopic examination of a urine sample shows bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals. An increased serum concentration of which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of progressive nausea, vomiting, and right-sided flank pain for 2 days. The pain is colicky and radiates to the groin. He has a history of gout and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications are metformin and allopurinol. He recently began taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement after he read on the internet that it may help to prevent gout attacks. Physical examination shows right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Oral examination shows dental erosions. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an 8-mm stone in the right proximal ureter. Microscopic examination of a urine sample shows bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals. An increased serum concentration of which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
hint: This patient's microscopic urinalysis shows bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals from a calcium oxalate kidney stone.
learning_objective: Recognize calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis, and recall the metabolic consequences of vitamin C toxicity.

answers.explanation_why: Acute vitamin A toxicity, which can occur due to excessive supplement intake, can manifest with nausea and vomiting. However, it also typically causes vertigo and blurry vision, which this patient does not have. In addition, vitamin A toxicity is not associated with dental erosions or nephrolithiasis.

Hyperphosphatemia predisposes to nephrolithiasis. However, unlike this patient's bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals, calcium phosphate stones appear on urine microscopy as wedge-shaped prisms. Also, this patient does not have a medical history (e.g., acute kidney injury, hyperparathyroidism), which is a risk factor for developing hyperphosphatemia. A history of taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement increases the risk of nephrolithiasis from the toxicity of a different substance.

images.title: Calcium phosphate crystals
images.description: Photomicrograph showing crystals with the appearance of wedge-shaped prisms (can also be described as blunt-ended needles), some bound together forming a rosette.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin B_3 toxicity can cause hyperuricemia, which predisposes to nephrolithiasis. However, uric acid stones appear on urine microscopy as rhomboid-shaped crystals, not bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals. Moreover, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of vitamin B_3 toxicity, such as facial flushing (due to prostaglandin release) and hyperglycemia. His history of taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement increases his risk of nephrolithiasis from the toxicity of another substance.

Vitamin E toxicity is rare and typically associated with excess supplementation. It can cause bleeding due to inhibition of platelet aggregation and platelet adhesion as well as an alteration in warfarin metabolism. In infants, vitamin E toxicity has been associated with an increased risk of necrotizing enterocolitis. It is not known to cause nausea, vomiting, dental erosions, or nephrolithiasis.

Vitamin C toxicity can result in calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis because vitamin C is metabolized to oxalate, and an increased serum oxalate concentration predisposes to stone formation. In particular, men with risk factors for nephrolithiasis, such as this patient with gout and type 2 diabetes mellitus, are at higher risk of stone formation secondary to excess vitamin C intake. Additional manifestations of vitamin C toxicity include dental erosions (due to the demineralizing activity of vitamin C), nausea, and vomiting, as seen in this patient. Diarrhea and fatigue may also be seen.

Vitamin C toxicity also increases dietary iron absorption and thus increases the risk of developing iron toxicity.

images.title: Calcium oxalate crystals in urine
images.description: Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

answers.explanation_why: Hyperuricemia, as seen in patients with gout, predisposes to nephrolithiasis. However, unlike this patient's bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals, uric acid stones appear on urine microscopy as rhomboid-shaped crystals. In addition, this patient takes allopurinol, a medication that reduces uric acid production. A history of taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement increases the risk of nephrolithiasis from the toxicity of a different substance.

images.title: Uric acid crystals
images.description: Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

question_text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of fatigue, facial rash, hair loss, and tingling of his hands and feet. He has followed a vegetarian diet for the past 3 years and has eaten 8 raw egg whites daily for the past year in preparation for a bodybuilding competition. Physical examination shows conjunctival injections and a scaly, erythematous rash around the eyes and mouth. Laboratory studies show decreased activity of propionyl-coenzyme A carboxylase in peripheral blood lymphocytes. Which of the following substances is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
content_preview: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of fatigue, facial rash, hair loss, and tingling of his hands and feet. He has followed a vegetarian diet for the past 3 years and has eaten 8 raw egg whites daily for the past year in preparation for a bodybuilding competition. Physical examination shows conjunctival injections and a scaly, erythematous rash around the eyes and mouth. Laboratory studies show decreased activity of propionyl-coenzyme A carboxylase in peripheral blood lymphocytes. Which of the following substances is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
hint: Alopecia, dermatitis, conjunctivitis, fatigue, and paresthesias in the setting of extreme consumption of raw egg whites are concerning for biotin (vitamin B_7) deficiency. Biotin is a cofactor for carboxylase enzymes, such as propionyl-coenzyme A carboxylase.
learning_objective: Recognize biotin deficiency, and recall its effects on carboxylase enzymes.

answers.explanation_why: The conversion of succinate to fumarate is a reaction of the citric acid cycle that is catalyzed by succinate dehydrogenase, an enzyme that uses flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) as a cofactor. FAD is derived from riboflavin (vitamin B_2) and serves as an electron carrier in redox reactions; it is not involved in carboxylation reactions.

The conversion of homocysteine and serine to cystathionine is catalyzed by cystathionine synthase, an enzyme that uses pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a cofactor. PLP is derived from pyridoxine (vitamin B_6) and serves as a cofactor for transamination, decarboxylation, and deamination reactions, not for carboxylase enzymes.

Conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to ribulose-5-phosphate is a reaction of the hexose monophosphate shunt catalyzed by transketolase, an enzyme that uses thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) as a cofactor. TPP is derived from thiamine (vitamin B_1) and serves as a cofactor for enzymes of carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism; it is not involved in carboxylation reactions.

Synthesis of adenine and other nitrogenous bases of DNA and RNA is dependent on tetrahydrofolic acid (THF), which generally serves as a cofactor in single-carbon transfers and methylation reactions. THF is not a cofactor of carboxylase enzymes.

The conversion of pyruvate to lactate is catalyzed by lactate dehydrogenase, an enzyme that uses nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) as a cofactor. NADH is derived from niacin (vitamin B_3) and serves as an electron carrier in redox reactions. Consequently, lactate would be decreased in niacin deficiency. Biotin deficiency, leads to an accumulation of pyruvate, resulting in an increase in lactate.

Biotin is needed as a cofactor for ATP-dependent carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, a reaction catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. Excessive ingestion of avidin, a protein found in raw egg whites, causes impaired biotin absorption and can lead to clinically relevant deficiency, as seen in this patient. Additional carboxylase enzymes that use biotin as a cofactor include acetyl-CoA carboxylase, propionyl CoA carboxylase, and methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception. For the past year, she has had intermittent episodes of headache, nausea, abdominal pain, and tingling of her fingers. She also reports dark urine during the episodes. Her mother and maternal uncle have similar symptoms and her father is healthy. Her husband is healthy and there is no history of serious illness in his family. Serum studies show elevated concentrations of porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid. Which of the following is the probability of this patient having a child with the same disease as her?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception. For the past year, she has had intermittent episodes of headache, nausea, abdominal pain, and tingling of her fingers. She also reports dark urine during the episodes. Her mother and maternal uncle have similar symptoms and her father is healthy. Her husband is healthy and there is no history of serious illness in his family. Serum studies show elevated concentrations of porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid. Which of the following is the probability of this patient having a child with the same disease as her?
hint: This patient has episodes of headaches, abdominal pain, nausea, paresthesias, and dark urine, in the setting of elevated porphobilinogen (PBG) and δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) concentrations. This indicates acute intermittent porphyria (AIP).
learning_objective: Recognize acute intermittent porphyria, and recall its inheritance pattern.

answers.explanation_why: In autosomal recessive conditions, a phenotypically unaffected child of heterozygous parents (Aa) has an approx. 67% chance of also being an asymptomatic carrier of the affected allele (Aa). In autosomal dominant conditions, such as AIP, every offspring with at least one mutated allele will be affected.

AIP is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in porphobilinogen deaminase. This patient must be heterozygous (Aa) for the disease because she is affected, but her father is healthy (aa). As her husband is phenotypically normal, he cannot be a carrier of a mutated copy of the gene. This woman has a 50% chance of passing on the affected allele, which would cause the disease. Therefore, the risk of having an affected child is ½ or 50%. 

See "AD inheritance pattern in heterozygous and homozygous parent” table.

images.title: Autosomal dominant inheritance
images.description: In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of a disease allele located on autosomes is needed to be passed to cause the expression of the phenotype in an offspring. In this inheritance pattern, there are affected individuals in each generation. Males and females are equally affected. At least one parent of the affected individual carries the disease allele and is affected. Affected males can inherit the phenotype from the affected mother, and affected females can inherit the phenotype from the affected father.

answers.explanation_why: In autosomal recessive conditions, the chance of having an affected child is 25% if both parents are heterozygous carriers of the affected allele (Aa). However, acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant condition. Therefore, inheritance of one affected allele would already cause the disease.

In autosomal dominant conditions, such as acute intermittent porphyria, the chance of having an affected child is 100% if at least one of the parents is homozygous for the affected allele (AA). This patient must be heterozygous (Aa) for the disease because she is affected, but her father is healthy (aa).

In autosomal recessive conditions, the chance of having a phenotypically affected child is 0% if one parent is homozygous for the normal allele. Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant condition. Therefore, inheritance of one affected allele would already cause the disease.

question_text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. She feels well. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 20.3 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her fasting serum glucose concentration is 132 mg/dL. Serum insulin concentration 30 minutes after oral glucose administration is 20 mIU/L (N = 30–230). Her hemoglobin A_1C concentration is 7.1%. After a thorough workup, the physician concludes that the patient has a chronic condition that can likely be managed with diet only and that she is not at a significantly increased risk of micro- or macrovascular complications. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
content_preview: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. She feels well. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 20.3 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her fasting serum glucose concentration is 132 mg/dL. Serum insulin concentration 30 minutes after oral glucose administration is 20 mIU/L (N = 30–230). Her hemoglobin A1C concentration is 7.1%. After a thorough workup, the physician concludes that the patient has a chronic condition that can likely be managed with diet only and that she is not at a significantly increased risk of micro- or macrovascular complications. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
hint: This young patient has evidence of chronically elevated serum glucose concentrations (HbA_1C of 7.1%) and inappropriate release of insulin in response to an oral glucose challenge. Based on her physician's assessment, she likely has a unique type of diabetes mellitus known as maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), which is sufficiently treated with diet modifications only.
learning_objective: Recognize maturity-onset diabetes of the young, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.content: Defect in expression of glucokinase gene
answers.explanation_why: A defect in the expression of the glucokinase gene is the underlying pathology in patients with MODY type II. The defect causes an increase in the glucose threshold required to promote insulin secretion. MODY type II is managed with dietary modifications only, as medical treatment fails to lower glucose and HbA1c. In contrast to other subtypes of MODY, patients with MODY type II are not at risk for micro- or macrovascular complications, despite mild fasting hyperglycemia and chronically elevated HbA1c.

Increased endogenous cortisol production is found in Cushing disease. Cortisol promotes gluconeogenesis, leading to hyperglycemia, and increases peripheral insulin resistance, thereby promoting the development of diabetes mellitus. However, this patient does not have any of the typical signs of hypercortisolism (e.g., central obesity, muscle weakness, striae). Furthermore, patients with Cushing disease who develop diabetes generally benefit from antidiabetic medications, while this patient likely would not.

Resistance to insulin-mediated glucose uptake occurs in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Affected individuals are typically overweight, which leads to elevated free fatty acids that interfere with insulin-mediated glucose uptake. Even though patients with type II diabetes mellitus can sometimes be managed with lifestyle modifications, most will eventually require medical therapy to prevent long-term complications, unlike in this case. Furthermore, this patient has a normal BMI.

Autoantibodies to pancreatic beta cells are the underlying cause of type I diabetes mellitus, which causes absolute insulin deficiency. Patients with type I diabetes require regular monitoring and are at high risk for micro- and macrovascular complications if not properly treated with exogenous insulin injections. This patient, though still of a plausible age for the onset of type I diabetes (i.e., childhood onset), can be treated with dietary modifications and is generally not at risk for vascular complications.

Mutations in hepatocyte nuclear factor 1 (HNF1) are responsible for the development of MODY type III. Defective HNF1 causes abnormal insulin secretion and lowers the threshold for glucose excretion in the kidneys, leading to glycosuria at a young age. Treatment is with sulfonylureas, which increase insulin release from the pancreas and are particularly effective in preventing long-term micro- and macrovascular complications in these patients.

question_text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician for evaluation of poor feeding and recurrent episodes of facial grimacing. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 3^rd percentile for length and 5^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows yellow discoloration of skin, a broad nasal bridge, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show increased concentrations of very long-chain fatty acids. Examination of the liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician for evaluation of poor feeding and recurrent episodes of facial grimacing. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 3rd percentile for length and 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows yellow discoloration of skin, a broad nasal bridge, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show increased concentrations of very long-chain fatty acids. Examination of the liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: A combination of hypotonia, abnormal facial grimacing suggestive of seizures, icterus, hepatomegaly, and elevated serum levels of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in a neonate indicates Zellweger syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Zellweger syndrome, and recall its cellular pathology.

answers.explanation_why: Centrilobular necrosis is seen in ischemic liver damage, alcohol-associated hepatitis, and various toxic liver damage cases (e.g., acetaminophen overdose). Although these conditions can cause liver failure and jaundice, they are not associated with neonatal seizures, hypotonia, or facial dysmorphism and would not explain the serum elevation of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Eosinophilic apoptotic bodies (Councilman bodies) can be seen in the liver in infectious diseases like viral hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C) or yellow fever. Although these diseases can cause liver failure and jaundice, they are not associated with neonatal seizures, hypotonia, or facial dysmorphism, and would not explain the accumulation of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Zellweger syndrome is characterized by a defect in peroxisome formation, which prevents catabolism of VLCFAs, leading to their accumulation in cells and impairing multiple organ systems. Zellweger syndrome has a poor prognosis, with death within the first year of life and no available treatment options.

Accumulation of PAS-positive granules in hepatocytes can be seen in glycogen storage diseases, as PAS will stain polysaccharides. Although glycogen storage diseases can cause neonatal seizures, hepatomegaly, and myopathy, they are not associated with facial dysmorphism and would not explain the high serum concentration of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Accumulation of cells with a foamy cytoplasm, i.e., lipid-laden macrophages, is seen in diseases like Niemann-Pick disease and Gaucher's disease (so-called Gaucher cells), or other causes of hepatic steatosis. Although these diseases can cause hepatomegaly and seizures, they are not generally associated with facial dysmorphism and would not explain the high serum concentrations of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

images.title: Foam cells
images.description: Microscopic image of the splenic red pulp (H&E stain)Macrophages with a lipid-laden cytoplasm (examples: green overlay). Those cells are often referred to as “foam cells” and are a typical finding in Niemann-Pick disease.

answers.explanation_why: Biliary atresia is seen in Alagille syndrome. Although Alagille syndrome can be associated with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and dysmorphic facial features, it would not cause hypotonia or the serum elevation of VLCFAs seen in this patient. Additionally, Alagille syndrome often presents with congenital heart defects (e.g., peripheral pulmonary stenosis) and ocular findings like posterior embryotoxon.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy with recurrent ear infections is brought to the pediatrician for a follow-up examination. He can walk with support and his vocabulary consists of approximately 50 words. His maternal uncle died in childhood from an unknown disease. Physical examination shows coarse facial features with an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and both the liver and spleen tip are palpable. Laboratory studies show elevated total urinary glycosaminoglycan levels and an absence of plasma iduronate-2-sulfatase. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy with recurrent ear infections is brought to the pediatrician for a follow-up examination. He can walk with support and his vocabulary consists of approximately 50 words. His maternal uncle died in childhood from an unknown disease. Physical examination shows coarse facial features with an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and both the liver and spleen tip are palpable. Laboratory studies show elevated total urinary glycosaminoglycan levels and an absence of plasma iduronate-2-sulfatase. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
hint: Iduronate-2-sulfatase is the deficient enzyme in Hunter syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type II). Patients with Hunter syndrome accumulate heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate.
learning_objective: Recognize Hunter syndrome, and recall its behavioral manifestations.

answers.explanation_why: Optic atrophy is seen with Krabbe disease (galactocerebrosidase deficiency), in which there is an accumulation of galactocerebroside and psychosine. Like Hunter syndrome, it can manifest with cognitive impairment and peripheral neuropathy but does not involve iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency.

images.title: Optic atrophy
images.description: Fundus photographs (a: left eye; b: right eye)Optic nerve pallor, a characteristic manifestation of optic atrophy, is visible.

answers.explanation_why: Pancytopenia can be seen in Gaucher disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glucocerebroside and is also associated with hepatosplenomegaly. However, this patient lacks other typical features such as aseptic necrosis of the femur, bone crises, and Gaucher cells. Furthermore, Gaucher disease is due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency, rather than the iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency observed in this patient. Patients with Gaucher disease can be managed with enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant glucocerebrosidase.

images.title: Gaucher cell
images.description: Photomicrograph of a bone marrow smear from a patient with bilateral femoral neck necrosis (PAS stain)A large cell (yellow overlay) with an eccentric nucleus (green overlay) can be seen. The cytoplasm shows a striated pattern.This is the typical appearance of a Gaucher cell, as seen in Gaucher disease.

answers.explanation_why: A cherry-red spot on the macula can be seen in both Niemann-Pick disease (sphingomyelinase deficiency) and Tay-Sachs disease (hexosaminidase A deficiency). Patients with Niemann-Pick disease accumulate sphingomyelin, while those with Tay-Sachs disease accumulate GM_2 ganglioside. While Niemann-Pick disease is associated with hepatosplenomegaly, which is seen in this patient, Tay-Sachs disease is not. Neither disorder is associated with the coarse facial features, enlarged tongue, or deficiency of iduronate-2-sulfatase seen in this patient.

images.title: Cherry-red spot of the retina
images.description: Fundus photography of a young childThe fovea (in the center of the photograph) appears bright red because the well-perfused choroid shines through the thin retinal layer consisting of only photoreceptors here. In contrast, the surrounding retina, which consists of several layers, appears lighter with lipid storage or retinal ischemia blocking the aspect of the choroid.A cherry-red spot of the retina can be seen in lipid storage diseases (in this case, Tay-Sachs disease) and in central artery occlusion of the retina.

answers.explanation_why: Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type I) is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency in α-L-iduronidase. Unlike Hunter syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type II), it is associated with more severe developmental delay, cognitive impairment, and corneal clouding. While it does manifest with coarse facial features, carpal tunnel syndrome, hepatosplenomegaly, and heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate accumulation, it is not associated with the iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency seen here.
answers.explanation_but: Hurler syndrome can be effectively managed with enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant α-L-iduronidase and symptomatic treatment (orthopedic care, corneal transplantation).

images.title: Corneal clouding
images.description: There is white-gray clouding of the cornea, making details of the iris appear blurred.Corneal clouding is seen in a variety of diseases (here: mucopolysaccharidosis VI).

answers.explanation_why: Hunter syndrome is an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency in iduronate-2-sulfatase and is associated with aggressive behavior, developmental delay, cognitive impairment, carpal tunnel syndrome, and hepatosplenomegaly. Unlike Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type I), it is not associated with corneal clouding.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of an itchy lesion on her skin. The rash developed shortly after she took an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.3°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling of the face and raised, erythematous plaques on her trunk and extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of an itchy lesion on her skin. The rash developed shortly after she took an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.3°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling of the face and raised, erythematous plaques on her trunk and extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
hint: The patient's acute-onset swelling and urticaria shortly after ingestion of an antibiotic are characteristic of a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
learning_objective: Recognize a type I hypersensitivity reaction, and recall its mediators.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of C1 inhibitor is the underlying pathology of bradykinin-mediated angioedema, which can be inherited or acquired. Lack of C1 inhibitor results in the unrestricted production of bradykinin, which mediates vasodilation and increased vascular permeability. Symptoms typically present as facial edema after a triggering event (e.g., ACE-inhibitor administration, infection), but do not include the urticaria or hypotension seen in this patient.

images.title: Angioedema
images.description: The severely swollen lower lip is most likely angioedema.

answers.explanation_why: Activation of the complement cascade via binding of antibodies to cell surface antigens plays a major role in type II hypersensitivity reactions. Complement-mediated cell lysis and activation of NK cells and macrophages via their Fc receptors cause this inflammatory reaction. Common type II HSRs include hemolytic transfusion reactions, but instant allergic reactions upon intake of a certain drug, as seen in this patient, are not mediated by the complement cascade.

The release of histamine, a vasoactive amine, plays an integral role in the type I hypersensitivity reaction seen in this patient. IgE antibodies from a previous encounter with a certain antigen are bound to mast cells and basophils. Re-exposure leads to degranulation of IgE-coated mast cells with release of histamine and various other mediators responsible for the characteristic features of type I HSR (i.e., erythema, pruritus, and urticaria). The patient's hypotension is due to hypovolemia caused by peripheral vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.

images.title: Urticaria
images.description: Well-circumscribed, pale papules (wheals) on an erythematous base (flare) can be seen on this patient's back.

answers.content: Secretion of cytokines by T cells
answers.explanation_why: Secretion of cytokines by T cells is essential for type IV hypersensitivity reactions, which result from delayed, cell-mediated cytotoxicity. Sensitization of CD4+ T cells to antigens (i.e., allergens) takes place via presentation by Langerhans cells in lymph nodes. Re-exposure to an antigen induces secretion of cytokines (e.g., IFN-γ) and subsequent activation of macrophages and T killer cells. However, this patient developed symptoms shortly after antigen exposure, which is inconsistent with a type IV HSR.

Immune complex deposition occurs with type III hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., serum sickness or vasculitis). Antibodies develop in response to a specific antigen, resulting in the formation of antigen-antibody immune complexes following second exposure. These immune complexes mainly deposit in vessel walls and trigger the complement cascade, initiating an inflammatory reaction. However, instant allergic reactions upon intake of a certain drug, as seen in this patient, are not mediated by the complement cascade.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation for chronic lower back pain. He has back stiffness that lasts all morning and slowly improves throughout the day. He has tried multiple over-the-counter medications, including ibuprofen, without any improvement in his symptoms. Physical examination shows tenderness over the iliac crest bilaterally and limited range of motion of the lumbar spine with forward flexion. The results of HLA-B27 testing are positive. An x-ray of the lumbar spine shows fusion of the lumbar vertebrae and sacroiliac joints. The physician plans to prescribe a new medication but first orders a tuberculin skin test to assess for the risk of latent tuberculosis reactivation. Inhibition of which of the following is the most likely primary mechanism of action of this drug?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation for chronic lower back pain. He has back stiffness that lasts all morning and slowly improves throughout the day. He has tried multiple over-the-counter medications, including ibuprofen, without any improvement in his symptoms. Physical examination shows tenderness over the iliac crest bilaterally and limited range of motion of the lumbar spine with forward flexion. The results of HLA-B27 testing are positive. An x-ray of the lumbar spine shows fusion of the lumbar vertebrae and sacroiliac joints. The physician plans to prescribe a new medication but first orders a tuberculin skin test to assess for the risk of latent tuberculosis reactivation. Inhibition of which of the following is the most likely primary mechanism of action of this drug?
hint: This young man presents with findings suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis (chronic lower back pain with morning stiffness, tenderness over sacroiliac joint indicating sacroiliitis, decreased spine mobility, and positive HLA-B27 test), which is confirmed by x-ray showing fusion of adjacent vertebrae (“bamboo spine”). The first choice medication (NSAID) did not prove effective here. Second-line drugs may cause reactivation of latent tuberculosis by disrupting granuloma stabilization.
learning_objective: Recognize ankylosing spondylitis, and recall the mechanism of action of TNF-α inhibitors.

answers.explanation_why: Inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH) controls the synthesis of purine nucleotides, which are needed for cellular proliferation. IMPDH inhibitors, such as mycophenolate mofetil and ribavirin, inhibit lymphocyte proliferation and are used as immunosuppressants (e.g., to prevent organ rejection after transplantation). They are not routinely used in the management of ankylosing spondylitis. An active systemic infection, including tuberculosis, is a contraindication to IMPDH inhibitor use. Tuberculin testing is used to detect latent tuberculosis and is not routinely indicated before initiating treatment with IMPDH inhibitors.

images.title: Mechanism of action: immunosuppressants
images.description: Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

answers.explanation_why: TNF-α is a cytokine that upregulates inflammation in numerous conditions, including ankylosing spondylitis (AS). TNF-α inhibitors can improve spine mobility and reduce pain in patients with AS. However, the pro-inflammatory action of TNF-α also plays a key role in granuloma formation and containment of tuberculosis. Inhibition of TNF-α could disrupt the granulomas, thereby releasing intracellular mycobacteria and reactivating latent tuberculosis. Thus, TNF-α inhibitors are contraindicated in individuals with latent tuberculosis, necessitating routine screening tests before initiation of treatment in all individuals.

Nuclear factor κB (NF-κB), which promotes pro-inflammatory cytokine COX-2 production, is inhibited by glucocorticoids. While temporary intra-articular glucocorticoids may be used in severe cases of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), this does not reactivate latent tuberculosis. In contrast, chronic use of systemic glucocorticoids can reactivate latent tuberculosis and would justify tuberculin skin testing. However, long-term high-dose steroids are not recommended in AS cases.

This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

answers.explanation_why: Calcineurin is a protein phosphatase enzyme involved in IL-2 dependent T-cell activation and proliferation. Calcineurin inhibitors, such as tacrolimus and cyclosporine, are potent immunosuppressants. While long-term use of calcineurin inhibitors may increase the risk of infection, they are not associated with reactivation of latent tuberculosis. In addition, these drugs are not used in the management of ankylosing spondylitis.

Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

answers.explanation_why: mTOR kinase promotes cellular proliferation and differentiation. Inhibitors of mTOR kinase (e.g., sirolimus and everolimus) inhibit lymphocyte proliferation and differentiation, resulting in decreased immunoglobulin synthesis, and are used as antineoplastic and immunosuppressant drugs. As these drugs can cause leukopenia, individuals treated with mTOR kinase inhibitors are at an increased risk of infection; however, reactivation of latent tuberculosis is not seen. In addition, mTOR kinase inhibitors are not routinely used in the management of ankylosing spondylitis.

images.title: Mechanism of action: immunosuppressants
images.description: Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of fever, cough, and ear pain over the past 2 days. He has had recurrent respiratory tract infections and several episodes of giardiasis and viral gastroenteritis since he was 6 months of age. Examination shows decreased breath sounds over both lung fields and bilateral purulent otorrhea. His palatine tonsils and adenoids are hypoplastic. Quantitative flow cytometry of his blood shows decreased levels of cells that express CD19, CD20, and CD21. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of fever, cough, and ear pain over the past 2 days. He has had recurrent respiratory tract infections and several episodes of giardiasis and viral gastroenteritis since he was 6 months of age. Examination shows decreased breath sounds over both lung fields and bilateral purulent otorrhea. His palatine tonsils and adenoids are hypoplastic. Quantitative flow cytometry of his blood shows decreased levels of cells that express CD19, CD20, and CD21. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Low levels of mature B cells (which express CD19, CD20, and CD21) in addition to recurrent episodes of respiratory and gastrointestinal tract infections when a child is older than 6 months (when the maternal IgG has decreased) are highly suggestive of X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia.
learning_objective: Recognize X-linked agammaglobulinemia, and recall its genetic cause.

answers.explanation_why: A mutation in the WAS gene causes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). WAS can cause recurrent infections, as seen in this patient, but it typically also causes eczema and thrombocytopenic purpura. The absence of these findings, along with this patient's hypoplastic lymphoid tissue and low levels of mature B cells, which are not typically seen in WAS, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

A defect in the IL-2R gamma chain is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Children with SCID appear normal at birth but progressively develop recurrent, severe infections (including bacterial, fungal, viral, and protozoal infections), and fail to thrive. SCID typically causes more severe infections than those seen in this patient, and it is usually lethal within the first year of life if not diagnosed and treated immediately. Diagnostic criteria for SCID include decreased T-cell receptor excision circles and absent T cells on peripheral blood flow cytometry, but a deficiency of mature B cells would not be expected.

A mutation in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA). BTK is a signal transduction molecule found on B cells. Without BTK, proper B-cell maturation cannot occur, which causes a severe reduction in plasma cells and immunoglobulins (panhypogammaglobulinemia). Although recurrent infections are a feature of many immunodeficiency disorders, tonsillar hypoplasia (due to low B-cell volume), as seen in this patient, is especially suggestive of XLA.

The diagnosis of XLA is confirmed by flow cytometry that shows reduced levels of B cells (marked by CD19, CD20, and CD21) and normal levels of T cells. Treatment for XLA consists of IVIG and prophylactic antibiotics.

images.title: Bruton agammaglobulinemia fact sheet
images.description: BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

answers.content: Microdeletion on the long arm of chromosome 22
answers.explanation_why: A microdeletion on the long arm of chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge syndrome, in which the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches fail to develop. Patients with DiGeorge syndrome may present with recurrent infections, which are also seen in this patient. However, in patients with DiGeorge syndrome, these infections are the result of a hypoplastic thymus and the subsequent T-cell deficiency, rather than due to low levels of mature B cells. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as hypocalcemia (due to hypoparathyroidism), cleft palate, facial abnormalities, and cardiac anomalies.

A mutation in the NADPH oxidase gene can lead to defective NADPH oxidase enzyme, which causes chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD can manifest with recurrent infections, as seen in this patient. In addition, patients with CGD often present with skin conditions (e.g., recurrent skin infections, eczematous rash) and symptoms typical of granuloma formation in the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts (e.g., dysphagia, abdominal pain, dysuria, urinary retention). However, these symptoms are not present in this patient. Finally, CGD would not explain the low levels of mature B cells.

A defect in the beta-2 integrin (CD18) causes leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD-1). Although LAD causes recurrent infections, these tend to be nonsuppurative skin and soft tissue infections caused by the inability of neutrophils to extravasate from the circulation to the infection. However, these types of infection are not seen in this patient. In addition, this patient does not present with other typical features of LAD, such as poor wound healing and a history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord. Finally, LAD would not explain the low levels of mature B cells.

A deficiency in the IL-17 receptor is associated with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (CMC). Unlike patients with CMC, this patient does not have a history of recurrent noninvasive Candida albicans infections of the skin, mucous membranes, and/or nails. In addition, CMC would not explain the low levels of mature B cells.

question_text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of fatigue. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.3 g/dL, a serum creatinine concentration of 0.9 mg/dL, and a serum alkaline phosphatase concentration of 130 U/L. Laboratory evaluation of which of the following parameters would be most helpful in determining the cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of fatigue. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.3 g/dL, a serum creatinine concentration of 0.9 mg/dL, and a serum alkaline phosphatase concentration of 130 U/L. Laboratory evaluation of which of the following parameters would be most helpful in determining the cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The patient has nonspecific symptoms and an elevation of serum alkaline phosphatase that may be associated with liver disease or bone pathology. To determine the underlying disease, a specific laboratory marker is needed.
learning_objective: Recognize the significance of elevated serum alkaline phosphatase, and choose the most appropriate laboratory parameter to differentiate its cause.

answers.explanation_why: Cancer antigen 27-29 (CA 27-29) may be elevated in breast cancer. Although high levels of CA 27-29 can indicate liver or bone metastases, which may also cause elevated ALP, CA 27-29 is a nonspecific parameter that can also be elevated in various other cancers and noncancerous conditions. Therefore, CA 27-29 cannot be used to determine the cause of this patient's symptoms.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme that catalyzes the reversible conversion of lactate to pyruvate and is elevated in any case of cell damage or disease with increased cell turnover. LDH would not help in determining the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms because it is a rather nonspecific marker that can be elevated in various conditions, including malignancies, hemolytic anemia, hepatocyte injury, and infarction.

Ferritin is responsible for iron storage and acts as an acute phase reactant. Ferritin would not help in determining the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms because it is a rather nonspecific marker that can be elevated in various conditions, including systemic inflammation, malignant disease, anemia of chronic disease, and sideroblastic anemia. A different investigation is more appropriate in this patient with normal hemoglobin and increased ALP.

In a patient with increased ALP, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) would be the most appropriate test to differentiate a disease of the hepatobiliary system from a disease of the bone. Simultaneous elevation in both ALP and GGT would signify a liver or biliary tract pathology. If ALP is elevated as a result of increased bone turnover, GGT levels would be normal. Increased GGT with normal ALP is characteristic of heavy alcohol use.

Calcitriol assays are indicated to diagnose vitamin D deficiency (osteomalacia/rickets), which can present with fatigue and increased ALP (due to secondary hyperparathyroidism). However, hepatic disorders are also associated with fatigue and increased ALP. Therefore, a different test is more appropriate to determine the tissue of origin of ALP before investigations pertinent to bone disorders are considered.

question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent abdominal pain, flatulence, and watery diarrhea. The episodes typically occur 2–3 hours after meals, particularly following ingestion of ice cream, cheese, and pizza. She is administered 50 g of lactose orally. Which of the following changes is most likely to be observed in this patient?
content_preview: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent abdominal pain, flatulence, and watery diarrhea. The episodes typically occur 2–3 hours after meals, particularly following ingestion of ice cream, cheese, and pizza. She is administered 50 g of lactose orally. Which of the following changes is most likely to be observed in this patient?
hint: Abdominal pain, flatulence, and diarrhea that occur after ingesting dairy products suggest lactose intolerance. Symptoms are caused by lactose malabsorption in the small bowel, which leads to increased intestinal filling and bacterial fermentation of undigested lactose in the colon.
learning_objective: Recognize lactose intolerance, and recall its effect on stool osmotic gap.

answers.explanation_why: An increased stool pH would not be expected in this patient, as those with lactose malabsorption present with acidic stool (pH < 6). Lactose reaches the large intestine due to insufficient hydrolysis by lactase. There, it serves as a fermentation substrate for colonic bacterial flora. Hydrogen and fatty acids are generated during fermentation, resulting in a decreased stool pH.

A decreased urinary D-xylose concentration would be expected in patients with malabsorptive disorders because xylose is absorbed in the proximal small intestine and excreted through the kidneys. Diminished absorption (e.g., in the setting of celiac disease, which can underlie lactose intolerance) would lead to decreased urinary D-xylose levels. However, this patient was given oral lactose, not xylose. A statement cannot yet be made regarding urinary D-xylose excretion.

In individuals with lactase deficiency, lactose is not sufficiently cleaved into the absorbable monosaccharides (galactose and glucose) that would raise serum glucose concentration in tolerant individuals. Instead, lactose is transferred to the colon without being absorbed. Therefore, serum glucose levels fail to rise after administration of lactose.

Calculation of the stool osmotic gap relies on the assumption that total stool osmolality stays constant and comes mainly from stool electrolyte concentrations. The remaining contribution to stool osmolality (i.e., the stool osmotic gap) depends on nonelectrolyte substances. In individuals with lactose malabsorption, unabsorbed lactose and its fermented metabolites contribute significantly to stool osmolality, meaning an increased stool osmotic gap.

An increased stool osmotic gap is not specific to lactose intolerance and occurs in all forms of osmotic diarrhea (e.g., laxative abuse).

Lactase deficiency does not affect fat absorption, though it can occur in the setting of other malabsorption disorders with elevated fecal fat content. Giving this patient an oral load of lactose will likely induce diarrhea, which may be accompanied by a slightly increased, not decreased, fecal fat content, as diarrhea generally impedes fat absorption.

Unabsorbed lactose undergoes fermentation by bacteria in the colon, a process that produces fatty acids and hydrogen. Hydrogen is then absorbed into the bloodstream, transported to the lungs, and exhaled. Therefore, increased, rather than decreased, breath hydrogen content would be expected in this patient. The hydrogen breath test is routinely used for patients with suspected lactose intolerance.

question_text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of worsening confusion, high-grade fever, and a productive cough. She has had recurrent respiratory infections and bulky, foul-smelling, oily stools since infancy. She is at the 14^th percentile for height and 8^th percentile for weight. Despite appropriate care, the patient dies 2 days after admission. Autopsy of the lungs shows bronchial mucus plugging and bronchiectasis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of worsening confusion, high-grade fever, and a productive cough. She has had recurrent respiratory infections and bulky, foul-smelling, oily stools since infancy. She is at the 14th percentile for height and 8th percentile for weight. Despite appropriate care, the patient dies 2 days after admission. Autopsy of the lungs shows bronchial mucus plugging and bronchiectasis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's symptoms of failure to thrive, recurrent respiratory infections, and chronic steatorrhea should raise concern for cystic fibrosis.
learning_objective: Recognize cystic fibrosis, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.content: Deletion of phenylalanine codon on chromosome 7
answers.explanation_why: Deletion of the codon for phenylalanine 508 in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 is the most common underlying cause of cystic fibrosis. This deletion leads to a misfolded CFTR protein that is unable to reach the cellular membrane. The CFTR protein is an important chloride channel in cell membranes, and when mutated cannot properly secrete intracellular chloride ions. This mutation causes exocrine glands to produce hyperviscous secretions that accumulate and damage different organs, mainly the lungs and pancreas.

images.title: Cystic fibrosis pathophysiology
images.description: A mutation in the CFTR gene results in defective protein synthesis and the absence of the ATP-gated chloride channel in the cell surface of epithelial cells throughout the body (intestinal and respiratory epithelia, sweat glands, exocrine pancreas, exocrine glands, and reproductive organs). Chloride and sodium are normally in equilibrium, but the accumulation of intracellular chloride due to the absence of a transporter results in the retention of intracellular sodium and water (due to osmosis). This ultimately results in hyperviscous mucus, which causes blockages of small organs and airways, inflammation, and end-organ damage.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency in adenosine deaminase leads to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Although patients with SCID can present with chronic diarrhea, recurrent infections, and failure to thrive as seen in this patient, chronic steatorrhea would not be expected.

answers.content: Mutation of DNAI1 gene on chromosome 9
answers.explanation_why: Mutation of the DNAI1 gene on chromosome 9 is the underlying cause of primary ciliary dyskinesia, which can also manifest with recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and mucus plugs, as seen in this patient. However, a diagnosis of primary ciliary dyskinesia would not explain this patient's chronic steatorrhea and growth failure.

answers.content: Deletion of UBE3A gene on chromosome 15
answers.explanation_why: Deletion of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15 is associated with Angelman syndrome. Unlike this patient's presentation, Angelman syndrome typically manifests with intellectual disability, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent laughing (inappropriate laughter).

Deficiency in apolipoprotein B-48 leads to abetalipoproteinemia. While affected individuals can present with severe steatorrhea and failure to thrive as seen in this patient, recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and mucus plugs would not be expected.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) results from a mutation that impairs the secretion of alpha-1 antitrypsin by hepatocytes. The lack of secretion leads to unchecked protease activity in the lungs and, consequently, the destruction of the pulmonary architecture, which can present with recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and failure to thrive as seen in this patient. However, AATD classically causes panacinar emphysema, which this patient does not have. Moreover, this patient lacks features of hepatitis and liver cirrhosis (secondary to intracellular accumulation of alpha-1 antitrypsin), such as abdominal distension from hepatosplenomegaly or ascites.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
hint: This patient presents with features of Marfan syndrome (i.e., tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, joint hypermobility, and superotemporal lens subluxation).
learning_objective: Recognize Marfan syndrome, and recall the associated defective structural protein.

answers.explanation_why: Defective laminin can cause junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in laminin.

Defective type III collagen is the cause of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents primarily with cardiovascular manifestations. These include heart valve defects (especially mitral valve prolapse), aneurysms or dissections of large arteries (e.g., aortic, iliac), and berry aneurysms of cerebral arteries. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type III collagen.

Marfan syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, which encodes fibrillin, an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that forms a supportive sheath around elastin. Abnormal elastin production leads to defective connective tissue and excessive growth factor release. Further features of Marfan syndrome include vascular abnormalities (e.g., aortic aneurysm or dissection).

Defective type I collagen is the cause of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). Patients with OI can present with joint hypermobility, as seen in this patient, but do not develop lens subluxation, high-arched palate, tall stature, or arachnodactyly. Moreover, patients with OI typically have a history of multiple fractures in the setting of minimal trauma along with blue sclerae and hearing loss. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type I collagen.
Defective keratin can cause epidermolysis bullosa simplex, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in keratin.

question_text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of walking difficulties. His mother says that he cannot walk unless he is supported. She has also noted orange, sandy residues in his diapers. Over the past year, she has frequently caught him pulling his toenails and chewing the tips of his fingers. Examination shows scarring of his fingertips. Muscle tone is decreased in the upper and lower extremities. He cannot pick up and hold small objects between the tips of the index finger and the thumb. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition inhibits which of the following conversions?
content_preview: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of walking difficulties. His mother says that he cannot walk unless he is supported. She has also noted orange, sandy residues in his diapers. Over the past year, she has frequently caught him pulling his toenails and chewing the tips of his fingers. Examination shows scarring of his fingertips. Muscle tone is decreased in the upper and lower extremities. He cannot pick up and hold small objects between the tips of the index finger and the thumb. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition inhibits which of the following conversions?
hint: This patient's delayed motor skills, self-mutilating behavior, and evidence of hyperuricemia (orange, sand-like sodium urate crystals in his diaper) are consistent with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, and recall the target of its pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: The conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate (IMP) is a step in the purine salvage pathway that can be competitively inhibited by 6-mercaptopurine, a purine analog used as an immunosuppressant drug. However, in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, the conversion of hypoxanthine to IMP is already impaired due to the deficiency of the catalyzing enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase. Further pharmacological inhibition of this reaction would counterproductively worsen the disease.

images.title: Salvage pathway
images.description: The salvage pathway is the pathway along which purine nucleotides are recycled (adenine, guanine, and hypoxanthine) and reconverted to nucleotides through phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP)-dependent reactions. The enzymes involved in the purine salvage pathway are adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) and hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). Both enzymes are inhibited by their end products.

answers.explanation_why: The conversion of ornithine to citrulline is catalyzed by ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC). OTC deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder and may cause developmental delay and orange, sandy residues in the diapers (due to orotic acid crystals in the urine). However, OTC deficiency does not cause self-mutilating behavior; instead, it is associated with nausea, vomiting, irritability, poor feeding, and in severe cases metabolic encephalopathy, none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, there are currently no clinically-approved OTC inhibitors and further inhibition of the enzyme would worsen the disease.

images.title: Urea cycle
images.description: The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

answers.explanation_why: The conversion of orotate to uridine monophosphate (UMP) is catalyzed by UMP synthase. A defect in this enzyme leads to accumulation of orotic acid in the serum and urine and a defective de novo synthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides. Orotic aciduria may present with developmental delay and orange, sandy residues in the diapers (due to orotic acid crystals in the urine). However, this condition does not manifest with self-mutilating behavior; instead, it is associated with failure to thrive, which is not present in this patient. Furthermore, there are currently no clinically-approved UMP synthase inhibitors and inhibition of the defective enzyme would worsen the disease.

The conversion of urate to allantoin is catalyzed (not inhibited) by rasburicase, a drug most commonly used in the prevention and treatment of hyperuricemia in the setting of tumor lysis syndrome. Although rasburicase could theoretically be used to treat hyperuricemia secondary to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, the paucity of clinical data supporting its efficacy makes it a less appropriate option. In addition, a drug that inhibits the conversion of urate to allantoin would decrease uric acid excretion and worsen this patient's hyperuricemia.

The conversion of adenosine (and deoxyadenosine) to inosine is catalyzed by adenosine deaminase. Accumulation of deoxyadenosine due to adenosine deaminase deficiency results in lymphocyte toxicity and severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). SCID is not associated with delayed motor skills, self-mutilating behavior, or hyperuricemia. Rather, features of SCID include severe recurrent infections, failure to thrive, and fatality in the first year of life if left untreated, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, there are currently no clinically-approved adenosine deaminase inhibitors and inhibition of the already deficient enzyme would worsen the disease.

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors such as allopurinol (first-line choice) or febuxostat (second-line) inhibit the conversion of both hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to urate and are used to treat hyperuricemia in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a congenital deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), a purine salvage enzyme that converts hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanine monophosphate. HGPRT deficiency results in the accumulation of hypoxanthine and guanine, both of which are converted to xanthine and subsequently uric acid.

images.title: Mechanism of action: gout drugs
images.description: Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.

question_text: A 55-year-old man with a history of repeated hospitalization for chronic pancreatitis comes to the physician because of difficulty walking and standing steadily. Neurological examination shows an unsteady, broad-based gait, distal muscle weakness, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and an abnormal Romberg test. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.9 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 89/μm^3, and serum lactate dehydrogenase is 215 U/L. His serum haptoglobin is slightly decreased. A deficiency of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man with a history of repeated hospitalization for chronic pancreatitis comes to the physician because of difficulty walking and standing steadily. Neurological examination shows an unsteady, broad-based gait, distal muscle weakness, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and an abnormal Romberg test. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.9 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 89/μm3, and serum lactate dehydrogenase is 215 U/L. His serum haptoglobin is slightly decreased. A deficiency of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
hint: In infants, excess of this vitamin has been associated with necrotizing enterocolitis.
learning_objective: Recognize vitamin E deficiency, and recall its neurological manifestations.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of tocopherol (vitamin E deficiency) classically manifests with hemolytic anemia and symptoms of posterior column and spinocerebellar tract dysfunction (ataxia, loss of proprioception, and diminished reflexes). It is an uncommon condition in developed countries, but specific populations, such as patients with fat malabsorption disorders (e.g., chronic pancreatitis, abetalipoproteinemia, cystic fibrosis) are at significant risk. Vitamin E deficiency is harmful to neurons and red blood cells specifically as they are particularly sensitive to the oxidative damage that results from the loss of vitamin E antioxidative effects.

Riboflavin (vitamin B_2) deficiency can occur due to malnutrition (e.g., from a restricted diet), and it may present with normocytic normochromic anemia, as seen in this patient. However, it is not associated with neurological dysfunction but presents with instead with dry, scaling skin of the lips and mouth (cheilosis). Affected individuals may also have vision loss due to corneal vascularization.

Pyridoxine deficiency (vitamin B_6 deficiency) can occur with prolonged isoniazid administration and chronic alcohol use. It may present with neurological compromise, most often in the form of peripheral neuropathy, which could explain this patient's neurological findings. However, anemia associated with pyridoxine deficiency, if present, manifests as (microcytic) sideroblastic anemia, not (normocytic) hemolytic anemia.

Cobalamin (vitamin B_12) deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration, which may manifest with neurological signs and symptoms similar to the ones seen in this patient, including ataxia and muscle weakness. However, cobalamin deficiency typically also manifests with symmetrical paresthesias of the extremities and dementia. In addition, it causes megaloblastic anemia. Finally, common risk factors for this vitamin deficiency include restricted diets, lack of intrinsic factor, or terminal ileum disease (e.g., Crohn disease), none of which are present in this patient.

Niacin deficiency (vitamin B_3 deficiency) can be seen in severe malnutrition, carcinoid syndrome, or Hartnup disease. Moderate deficiency may cause glossitis whereas severe cases may lead to pellagra. However, neurological symptoms and hemolytic anemia would not be present.

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for sudden-onset slurring of speech and weakness of her right arm and leg. She has a mild intellectual disability. She is at the 10th percentile for weight and at the 85th percentile for height. Physical examination shows bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens and a high-arched palate. Her fingers are long and slender. Neurological examination shows an extensor plantar response on the right. This patient is most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for sudden-onset slurring of speech and weakness of her right arm and leg. She has a mild intellectual disability. She is at the 10th percentile for weight and at the 85th percentile for height. Physical examination shows bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens and a high-arched palate. Her fingers are long and slender. Neurological examination shows an extensor plantar response on the right. This patient is most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with signs of an acute stroke (hemiplegia, slurred speech, positive Babinski sign), Marfanoid habitus (tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly), inferonasal lens subluxation, and intellectual disability, indicating homocystinuria most likely caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize homocystinuria, and choose the appropriate vitamin supplementation.

answers.explanation_why: Supplementation of methionine is the treatment of choice for homocystinuria caused by defective methionine synthase. However, it is a rare cause of homocystinuria, and symptoms typically present earlier and more acutely. In all other forms of homocystinuria, methionine intake should be restricted in order to prevent further accumulation of homocysteine.

Together with tyrosine supplementation, dietary restriction of phenylalanine is the treatment of choice for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU). Although PKU does present with intellectual disabilities, which are seen in this patient, it is not associated with marfanoid habitus, lens luxation, or vascular events. Moreover, patients with PKU typically have a history of seizures and skin disorders such as eczema and may have a characteristic musty body odor.

Alkalinization of the urine to a pH > 7 through the administration of potassium citrate or potassium bicarbonate dissolves cystine stones formed in cystinuria. However, homocystinuria does not lead to the formation of cystine stones, and patients would not benefit from such a treatment.

Vitamin B6 is a cofactor of cystathionine synthase, which catalyzes the first step of conversion of homocysteine and serine into cystathionine. Homocystinuria caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity of the enzyme for vitamin B6 can be treated with B6 supplementation. However, only about 50% of patients are pyridoxine-responsive. Because cystathionine synthase deficiency results in the accumulation of thrombogenic homocysteine, it predisposes to thromboembolic events (e.g., acute stroke). Lowering the plasma homocysteine concentration is therefore the single most important factor for reducing the risk of vascular events.
Homocystinuria is most commonly caused by defective conversion of homocysteine to cysteine. Subsequently, cysteine levels are usually decreased and supplementation is indicated, not restriction.
