question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 30 minutes after having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He was born at home and has not attended any well-child visits. He is not yet able to walk and does not use recognizable words. His paternal uncle has a severe intellectual disability and has been living in an assisted-living facility all of his life. The boy's urine phenylacetate level is markedly elevated. Which of the following amino acids is most likely nutritionally essential for this patient because of his underlying condition?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 30 minutes after having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He was born at home and has not attended any well-child visits. He is not yet able to walk and does not use recognizable words. His paternal uncle has a severe intellectual disability and has been living in an assisted-living facility all of his life. The boy's urine phenylacetate level is markedly elevated. Which of the following amino acids is most likely nutritionally essential for this patient because of his underlying condition?
hint: This patient's seizure, speech and motor delays, and elevated urine phenylacetate are indicative of phenylketonuria (PKU). His family history of severe intellectual disability, the hallmark of untreated PKU, is consistent with the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern of this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize phenylketonuria (PKU), and recall the amino acid that becomes essential due to the condition.

answers.explanation_why: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid in humans. However, management of phenylketonuria, a condition characterized by excess levels of phenylalanine and its metabolites, involves dietary restriction of this protein. Supplementation of phenylalanine would worsen this patient's clinical condition.

Glutamate is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from α-ketoglutarate via the action of glutamate dehydrogenase and from glutamine via glutaminase. Glutamate synthesis is not affected in patients with PKU.
Alanine is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from pyruvate via the action of alanine aminotransferase. Synthesis of this amino acid is not affected in patients with PKU.

Tyrosine is nutritionally essential to patients with PKU and must be supplemented. Phenylalanine hydroxylase normally converts phenylalanine into tyrosine, but this enzyme is lacking in classic phenylketonuria. The seizure seen in this patient was caused by insufficient tyrosine, which is necessary for neurotransmitter and thyroxine production. Tyrosine is also required for melanin production, explaining the light skin characteristic of PKU. Other symptoms include a musty body odor, failure to thrive, loss of motor control, and mental disabilities.

images.title: Classic phenylketonuria vs. tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency (malignant PKU)

answers.explanation_why: Arginine is a conditionally essential amino acid that can be synthesized from citrulline via the action of argininosuccinate synthetase and argininosuccinate lyase (in the urea cycle). Arginine can become essential during times of increased demand (e.g., growth phases during childhood). However, synthesis pathways of this amino acid are not affected in patients with PKU.

Cysteine is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from homocysteine and serine via the action of cystathionine synthase. Synthesis pathways of this amino acid are not affected in patients with PKU.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician after his adoptive mother observed jerking movements of his arms and legs earlier that morning. He was adopted from an orphanage in Albania at 4 months of age. He has a history of intellectual disability. Examination shows pale skin and light blue eyes. There is a dry, eczematous, scaly rash on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. This patient is most likely deficient in which of the following enzymes?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician after his adoptive mother observed jerking movements of his arms and legs earlier that morning. He was adopted from an orphanage in Albania at 4 months of age. He has a history of intellectual disability. Examination shows pale skin and light blue eyes. There is a dry, eczematous, scaly rash on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. This patient is most likely deficient in which of the following enzymes?
hint: This boy has an autosomal recessive condition that, in addition to the symptoms above, also causes a characteristic mousy or musty odor of the body and urine.
learning_objective: Recognize phenylketonuria, and recall the deficient enzyme.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase results in failure to convert phenylalanine to tyrosine and is the underlying cause of phenylketonuria (PKU). Symptoms usually develop after the neonatal period and include developmental delay and seizures (due to phenylalanine accumulation in the CNS), hypopigmentation (due to a lack of melanin production from low levels of tyrosine), and eczema, all of which are present in this case. In addition, PKU manifests with a characteristic mousy or musty odor due to excretion of phenylalanine metabolites in the urine and sweat. PKU is typically detected by newborn screening for metabolic disorders.

Branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency results in the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (i.e., valine, leucine, isoleucine) and causes maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). This condition manifests in the early neonatal period with vomiting, lethargy, dystonia, hypoglycemia (which can lead to seizures), and a characteristic maple syrup odor to the urine which eventually lead to severe central nervous system defects and intellectual disability.

Cystathionine synthase deficiency leads to homocystinuria, which can cause intellectual disability and seizures. However, this condition also causes ectopia lentis, marfanoid habitus, and increased risk of thrombosis.

Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency can cause intellectual disability and seizures. However, this condition typically manifests shortly after birth, not in early childhood. In addition, OTC deficiency causes symptoms of hyperammonemia (e.g., asterixis, slurred speech, nausea, vomiting, irritability).

Tyrosinase deficiency leads to oculocutaneous albinism due to defective melanin production and causes pale skin and light-colored eyes. However, this condition also typically manifests with visual abnormalities.

Homogentisate oxidase deficiency causes alkaptonuria. This condition results in the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which leads to ochronosis, valvular calcification, and nephrolithiasis. The urine of patients with alkaptonuria turns dark brown/black when left standing or alkalinized. Unlike this patient, affected individuals are typically asymptomatic in childhood.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He feels well. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and a standard electrolyte panel, are within normal limits. Urine dipstick is negative for glucose; a reducing substance test result of the urine is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate dietary recommendation for this patient?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He feels well. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and a standard electrolyte panel, are within normal limits. Urine dipstick is negative for glucose; a reducing substance test result of the urine is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate dietary recommendation for this patient?
hint: The patient has a reducing sugar in his urine which is not glucose. As he is asymptomatic and has an otherwise completely normal exam the sugar is most likely fructose, leading to the diagnosis of essential fructosuria.
learning_objective: Recognize essential fructosuria from urine test results, and choose the appropriate dietary recommendation for the patient.

answers.explanation_why: Eliminating fructose and sucrose from the diet would be recommended in hereditary fructose intolerance, which is characterized by fructose-1-phosphate accumulation, phosphate depletion, and inhibition of glycolytic pathways. Although a reducing sugar (fructose) could be detected in the urine (as is the case in this patient), hereditary fructose intolerance would present in early childhood with severe hypoglycemia, vomiting, jaundice, bleeding, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive.

Decreasing purine intake would be recommended in conditions associated with hyperuricemia (e.g., primary gout, renal failure, Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, tumor lysis syndrome, von Gierke disease). This patient, however, is an asymptomatic adult.

No treatment is required for patients with essential fructosuria, a benign disorder of fructose metabolism caused by the deficiency of fructokinase, which converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Although fructokinase deficiency can lead to detectable fructose in the blood and urine, the condition has no clinical consequences, as hexokinase shunts excess fructose back into the glycolytic pathway by converting fructose directly to fructose-6-phosphate.

images.title: Mechanisms of fructose intolerance
images.description: (1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Eliminating galactose and lactose from the diet would be recommended in galactosemia, which is characterized by the accumulation of galactose and galactitol. Although galactosemia can present with a reducing sugar (galactose) in the urine, as seen in this patient, it presents as soon as an infant starts feeding with infantile cataracts, jaundice, vomiting, hepatosplenomegaly, and failure to thrive.

answers.content: Increase intake of ketogenic amino acids
answers.explanation_why: Increasing intake of ketogenic amino acids may delay the progression of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, which is caused by a dysfunction of the citric acid cycle leading to lactate build-up. It manifests early in life with nonspecific symptoms like lethargy, poor feeding, tachypnea, neurodevelopmental delays, and lactic acidosis. This patient is, however, asymptomatic and does not have a history of consistent symptoms.

question_text: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician because of somnolence, poor feeding, and vomiting after his first few breast feedings. He appears lethargic. His respiratory rate is 73/min. Serum ammonia is markedly increased. Genetic analysis shows deficiency in N-acetylglutamate synthase. The activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely directly affected by this genetic defect?
content_preview: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician because of somnolence, poor feeding, and vomiting after his first few breast feedings. He appears lethargic. His respiratory rate is 73/min. Serum ammonia is markedly increased. Genetic analysis shows deficiency in N-acetylglutamate synthase. The activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely directly affected by this genetic defect?
hint: N-acetylglutamate synthase produces N-acetylglutamate, which serves as an allosteric activator for one of the two enzymatic reactions of the urea cycle that take place in the mitochondria.
learning_objective: Recall the function of N-acetylglutamate, and recall its role in the urea cycle.

answers.explanation_why:
N-acetylglutamate increases the activity of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1), a mitochondrial enzyme that converts bicarbonate and ammonia to carbamoyl phosphate using 2 molecules of ATP. This process is the rate-limiting step of the urea cycle. N-acetylglutamate is synthesized primarily in the liver and small intestinal cells when the cellular concentration of arginine is increased. In this way, the activity of CPS1 is increased following a protein-rich meal, when ammonia production is expected to be increased.

The two most common hereditary defects in the urea cycle are ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency) and CPS1 deficiency. Neonates with either of these defects are usually normal at birth but present with vomiting, lethargy, hyperventilation, and cerebral edema (due to intracellular accumulation of glutamine) after the first 24–72 hours as a result of introduction of dietary protein. In addition to increased ammonia levels in blood, they have increased glutamine and decreased blood urea nitrogen. OTC deficiency can be differentiated from CPS1 deficiency by the presence of orotic acid in urine.

images.title: Urea cycle
images.description: The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

answers.explanation_why: Ornithine translocase is a mitochondrial protein that is critical for urea cycle activity because it transports ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria, where it is converted to citrulline by ornithine transcarbamylase. A defect in ornithine translocase would cause hyperammonemia, but this protein's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

Ornithine transcarbamylase is a mitochondrial enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it transfers a carbamoyl group onto ornithine to form citrulline. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

Argininosuccinate synthetase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it synthesizes argininosuccinate from aspartate and citrulline. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

Argininosuccinase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it converts arginosuccinate to arginine and fumarate. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

Arginase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it converts arginine to urea and ornithine. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

question_text: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting, irritability, and poor feeding. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Physical examination shows increased muscle tone in all extremities. He appears lethargic. His diapers emit a caramel-like odor. Urine studies are positive for ketone bodies. Supplementation of which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting, irritability, and poor feeding. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Physical examination shows increased muscle tone in all extremities. He appears lethargic. His diapers emit a caramel-like odor. Urine studies are positive for ketone bodies. Supplementation of which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's condition?
hint: This boy has maple syrup urine disease, which typically manifests in the early neonatal period with vomiting, irritability, poor feeding, dystonia, lethargy, urine that has a sweet-smelling odor, and ketonuria.
learning_objective: Recognize maple syrup urine disease, and recall the treatment for thiamine-responsive MSUD.

answers.explanation_why: Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is caused by decreased activity of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH). Supplementation of thiamine (vitamin B_1), which is a cofactor for several dehydrogenases, can increase the activity of BCKDH in some patients with MSUD (thiamine-responsive MSUD). In addition to thiamine supplementation, patients should avoid intake of branched-chain amino acids (i.e., isoleucine, leucine, and valine).

Cysteine supplementation is indicated for patients with homocystinuria due to cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity of cystathionine synthase for pyridoxal phosphate. Patients with homocystinuria are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period but can develop osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease, and/or intellectual disability as they grow older. Urinalysis of patients with homocystinuria shows increased homocysteine levels, not ketone bodies. Cysteine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

Increased intake of ketogenic amino acids (e.g., leucine, lysine) is indicated for patients with pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency (PDCD), which can manifest in the neonatal period with vomiting, irritability, dystonia, and lethargy. However, this condition does not cause a caramel-like odor to the urine or ketonuria. In addition, PDCD results in decreased acetyl-CoA production and thus decreased ketone body synthesis. This patient with maple syrup urine disease should avoid intake of leucine, which is a branched-chain amino acid.

Methionine supplementation is indicated for patients with homocystinuria due to methionine synthase deficiency. Patients with homocystinuria are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period but can develop osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease, and/or intellectual disability as they grow older. Urinalysis of patients with homocystinuria shows increased homocysteine levels, not ketone bodies. Methionine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

Tyrosine supplementation is indicated for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU), which can manifest with poor feeding, lethargy, spasticity due to CNS damage, and ketonuria. However, patients with PKU are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period. In addition, the urine of patients with PKU typically has a musty odor, not a caramel-like odor. Tyrosine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

images.title: Classic phenylketonuria vs. tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency (malignant PKU)

answers.explanation_why: Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH_4) supplementation is indicated for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU), which can manifest with poor feeding, lethargy, spasticity due to CNS damage, and ketonuria. However, patients with PKU are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period. In addition, the urine of patients with PKU typically has a musty odor, not a caramel-like odor. BH_4 supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman with beta-thalassemia major is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue, darkening of her skin, and pain in her ankle joints. She has also had increased thirst and frequent urination for 2 weeks. She receives approximately 5 blood transfusions every year; her last transfusion was 3 months ago. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented skin, scleral icterus, pale mucous membranes, and a liver span of 17 cm. Which of the following serum findings is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman with beta-thalassemia major is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue, darkening of her skin, and pain in her ankle joints. She has also had increased thirst and frequent urination for 2 weeks. She receives approximately 5 blood transfusions every year; her last transfusion was 3 months ago. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented skin, scleral icterus, pale mucous membranes, and a liver span of 17 cm. Which of the following serum findings is most likely in this patient?
hint: This patient's fatigue, joint pain, hyperpigmented skin, signs of diabetes mellitus (e.g., polydipsia, polyuria), hepatomegaly, and history of beta-thalassemia major with frequent blood transfusions are highly suggestive of secondary hemochromatosis.
learning_objective: Recognize secondary hemochromatosis in beta-thalassemia major, and recall the associated serum finding.

answers.explanation_why: Hepcidin is an iron-regulatory protein that impairs iron absorption in the intestinal mucosa and decreases iron release from macrophages. As an acute-phase reactant, it mediates anemia of chronic disease in patients with chronic inflammation. Deficiency of hepcidin is thought to cause hemochromatosis, resulting in primary iron overload. Hepcidin levels have also been shown to be suppressed or not detectable in patients with thalassemia, showing that secondary iron overload in this condition is not only due to frequent blood transfusions but also results from increased iron absorption in the intestine.

Patients with beta-thalassemia major who undergo frequent blood transfusions are prone to developing secondary iron overload due to the high iron content of red blood cells. Plasma ferritin is a marker of total body iron stores and would thus be elevated in this patient. Other expected findings are decreased transferrin/TIBC levels and elevated transferrin saturation.

Transferrin saturation, which indicates how much of the circulating transferrin is bound to iron, directly increases with serum iron levels. This patient who receives frequent blood transfusions likely developed secondary iron overload, which results in increased transferrin saturation.

Transferrin is an iron transport protein, whose levels vary inversely with total body iron stores. This patient who receives frequent blood transfusions likely developed secondary iron overload, which results in decreased transferrin levels.

Haptoglobin is an acute-phase reactant that binds to free hemoglobin released into the circulation and would thus be decreased in intravascular hemolysis. Since thalassemia predominantly causes extravascular hemolysis (occurs in the reticuloendothelial system), haptoglobin levels would not be significantly affected.

The total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) reflects the blood's capacity to bind iron with transferrin and hence is an indirect measurement of transferrin. This patient who receives frequent blood transfusions likely developed secondary iron overload. As a result, most of her transferrin is already bound to iron and her capacity to bind further iron is decreased.

question_text: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
content_preview: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
hint: This vitamin is used in gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.
learning_objective: Recognize the risk of hemorrhagic disease in newborns, and choose the appropriate supplement to prevent it.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin B1 (thiamine), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk. Infants born to thiamine-deficient mothers can develop infantile beriberi, which, if untreated, can be life-threatening. However, thiamine deficiency usually occurs in countries where the main diet is composed of polished white rice or as a result of chronic alcohol abuse.

Fluoride crosses the placental barrier and is present in breast milk following environmental exposure. Most newborns have already accumulated measurable levels at birth. In regions where the drinking water is not fluoridated, the current recommendation is to administer fluoride to children but not before the age of 6 months due to the risk of fluorosis. Using fluoride to support dental hygiene protects against dental caries, which is not a life-threatening condition.

Vitamin K levels are low in all newborns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant. In addition, newborns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months. As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Folic acid (vitamin B9), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk, making postnatal supplementation unnecessary. Individuals planning pregnancy should be supplied with folic acid beginning ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continuing until 12 weeks' gestation to prevent neural tube defects. Infants born to folate-deficient mothers can develop megaloblastic anemia, but this carries no immediate postnatal complication or risk of mortality.

Iron stores in newborns are sufficient for the first 6 months of life, so immediate postnatal supplementation is not routinely required. Although breast milk contains only a small amount of iron, its bioavailability is high, which helps protect infants from iron deficiency during this period. After around 6 months of age, the introduction of iron-rich foods is recommended to prevent iron deficiency anemia.

Since vitamin D crosses the placenta, most newborns have adequate levels at birth. Furthermore, vitamin D deficiency would usually remain asymptomatic unless it led to rickets, which is not a life-threatening condition and not common in industrialized nations. However, as the amount of vitamin D in breastmilk is usually not sufficient to meet infants' daily requirements, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in exclusively and partially breastfed infants starting within the first few days of birth.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of developmental delay and recurrent tonic-clonic seizures. There is no family history of seizures or other serious illness. Current medications include risperidone for hyperactivity. He is at the 17th percentile for head circumference. Examination shows protrusion of the mandible, strabismus, and a laughing facial expression. His gait is unsteady. He has a vocabulary of about 200 words and cannot speak in full sentences. Karyotype analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype without chromosomal deletions. Which of the following genetic mechanisms best explains this patient's findings?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of developmental delay and recurrent tonic-clonic seizures. There is no family history of seizures or other serious illness. Current medications include risperidone for hyperactivity. He is at the 17th percentile for head circumference. Examination shows protrusion of the mandible, strabismus, and a laughing facial expression. His gait is unsteady. He has a vocabulary of about 200 words and cannot speak in full sentences. Karyotype analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype without chromosomal deletions. Which of the following genetic mechanisms best explains this patient's findings?
hint: This patient's history of developmental delay and seizures, along with his physical examination findings (protrusion of the mandible, strabismus, and laughing facial expression) are highly suggestive of Angelman syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Angelman syndrome, and recall its genetic mechanisms.

answers.explanation_why: Chromosome 22q11 microdeletion is the underlying genetic pathology of diGeorge syndrome. Although patients with diGeorge syndrome typically present with hypocalcemic seizures and dysmorphic facial features, these facial features would be different (e.g., prominent nasal bridge, hypoplastic wing of the nose, dysplastic ears, or micrognathia). Moreover, this patient does not show other typical features of diGeorge syndrome, such as thymus hypoplasia (e.g., history of recurrent infections), cardiac anomalies, cleft palate, and hypoparathyroidism.

answers.content: De novo mutation of MECP2 on the X chromosome
answers.explanation_why: A de novo mutation of the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome is the underlying genetic pathology of Rett syndrome. Although patients with Rett syndrome show signs of intellectual disability, normal mental development occurs initially and is then followed by progressive loss of intelligence, as well as locomotion and fine motor skills. Moreover, Rett syndrome is seen only in girls, which makes it unlikely in this male patient.

answers.content: Nondisjunction of chromosome 21 during meiosis I
answers.explanation_why: Chromosomal nondisjunction during meiosis I is most commonly seen in Down syndrome, which may manifest with intellectual disability. However, facial abnormalities would be different in a patient with Down syndrome (e.g., upward slanting of the eyelids, epicanthus, hypertelorism, broad and flat nasal bridge) and, most significantly, karyotype analysis would show autosomal trisomy (47, XY).

Paternal uniparental disomy is a rare cause of Angelman syndrome (only accounts for around 5% of cases) and results from inheritance of both copies of the paternal chromosome 15 and no copies of the maternal copy of chromosome 15. Because the progeny is euploid, there is no visible gene defect on karyotyping. Angelman syndrome is more commonly caused by paternal imprinting, in which there is a deletion or mutation of the maternal UBE3A allele and the paternal UBE3A allele is silenced.

images.title: Etiology of Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes

answers.explanation_why: A trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene is the underlying genetic pathology of fragile X syndrome. Although fragile X syndrome manifests with intellectual disability, this patient does not have other typical features of fragile X syndrome, such as a long and narrow face, big ears, or hypermobile joints. Furthermore, focal seizures occur in fragile X syndrome as opposed to the tonic-clonic seizures seen in this patient.

question_text: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being rescued from a fire in her apartment. The paramedics report a brief loss of consciousness during transport. The patient reports nausea, headache, and dizziness. She also has a hoarse voice and a cough productive of grey mucus. On arrival, she seems confused and drowsy. Physical examination shows superficial burns on her upper extremities and singed eyebrows. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by which of the following mechanisms?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being rescued from a fire in her apartment. The paramedics report a brief loss of consciousness during transport. The patient reports nausea, headache, and dizziness. She also has a hoarse voice and a cough productive of grey mucus. On arrival, she seems confused and drowsy. Physical examination shows superficial burns on her upper extremities and singed eyebrows. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by which of the following mechanisms?
hint: This patient was rescued from a domestic fire and presents with dysphonia, soot in the airways, and singed eyebrows, suggesting inhalation injury. Inhalation injury in combination with altered mental status, loss of consciousness, nausea, headache, and dizziness is consistent with carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.
learning_objective: Recognize carbon monoxide poisoning, and recall its effect on hemoglobin.

answers.explanation_why: CO is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas with a > 200 times greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen. CO occupies the oxygen binding site of hemoglobin, resulting in carboxyhemoglobin (COHb), which has a reduced capacity to carry oxygen. CO also causes a left shift of the oxygen dissociation curve by stabilizing hemoglobin in its bound state, which inhibits oxygen release into tissues with low paO2. Measured oxygen saturation is typically normal because standard pulse oximeters cannot differentiate between oxyhemoglobin and COHb. Patients should receive 100% O2 or hyperbaric O2 to offset CO bound to heme.

images.title: Oxygen dissociation curve for carbon monoxide poisoning
images.description: The pink line shows the normal change in blood oxygen content (O_2 bound to hemoglobin (Hb)) in the presence of increasing partial pressure of O_2 in arteries (P_aO_2). When carbon monoxide (CO) is bound to 50% of hemoglobin (green line), the maximal volume of O_2 bound to hemoglobin decreases and there is a left shift in the graph, reflecting the increase in O_2 affinity of hemoglobin.

answers.explanation_why: A rise in serum pH might be seen in respiratory alkalosis due to an increase in respiratory rate and/or tidal volume. This alveolar hyperventilation leads to CO_2 washout, causing a shift to the left in the oxygen dissociation curve. This shift could induce tissue hypoxia, manifesting with nausea, headache, and dizziness, which are seen in this patient. However, a rise in serum pH would not be caused by smoke inhalation injury.

Oxidation of ferrous iron (Fe^2+) to ferric iron (Fe^3+) results in the formation of methemoglobin. Methemoglobinemia can be caused by poisoning with nitrates (most common), oxidant drugs, chemicals, or toxins. Fe^3+ has a reduced affinity for binding oxygen, making methemoglobin a poor oxygen transporter. This results in tissue hypoxia, which can manifest with nausea, headache, and dizziness, symptoms found in this patient. However, oxidation of Fe^2+ is not caused by smoke inhalation injury.

Degradation of 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) by 2,3-BPG phosphatase to form 3-phosphoglycerate is a way around one step of glycolysis at the expense of one ATP. 2,3-BPG tightly binds to deoxyhemoglobin to promote oxygen release to peripheral tissues. It loosely binds to oxygenated hemoglobin to keep oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the lungs. Reduced 2,3-BPG shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the left, causing tissue hypoxia. This can manifest with nausea, headache, and dizziness, which are seen in this patient. However, degradation of 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate is not caused by smoke inhalation injury.

Inhibition of mitochondrial complex V is consistent with oligomycin use. Oligomycin inhibits ATP synthase, which decreases the ATP synthesis needed for energy and intracellular reactions. This lack of oxidative phosphorylation leads to increased anaerobic glycolysis, causing lactic acidosis, which can manifest with nausea and headache. However, inhibition of mitochondrial complex V is not caused by smoke inhalation injury. The substance most likely causing symptoms in this patient inhibits mitochondrial complex IV (cytochrome C oxidase), not complex V.

question_text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being rescued from a house fire. He reports headache, abdominal pain, and nausea. He appears confused and agitated. His pulse is 125/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination of the skin shows a bright red color. His breath smells of bitter almonds. Carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) level is 2% (N < 3). Treatment with sodium nitrite is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of the beneficial effect of this treatment?
content_preview: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being rescued from a house fire. He reports headache, abdominal pain, and nausea. He appears confused and agitated. His pulse is 125/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination of the skin shows a bright red color. His breath smells of bitter almonds. Carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) level is 2% (N < 3). Treatment with sodium nitrite is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of the beneficial effect of this treatment?
hint: This patient presents with headache, adbominal pain, altered mental status, tachycardia, dyspnea, bright red skin tone, and breath that smells like bitter almonds. These features in combination with normal pulse oximetry suggest cyanide poisoning.
learning_objective: Recognize cyanide poisoning, and recall the mechanism of nitrite therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Reducing ferric iron (Fe^3+) to ferrous iron (Fe^2+) is the goal of treatment for methemoglobinemia. The ferrous ion is the site of oxygen binding in hemoglobin, so it is necessary to restore the correct oxidation state of iron for effective delivery of oxygen to peripheral tissues. Methylene blue is indicated to treat methemoglobinemia by this mechanism, but it has no role in treating cyanide toxicity.

2,3-bisphosphoglycerate binds to deoxyhemoglobin and promotes oxygen release, increasing oxygen delivery to tissues. Although improving oxygen delivery to tissues is desirable in patients with cyanide poisoning to help counteract the cellular hypoxia caused by cyanide, this process is not sufficient to treat cyanide poisoning as it does not reduce serum cyanide levels. None of the indicated antidotes for cyanide poisoning act by this mechanism.

Cyanide blocks the electron transport chain by binding to cytochrome complex IV, thereby impairing oxidative phosphorylation and causing histotoxic hypoxia. Nitrites oxidize hemoglobin into methemoglobin, which binds cyanide (forming the compound cyanomethemoglobin), thereby resuming oxidative phosphorylation and improving symptoms. Other important treatments include hydroxocobalamin, which binds cyanide to form the harmless compound cyanocobalamin, and sodium thiosulfate, which converts cyanide to thiocyanide, allowing for safe excretion.

Nitrite therapy is not recommended in patients with suspected carbon monoxide poisoning, as inducing methemoglobinemia can worsen tissue hypoxia.

The dissociation of carboxyhemoglobin from physiologic hemoglobin is desirable in patients with carbon monoxide poisoning and is achieved by administering 100% oxygen or hyperbaric oxygen. Carbon monoxide poisoning, like cyanide poisoning, causes altered mental status, red/flushed skin, tachypnea, and normal pulse oximetry. However, almond-scented breath is not a feature of carbon monoxide poisoning. Additionally, this patient's COHb level is normal.

Inhibition of cytochrome c oxidase, a mitochondrial enzyme, impairs oxidative phosphorylation and leads to histotoxic hypoxia. This is the mechanism of cyanide toxicity, so the goal of treatment is to reverse this process. Other agents, such as azide, also poison cells via this process.

question_text: Three hours after undergoing a total right hip replacement, a 71-year-old woman has tingling around the lips and numbness in her fingertips. Her surgery was complicated by unintentional laceration of the right femoral artery that resulted in profuse bleeding. She appears uncomfortable. Examination shows an adducted thumb, extended fingers, and flexed metacarpophalangeal joints and wrists. Tapping on the cheeks leads to contraction of the facial muscles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Three hours after undergoing a total right hip replacement, a 71-year-old woman has tingling around the lips and numbness in her fingertips. Her surgery was complicated by unintentional laceration of the right femoral artery that resulted in profuse bleeding. She appears uncomfortable. Examination shows an adducted thumb, extended fingers, and flexed metacarpophalangeal joints and wrists. Tapping on the cheeks leads to contraction of the facial muscles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's numbness of her fingers and perioral region, carpopedal spasm, and positive Chvostek sign are indicative of hypocalcemia.
learning_objective: Recognize hypocalcemia due to calcium chelation.

answers.explanation_why: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is unlikely to cause the acute hypocalcemia seen in this patient even though profuse bleeding and subsequent systemic hypotension puts her at risk for AKI (or a clinical prerenal azotemia). However, secondary hyperparathyroidism resulting in normal to decreased serum calcium levels is often seen in patients with chronic kidney disease.

The chelation of calcium by citrate is the cause of hypocalcemia following massive blood transfusion. Citrate is an anticoagulant that is central to the storage of blood products. During transfusion, citrate prevents activation of the clotting cascade by chelating free extracellular calcium (a necessary cofactor for many steps in the coagulation cascade), resulting in transient hypocalcemia post-transfusion. In patients with symptomatic hypocalcemia, as seen here, calcium replacement therapy must be administered.

Because about half of the total serum calcium is bound to proteins, hypoalbuminemia will decrease the total calcium levels. However, ionized (or free) calcium concentrations are regulated hormonally and thus will not be affected. Since only ionized calcium is biologically active, hypocalcemia due to hypoalbuminemia usually is asymptomatic (pseudohypocalcemia) and would not explain this patient's symptoms.

Intravascular hemolysis following massive blood transfusion is concerning for an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction due to ABO incompatibility. Affected patients will present within 1 hour of transfusion with hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia, caused by destruction of donor RBCs by recipient antibodies. Symptoms include fever, flushing, pruritus, flank pain, dyspnea and a burning pain at the IV site; none of which are present in this patient. Hemoglobinuria and subsequent renal tubular necrosis may follow. Hypocalcemia, however, does not typically occur as part of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction.
answers.explanation_but: An acute hemolytic transfusion reaction requires immediate cessation of transfusion and supportive care.

answers.explanation_why: Parathyroid ischemia leads to hypocalcemia due to decreased release of parathyroid hormone. The most common cause is damage to the parathyroid glands during anterior midline surgeries or thyroidectomies. Although this patient's profuse bleeding and subsequent systemic hypotension may have caused tissue ischemia, a selective affection of the parathyroid glands is unlikely, as watershed areas in the GI tract and brain are far more susceptible to ischemia.

Metabolic acidosis reduces the affinity of albumin to bind calcium in the serum, resulting in increased serum levels of ionized (or free) calcium levels, i.e. hypercalcemia. Unlike this patient's presentation, hypercalcemia manifests with symptoms such as bone pain, myalgia, abdominal pain, constipation, polyuria, and neuropsychiatric abnormalities. Symptomatic hypocalcemia could, however, be caused by metabolic alkalosis leading to an increased albumin-calcium binding.

question_text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for episodic fever, recurrent night sweats, and a 6-kg (14.2-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. He reports that the fever lasts for 7 to 10 days, then subsides completely for about a week before returning again. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows nontender cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral mediastinal masses. Resection of a cervical lymph node is performed. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Further histopathological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for episodic fever, recurrent night sweats, and a 6-kg (14.2-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. He reports that the fever lasts for 7 to 10 days, then subsides completely for about a week before returning again. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows nontender cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral mediastinal masses. Resection of a cervical lymph node is performed. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Further histopathological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient presents with cyclical fever (following a typical Pel-Ebstein pattern), cervical (and likely also mediastinal) lymphadenopathy, and B symptoms. His biopsy shows an inflammatory background featuring large cells that appear to be multinucleated and have prominent nucleoli (Reed-Sternberg cells). These features confirm the diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma.
learning_objective: Recognize Hodgkin lymphoma, and recall its characteristic cell markers.

answers.content: Cells staining positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase
answers.explanation_why: Cells staining positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase are seen in hairy cell leukemia. HCL can manifest with B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, lymphadenopathy is uncommon in HCL, and this patient does not have other characteristic features of this condition (e.g., eponymous hairy cells, symptomatic cytopenia, and massive splenomegaly).

images.title: Hairy cell leukemia
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear sample (H&E stain)A typical hairy cell is visible on the right side of the image. It is significantly bigger than a normal lymphocyte and its membrane has hairy projections (e.g., arrowheads). There is abundant cytoplasm and the nucleus (green overlay) is displaced to one side.The presence of hairy cells in peripheral blood smears is characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.content: Cells staining positive for CD15 and CD30
answers.explanation_why: The lymph node biopsy of this patient with Hodgkin lymphoma shows Reed-Sternberg cells, which stain positive for CD15 and CD30. These large cells have two nuclei, or at least a bilobed nucleus, and prominent nucleoli surrounded by pale halos (owl-eye appearance), as seen in the biopsy specimen here. They are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma and confirm the diagnosis. Other histological findings in Hodgkin lymphoma include granuloma formation and an inflammatory background that contains the following cell types in varying numbers: lymphocytes, eosinophils, neutrophils, macrophages/histiocytes, plasma cells, and fibroblasts.

images.title: Hodgkin lymphoma (immunohistochemistry for CD30)
images.description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Cells with a BCR-ABL rearrangement are a characteristic finding of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). CML can manifest with B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, lymphadenopathy would not be expected. Furthermore, this patient does not have other common features of CML, such as basophilia, extreme leukocytosis, or a peripheral blood smear showing mid-stage progenitor cells (e.g., promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes).

images.title: Left shift to promyelocyte stage in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
images.description: Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)A typical finding in chronic myelogenous leukemia is marked leukocytosis with a spectrum of neutrophils in different stages of maturation, usually not seen in the peripheral blood.Seg: mature segmented neutrophils; St: stab cells/band cells; PM: promyelocytes; L: lymphocytes; P: platelets

answers.explanation_why: Cells overexpressing Bcl-2 are seen in follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Either disease can manifest with painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, the pathological findings would differ from those seen here. Biopsy in follicular lymphoma would reveal densely packed lymphoid follicles with small cleaved cells, while biopsy in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma would typically show a diffuse growth pattern and large lymphocytes.

images.title: Follicular lymphoma (peripheral blood smear)
images.description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Cells with a t(8;14) chromosomal translocation are typically seen in Burkitt lymphoma, which can manifest with the painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms seen in this patient. However, this patient's Pel-Ebstein fever pattern would be atypical in Burkitt lymphoma. Furthermore, biopsy would typically show a starry sky pattern instead of the Reed-Sternberg cells found here.

images.title: Hodgkin lymphoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a lymph node biopsy specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)A Reed–Sternberg cell (green overlay) can be seen in the center of the image. It is surrounded by numerous lymphocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads).This histopathological appearance is characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive daytime sleepiness and exertional dyspnea for the past 6 months. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and several pinpoint, purple spots on his legs. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 3000/mm^3, and platelet count is 16,000/mm^3. A peripheral blood smear shows normochromic, normocytic cells. Which of the following laboratory values is most likely to be increased in this patient?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive daytime sleepiness and exertional dyspnea for the past 6 months. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and several pinpoint, purple spots on his legs. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 3000/mm3, and platelet count is 16,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows normochromic, normocytic cells. Which of the following laboratory values is most likely to be increased in this patient?
hint: A bone marrow biopsy of this patient would most likely show hypocellular, fat-filled bone marrow, consistent with aplastic anemia.
learning_objective: Recognize aplastic anemia, and recall the laboratory value that is physiologically increased in response to anemia.

answers.explanation_why: Transferrin concentration varies inversely to iron stores and is therefore increased in patients with iron deficiency anemia. This patient's peripheral blood smear shows no features of iron deficiency (e.g., microcytosis, hypochromasia). In addition, pancytopenia cannot be explained by iron deficiency alone. Instead, this patient's presentation is concerning for aplastic anemia in which iron stores, and thus transferrin concentrations, are typically normal. In some cases of aplastic anemia, iron stores may even be increased (due to lack of use) and transferrin levels decreased accordingly.

Elevated homocysteine concentrations may be seen in vitamin B_12 deficiency or folate deficiency. A deficiency of these vitamins can cause megaloblastic anemia and may even lead to pancytopenia. However, peripheral blood smear in patients with megaloblastic anemia typically shows macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils, not normochromic, normocytic cells.

The reticulocyte count can serve as a marker of effective erythropoiesis. An elevated reticulocyte count may be seen in cases of increased RBC breakdown or loss. As this patient's presentation is concerning for aplastic anemia, in which bone marrow activity is drastically reduced, his reticulocyte count would be decreased rather than increased.

Clinical findings of fatigue, pallor, and petechiae (pinpoint, purple spots), together with laboratory results showing pancytopenia, are consistent with aplastic anemia. In patients with aplastic anemia, peripheral blood smear typically shows normocytosis or mild macrocytosis. An increase in erythropoietin (EPO) production (hypoxia-induced EPO expression) is a physiological response to anemia, as EPO stimulates erythropoiesis. Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure, which has a variety of causes, such as viruses, medication side effects, congenital etiologies, radiation, and toxins; > 50% of cases are idiopathic.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is a marker of cell breakdown. The combination of pancytopenia and increased LDH may be seen in conditions such as paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria or hematological malignancy (e.g., acute leukemia). However, these conditions typically also manifest with abnormal blood smear findings, such as signs of hemolysis (e.g., schistocytes) or malignancy (e.g., blast cells).

question_text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of swelling and pain in the left leg. Two days ago, she returned from a business trip on a long-distance flight. She has alcohol use disorder. Physical examination shows a tender, swollen, and warm left calf. Serum studies show a methylmalonic acid concentration within the reference range and an increased homocysteine concentration. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following serum findings?
content_preview: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of swelling and pain in the left leg. Two days ago, she returned from a business trip on a long-distance flight. She has alcohol use disorder. Physical examination shows a tender, swollen, and warm left calf. Serum studies show a methylmalonic acid concentration within the reference range and an increased homocysteine concentration. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following serum findings?
hint: This patient has a deep vein thrombosis, which typically manifests with pain, swelling, and warmth of the leg. Risk factors for this condition include a history of prolonged immobilization (e.g., long-distance flights) and coagulopathies (e.g., from hyperhomocysteinemia).
learning_objective: Recognize deep vein thrombosis associated with hyperhomocysteinemia, and recall the expected serum findings.

answers.explanation_why: Increased pyridoxine (vitamin B_6) serum concentrations are rarely seen because this water-soluble vitamin is readily cleared from the body. Manifestations of pyridoxine toxicity include peripheral neuropathy, rash, and photosensitivity, none of which is seen in this patient. In fact, pyridoxine deficiency (e.g., due to alcohol use disorder), not toxicity, is associated with deep vein thrombosis due to impairment of conversion of homocysteine to cystathionine, which is dependent on vitamin B_6. Accumulation of homocysteine results in a hypercoagulable state, which increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

Fibrinogen is a coagulation factor that is converted by thrombin into fibrin, which is then used to stabilize platelet aggregates. Thromboembolic events (e.g., deep vein thrombosis) involve the activation of the coagulation cascade and subsequent consumption of fibrinogen; this patient is therefore likely to have a decreased serum fibrinogen concentration.

Cobalamin (vitamin B_12) serves as a coenzyme for the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. Cobalamin deficiency therefore results in the accumulation of homocysteine. Hyperhomocysteinemia leads to hypercoagulability and is associated with thromboembolic events, such as deep vein thrombosis. This patient's alcohol use disorder puts her at risk of cobalamin deficiency due to malnutrition; however, because cobalamin is also required to convert methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, increased methylmalonic acid serum concentrations would be expected. Moreover, this patient lacks the neuropsychiatric symptoms associated with cobalamin deficiency (e.g., ataxia, neuropathy, cognitive decline).

Protein C inhibits the coagulation cascade by inactivating factor Va and factor VIIIa. Thus, decreased serum protein C concentration (e.g., due to inherited protein C deficiency or vitamin K antagonist therapy) increases the risk of thromboembolic events such as deep vein thrombosis and can result in warfarin-induced skin and soft tissue necrosis. However, protein C deficiency is not associated with an increased serum homocysteine concentration.

Folate serves as a coenzyme in several biochemical reactions, including the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. Since this reaction is also vitamin B_12-dependent, a deficiency of either vitamin (e.g., from malnutrition due to alcohol use disorder) results in the accumulation of homocysteine. Hyperhomocysteinemia leads to hypercoagulability and is therefore associated with thromboembolic events such as deep vein thrombosis. The underlying mechanisms include decreased endothelial antithrombotic activity and activation of procoagulatory factors (e.g., factor V, factor VII). A normal serum methylmalonic acid concentration, as seen here, indicates folate deficiency rather than vitamin B_12 deficiency.

In addition to malnutrition, folate deficiency can also be caused by malabsorptive conditions (e.g., celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease), increased vitamin requirements (e.g., due to pregnancy), and certain drugs (e.g., methotrexate, phenytoin, trimethoprim).

images.title: Pathophysiology of homocystinuria
images.description:
Methionine synthase deficiency or MTHFR deficiency: impaired conversion of homocysteine to methionine
Cystathionine synthase deficiency or reduced affinity of cystathionine synthase for pyridoxal phosphate: impaired conversion of homocysteine to cystathionineBoth result in accumulation of homocysteine.Substances shown in blue text are enzymes (e.g., MTHFR). Substances shown in parentheses and blue shading are cofactors in enzymatic reactions (e.g., FAD). Substances shown in beige shading are B vitamins, highlighted here because treatment of homocystinuria may involve B vitamin supplementation.PLP: pyridoxal phosphate (active form of vitamin B_6); MTHFR: methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase; FAD: flavin adenine dinucleotide (derived from vitamin B_2); THF: tetrahydrofolate (derived from vitamin B_9)

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of fever and recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his extremities for the past 6 hours. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and development was normal until the age of 1 year. The parents report that he has had gradual loss of speech, vision, and motor skills over the past year. During this time, he has been admitted to the hospital three times because of myoclonic seizures. Physical examination shows hypertonicity of the upper and lower extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. An MRI of the brain shows brain atrophy and hyperintensity of the periventricular and subcortical areas. Two days after admission, the patient dies. Histopathologic examination of the brain shows aggregation of globoid cells and loss of glial cells. The patient’s condition was most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of fever and recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his extremities for the past 6 hours. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and development was normal until the age of 1 year. The parents report that he has had gradual loss of speech, vision, and motor skills over the past year. During this time, he has been admitted to the hospital three times because of myoclonic seizures. Physical examination shows hypertonicity of the upper and lower extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. An MRI of the brain shows brain atrophy and hyperintensity of the periventricular and subcortical areas. Two days after admission, the patient dies. Histopathologic examination of the brain shows aggregation of globoid cells and loss of glial cells. The patient’s condition was most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
hint: Giant, multinucleated histiocytes (globoid cells) on histopathologic examination of the brain are diagnostic of Krabbe disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Krabbe disease, and recall the enzyme deficiency it involves.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of sphingomyelinase, which leads to an accumulation of sphingomyelin mainly in the brain, liver, spleen and bone marrow, is the primary defect in Niemann-Pick disease (NPD). This condition can manifest with seizures and progressive neurodegeneration with brain atrophy. However, NPD is typically associated with hypotonia (not hypertonia), a cherry-red spot on the macula on fundoscopic examination (rather than optic disc pallor), interstitial lung disease, and hepatosplenomegaly, none of which is seen here. Moreover, globoid cells on brain biopsy are not a feature of NPD.

A deficiency of arylsulfatase A, which leads to an accumulation of cerebroside sulfate mainly in the central and peripheral nervous system, is the primary defect in metachromatic leukodystrophy (ML). ML can manifest with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), brain and optic atrophy (optic pallor and vision loss), seizures, and loss of glial cells on brain biopsy, all of which are seen in this patient. However, globoid cells on brain biopsy are not a feature of this condition. Moreover, ML typically also manifests with ataxia and hypotonia (not hypertonia), which are not seen here.

A deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase, which leads to an accumulation of glucocerebroside in the brain, liver, spleen, and bone marrow, is the primary defect in Gaucher disease. Some patients with this condition present with neurological complications such as developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), loss of vision (from macular atrophy and uveitis), and seizures. However, Gaucher disease is not associated with brain or optic atrophy (optic disc pallor) or globoid cells on brain biopsy. Instead, typical manifestations of Gaucher disease include hepatosplenomegaly, petechiae, painful bone crises, and pathological fractures, none of which is seen here.

A deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A, which leads to an accumulation of GM_2 ganglioside mainly in the brain and retina, is the primary defect in Tay-Sachs disease (TSD). This condition can manifest with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), vision loss, and seizures. However, TSD is typically also associated with muscle weakness and hypotonia (not hypertonia), hyperreflexia, hearing impairment and a cherry-red spot on the macula on fundoscopic examination (not optic disc pallor), none of which is present here. Moreover, brain biopsy of a patient with TSD typically reveals lysosomes with an onion skin appearance, not globoid cells.

A deficiency of β-galactocerebrosidase, which leads to intracellular accumulation of myelin breakdown products (galactocerebroside and psychosine) in the central and peripheral nervous system, is the primary defect in Krabbe disease. Characteristic pathologic findings resulting from the toxic effect of these breakdown products include globoid cells and progressive loss of myelin sheaths. Krabbe disease most commonly manifests in early infancy with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), fever, limb spasticity, brain and optic atrophy (optic disc pallor and vision loss), and seizures, as seen in this patient. Further symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, axial hypotonia, absent reflexes, and microcephaly. Progressive decerebration usually leads to death before the age of two.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been shown to improve outcomes if performed before the onset of symptoms.

images.title: Lysosomal storage disease
images.description: The chart illustrates the breakdown of select sphingolipids in the lysosomes, the corresponding enzymes that catalyze the reactions, and the diseases that an enzyme defect can cause.GM1, GM2, GM3, GA1, and GA2 refer to various gangliosides, i.e., sphingolipids with different sugar residues.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of α-galactosidase A is the primary defect in Fabry disease and leads to an accumulation of ceramide trihexoside (globotriaosylceramide) in the endothelium of vessels, the epithelium of many organs, and smooth muscle cells. This condition classically manifests during late childhood with paresthesias and neuropathic pain, hypohidrosis, angiokeratomas, asymptomatic cataracts, and gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient's presentation is not consistent with Fabry disease.

question_text: A 57-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. He was recently diagnosed with hyperlipidemia, for which he takes several medications. His serum total cholesterol concentration is 295 mg/dL and serum high-density lipoprotein concentration is 19 mg/dL. The physician prescribes an additional drug that decreases hepatic production of triglycerides and reduces the release of VLDL and LDL through the inhibition of diacylglycerol acyltransferase 2. This patient should be advised to do which of the following?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. He was recently diagnosed with hyperlipidemia, for which he takes several medications. His serum total cholesterol concentration is 295 mg/dL and serum high-density lipoprotein concentration is 19 mg/dL. The physician prescribes an additional drug that decreases hepatic production of triglycerides and reduces the release of VLDL and LDL through the inhibition of diacylglycerol acyltransferase 2. This patient should be advised to do which of the following?
hint: The drug that has been prescribed is niacin.
learning_objective: Recognize the side effects of niacin therapy, and choose the appropriate premedication to reduce these effects.

answers.content: Take aspirin shortly before taking the new drug to reduce pruritus
answers.explanation_why:
Niacin frequently causes pruritus, cutaneous flushing, paresthesias, and/or nausea due to the increased synthesis and release of prostaglandins. To reduce these side effects, aspirin or ibuprofen can be taken prior to the administration of niacin to decrease the production of prostaglandins. Taking the medication with food and/or using a prolonged release formulation can also help mitigate these side effects.

Niacin can also cause hyperglycemia, hyperuricemia, hypotension, and hepatotoxicity.

answers.content: Schedule a follow-up appointment in 2 weeks to check serum creatine kinase levels
answers.explanation_why: Measurement of creatine kinase levels is indicated in patients who have symptoms of severe myopathy (e.g., severe myalgias) to assess for rhabdomyolysis, a rare but serious complication of statin therapy. This patient is most likely already taking a statin, putting him at increased risk of statin-induced myopathy due to the additive effect of niacin. However, routine monitoring of CK in an asymptomatic patient is not recommended.

answers.content: Take diphenhydramine with the new drug to prevent skin rash
answers.explanation_why: Antihistamines can be used to treat rash and pruritus that are caused by histamine release (e.g., due to type I hypersensitivity reaction, pseudoallergic reaction, vancomycin flushing reaction). Niacin, which this patient has been prescribed, is not associated with a histamine-mediated skin reaction.

answers.content: Avoid smoking because of the new drug's increased risk of thrombosis
answers.explanation_why: Patients taking any medication associated with an increased risk of thrombosis (e.g., oral contraceptives, celecoxib) should be counseled to avoid smoking, due to the additive risk of VTE associated with smoking. Niacin, which this patient has been prescribed, is not associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.

answers.content: Check blood glucose levels after taking the new drug to detect hypoglycemia
answers.explanation_why: Niacin can cause hyperglycemia and may serve as a risk factor for the development of diabetes mellitus. However, niacin is not associated with the development of hypoglycemia and checking blood glucose levels after the administration of the new medication is unnecessary.

his wife noticed 6 weeks ago that he had bruising on the bilateral lower extremities

hint: This patient's history of decreased appetite and low BMI (17 kg/m^2) suggest malnutrition, which is complicated by a vitamin deficiency as indicated by impaired wound healing and an impaired immune response.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical manifestations of vitamin C deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) results in impaired collagen synthesis and easily-damaged connective tissue, which manifests with swollen gums and mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs (corkscrew hairs), perifollicular hemorrhages, anemia (fatigue, pallor), and easy bruising (e.g., multiple ecchymoses). His joint pain may be caused by hemarthroses from vitamin C deficiency or may be due to his underlying osteoarthritis. Populations at increased risk for developing nutritional deficiencies include individuals with substance use disorders, the elderly, and patients who are chronically ill, such as this man with non-small cell lung carcinoma who may have poor intake due to loss of appetite and chemotherapy-induced nausea. The treatment for scurvy is vitamin C supplementation.

Vitamin A deficiency is associated with several ocular and dermatologic manifestations, including night blindness, xerophthalmia, keratomalacia, Bitot spots, and xerosis. In addition, vitamin A deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

Vitamin D deficiency can cause osteomalacia and symptoms of hypocalcemia (e.g., paresthesias, muscle spasms). It does not cause anemia (fatigue, pallor), mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

Vitamin B_12 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy (decreased sensation in the lower extremities) as well as fatigue and pallor (due to macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia). However, this patient's peripheral neuropathy is likely caused by cisplatin-based chemotherapy. Other symptoms of vitamin B_12 deficiency include ataxia and spasticity (due to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord) and manifestations of neuropsychiatric diseases such as dementia and depression. Moreover, vitamin B_12 deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

Vitamin B_6 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy (decreased sensation in the lower extremities) as well as fatigue and pallor (due to sideroblastic anemia). However, this patient's peripheral neuropathy is likely caused by cisplatin-based chemotherapy. Other symptoms of vitamin B_6 deficiency include cheilitis, glossitis, and stomatitis. Moreover, vitamin B_6 deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

Vitamin K is a cofactor for factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X of the coagulation cascade; vitamin K deficiency causes coagulopathy that could manifest with ecchymoses, mucosal bleeding, and pallor. However, vitamin K deficiency does not cause coiled hairs. In addition, perifollicular hemorrhages are highly specific for another nutritional deficiency.

question_text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a follow-up examination. He has had a short stature since birth and underwent diagnostic testing. Genetic analyses showed a gain of function mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene. He has met all developmental milestones. He is at the 10^th percentile for height and 90^th percentile for weight. Which of the following additional findings is most likely on physical examination?
content_preview: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a follow-up examination. He has had a short stature since birth and underwent diagnostic testing. Genetic analyses showed a gain of function mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene. He has met all developmental milestones. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 90th percentile for weight. Which of the following additional findings is most likely on physical examination?
hint: Constitutive activation of FGFR3 impairs chondrocyte proliferation in the growth plate and is the cause of achondroplasia.
learning_objective: Recognize achondroplasia, and recall its characteristic facial features.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's short stature since birth might raise concern for cleidocranial dysplasia (CCD), which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in a transcription factor involved in osteoblast development and is characterized by absent collar bones. CCD typically manifests with mildly disproportionate short stature (short limb length relative to the trunk), other skeletal abnormalities (e.g., delayed closure of cranial sutures, pelvic abnormalities, scoliosis) that often lead to gross motor delay, dental abnormalities (e.g., supernumerary teeth, unerupted permanent teeth), and characteristic facial dysmorphism (wide face, prominent forehead and chin, maxillary hypoplasia).

This patient's short stature since birth should raise concern for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in type 1 collagen genes (COL1A1 or COL1A2) and can manifest with blue sclera. Further symptoms include progressive hearing loss, brittle bones and recurrent pathological fractures, and dentinogenesis imperfecta (brittle, opalescent teeth), none of which is seen in this patient. OI is managed with IV bisphosphonates to decrease the risk of fractures.

Disproportionately long extremities are characteristic of Marfan syndrome (caused by a mutation in fibrillin-1) and homocystinuria (caused by mutations in enzymes of homocysteine metabolism). Both conditions are associated with tall stature rather than the short stature seen here. Other common features of both Marfan syndrome and homocystinuria include pectus deformity, arachnodactyly, joint hyperlaxity, skin hyperelasticity, and scoliosis, which are absent in this patient.

This patient's short stature since birth may raise concern for Laron syndrome, which is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the growth hormone (GH) receptor gene and can manifest with small genitalia. Laron syndrome typically manifests with disproportionate short stature (average-sized torso with short extremities), distinctive facial dysmorphism (saddle nose, prominent forehead, microcephaly), delayed gross motor developmental milestones and metabolic abnormalities (e.g., osteopenia, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypoglycemia).

Achondroplasia causes disproportionate short stature (average-sized torso with short extremities), characteristic facial dysmorphism (frontal bossing, macrocephaly, midface retrusion, nose flattening), and spinal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis, thoracolumbar kyphosis). Patients with achondroplasia have normal intelligence and typically meet all developmental milestones, as seen here. Approximately 80% of achondroplasia cases are due to sporadic FGFR3 mutations and approximately 20% of cases are caused by autosomal dominant inheritance with full penetrance. The probability of new mutations increases with paternal age at the time of conception.
