question_text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of anxiety, irritability, insomnia, and abdominal pain that began after a weekend of partying. She also reports “bloody” urine as well as a tingling sensation in her hands and feet. She has never experienced similar symptoms. She does not smoke but says that she tends to drink too much (5 or more drinks) when partying with friends. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 123/min, and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Examination shows slightly decreased power in the shoulders (3/5) and thighs (4/5), along with hyporeflexia. Urine dipstick shows:

Blood
Negative

Protein
Negative

WBC
Negative

Bilirubin
Negative

Urobilinogen
3+

This patient's condition is most likely caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of anxiety, irritability, insomnia, and abdominal pain that began after a weekend of partying. She also reports “bloody” urine as well as a tingling sensation in her hands and feet. She has never experienced similar symptoms. She does not smoke but says that she tends to drink too much (5 or more drinks) when partying with friends. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 123/min, and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Examination shows slightly decreased power in the shoulders (3/5) and thighs (4/5), along with hyporeflexia. Urine dipstick shows: Blood Negative Protein Negative WBC Negative Bilirubin Negative Urobilinogen 3+ This patient's condition is most likely caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?
hint: This patient presents with the characteristic 5 “Ps” of acute intermittent porphyria: Painful abdomen, Psychologic disturbances (anxiety, irritability, insomnia), Polyneuropathy (hyporeflexia, tingling sensation, muscle weakness), reddish Pee, and Precipitated by alcohol.
learning_objective: Recognize acute intermittent porphyria, and recall the enzyme deficiency it involves.

answers.explanation_why: Alkaptonuria is caused by a defect in homogentisic acid dioxygenase. This condition manifests with bluish-black discoloration of connective tissue and body fluids, including urine. Further symptoms, which typically occur in adulthood, include arthralgia, nephrolithiasis, or heart valve stenosis due to calcification. This patient's neurovisceral symptoms are inconsistent with alkaptonuria.

Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase porphyria, an extremely rare autosomal recessive disorder, is caused by a defect in ALA dehydratase, a heme synthesis enzyme. Although patients present with neurovisceral attacks similar to the one seen here, ALA dehydratase porphyria usually manifests in late childhood, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient. Furthermore, ALA dehydratase can be inhibited due to lead poisoning, which can manifest with symptoms such as abdominal pain, sensorimotor neuropathy, and psychiatric disturbances. This patient, however, has no history of lead exposure.

X-linked sideroblastic anemia is caused by a defect in aminolevulinic acid synthase, a heme synthesis enzyme. Patients present with signs and symptoms of anemia (e.g., fatigue, lethargy, pallor), none of which are seen here. This patient's symptoms suggest acute intermittent porphyria, which is caused by a defect in a different enzyme.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is caused by an inherited or acquired defect in uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, a heme synthesis enzyme. PCT, for which alcohol consumption is a risk factor, can manifest with reddish discoloration of the urine due to the accumulation of uroporphyrin. This patient's neurovisceral symptoms, however, are inconsistent with this condition. Typical findings of PCT include skin hyperpigmentation, hypertrichosis, and blistering photosensitivity due to uroporphyrin accumulation in the skin.

Erythropoietic protoporphyria is caused by a genetic defect in ferrochelatase, a heme synthesis enzyme. This rare condition typically manifests in childhood with extreme photosensitivity. Furthermore, ferrochelatase can be inhibited by lead poisoning, which can manifest with symptoms such as abdominal pain, sensorimotor neuropathy, and psychiatric disturbances. This patient, however, has no history of lead exposure.

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a defect in porphobilinogen deaminase, a heme synthesis enzyme that converts porphobilinogen to hydroxymethylbilane. This defect leads to accumulation of potentially toxic intermediates of the early steps of heme synthesis, such as porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid (δ-ALA). Neurologic dysfunction (manifesting as sensorimotor, psychiatric, and autonomic symptoms, all of which are seen here) may also be caused by an impaired electron transport chain and energy production due to lack of heme. Precipitating factors for AIP attacks include alcohol, smoking, fasting, and certain drugs (e.g., cytochrome P450 inducers). Treatment includes cessation of such substances and administration of hemin and glucose, which inhibit δ-ALA synthase.

In patients with AIP, urobilinogen urine dipstick findings can be false-positive because of a cross-reaction between porphobilinogen and urobilinogen. The reddish-brown urine color, which may be mistaken for hematuria, is due to the accumulation of porphyrins.

images.title: Heme synthesis and corresponding diseases
images.description: Overview of heme synthesis and its key enzymes as well as the molecular causes of several diseases that interfere with heme synthesis.

question_text: A 2860-g (6-lb 3-oz) male newborn is born at term to a primigravid woman via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother has had no routine prenatal care. She reports that there is no family history of serious illness. The initial examination of the newborn shows bowing of the legs and respiratory distress upon palpation of the chest. The skin and joints are hyperextensible. X-rays of the chest and skull show multiple rib fractures and small, irregular bones along the cranial sutures. The patient is at increased risk of which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 2860-g (6-lb 3-oz) male newborn is born at term to a primigravid woman via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother has had no routine prenatal care. She reports that there is no family history of serious illness. The initial examination of the newborn shows bowing of the legs and respiratory distress upon palpation of the chest. The skin and joints are hyperextensible. X-rays of the chest and skull show multiple rib fractures and small, irregular bones along the cranial sutures. The patient is at increased risk of which of the following complications?
hint: This patient's presentation with multiple perinatal fractures, bowing of legs, and hyperextensibility of the skin and joints suggests a diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI).
learning_objective: Recognize osteogenesis imperfecta, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Costochondral junction enlargement (rachitic rosary) is characteristic of rickets, which can cause bone deformities (including tibial bowing) and impaired growth, as well as fractures in severe cases. However, rickets does not cause skin or joint hypermobility. Costochondral prominence is not a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Intestinal rupture is a complication seen in patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), especially the vascular subtype, wherein defective synthesis of collagen type III leads to the formation of fragile tissue that is susceptible to rupture. Affected individuals may present with hyperextensible skin and joints, as seen here, but multiple bone fractures are not a feature of EDS. Intestinal rupture is not associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

Several causes of short stature, including chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Down syndrome, Williams syndrome), inborn errors of metabolism (e.g., Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, homocystinuria), and exposure to toxins in utero (e.g., fetal alcohol syndrome), can cause intellectual disability. However, these conditions do not manifest with perinatal fractures and skin and joint hyperextensibility. Patients with osteogenesis imperfecta typically have preserved cognitive ability.

Spinal stenosis can occur in patients with achondroplasia, resulting in low back and leg pain, paresthesias, and incontinence. Patients with achondroplasia may also present with respiratory distress due to a small chest cavity and varus deforming of the legs. However, achondroplasia does not cause skin or joint hypermobility, nor does it increase the risk of developing fractures. Spinal stenosis is not a complication of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Hearing loss occurs in patients with OI as a result of bone formation defects such as otosclerosis and ossicle fractures and atrophy. Autosomal dominant mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, which encode the alpha chains of type I collagen, are responsible for most cases of OI. The severe subtypes (types II, III) of OI are usually due to a new (sporadic) mutation in one of these genes, while patients with the mild forms (types I, IV) typically have a parent with the condition. Additional findings in patients with OI include blue sclerae (due to choroidal veins appearing through the overlying thin sclerae), easy bruising, and brittle, opalescent teeth.

In this patient, the described irregular bones around the cranial sutures are indicative of wormian bones. Excessive amounts (> 10) of wormian bones are a feature of OI.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and yellowish discoloration of her skin. During this period, she has also had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight gain. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine daily. She follows a vegan diet that consists mainly of spinach, kale, and sweet potatoes. Physical examination shows yellowing of the skin. Her hands are cold to the touch and her nails appear brittle. Eye examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient's serum?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and yellowish discoloration of her skin. During this period, she has also had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight gain. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine daily. She follows a vegan diet that consists mainly of spinach, kale, and sweet potatoes. Physical examination shows yellowing of the skin. Her hands are cold to the touch and her nails appear brittle. Eye examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient's serum?
hint: Notably, this patient does not present with scleral icterus.
learning_objective: Recognize pseudojaundice due to carotenemia, and recall the expected serum finding.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased haptoglobin concentration occurs in hemolysis, which results in yellow skin discoloration through deposition of bilirubin, a degradation product of hemoglobin, in the subcutaneous fat tissue. This patient also presents with fatigue, which can be caused by hemolytic anemia. However, unlike this patient's presentation, hyperbilirubinemia would lead to jaundice of the sclerae and mucous membranes before affecting the skin.

Increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP) concentration occurs in obstructive jaundice, which also leads to yellow skin discoloration through the accumulation of bilirubin in the subcutaneous fat tissue. However, hyperbilirubinemia would also cause jaundice of the sclerae and mucous membranes (before it is visible on the skin), which this patient notably lacks. Additionally, typical signs of cholestasis such as pale stools, dark urine, pruritus, and symptoms of fat malabsorption (e.g., steatorrhea, weight loss) are absent in this patient.

Antimitochondrial antibodies are present in patients with primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC), which leads to intrahepatic cholestasis (due to the destruction of the intrahepatic bile ducts) and yellow discoloration of the skin from bilirubin deposition in the subcutaneous fat tissue. This patient's fatigue, age, gender, and (likely autoimmune) hypothyroidism suggest PBC. However, the hyperbilirubinemia seen in PBC would cause jaundice of the sclerae and mucous membranes before visibly affecting the skin.

Increased beta-carotene concentration causes pseudojaundice, which manifests with yellow discoloration of the skin, especially in the hands, soles, forehead, and nose because beta-carotene accumulates in the skin's epidermis; the sclerae and mucous membranes are spared, as seen here. Carotenemia can result from excessive consumption of sweet potatoes, leafy greens, carrots, and oranges; increased intake of carotene-rich supplements may also cause carotenemia. This patient's weight gain, fatigue, brittle nails, and cold skin indicates hypothyroidism, which leads to reduced production of vitamin A from beta-carotene due to lack of thyroxine, thereby further increasing beta-carotene levels.

images.title: Carotenemia
images.description: The orange discoloration of the palm stands in stark contrast to the nondiscolored skin of the shoulder in the background.

answers.explanation_why: Anti-HAV IgM antibodies indicate a hepatitis A infection, which leads to yellow discoloration of the skin through bilirubin deposition in the subcutaneous fat tissue. However, unlike this patient's presentation, hyperbilirubinemia would lead to jaundice of sclerae and mucous membranes before visibly affecting the skin. Additionally, this patient lacks other symptoms of hepatitis A, such as fever, nausea, anorexia, and right upper quadrant pain.

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of low performance in school since starting 1^st grade 2 months ago. His mother reports that, according to his teachers, he always prefers to sit close to the blackboard. He continuously interrupts other children while they are talking and is unable to sit quietly through a classroom period. When he is asked by the teacher to stop, he bursts into tears and leaves the classroom. His parents say that “he has always been a bit slower than his peers.” Physical examination shows pale skin, long and slender toes and fingers, and hunching of the back. Visual acuity is decreased bilaterally. His serum methionine concentration is increased. A deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of low performance in school since starting 1st grade 2 months ago. His mother reports that, according to his teachers, he always prefers to sit close to the blackboard. He continuously interrupts other children while they are talking and is unable to sit quietly through a classroom period. When he is asked by the teacher to stop, he bursts into tears and leaves the classroom. His parents say that “he has always been a bit slower than his peers.” Physical examination shows pale skin, long and slender toes and fingers, and hunching of the back. Visual acuity is decreased bilaterally. His serum methionine concentration is increased. A deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: Intellectual disability, behavioral changes, arachnodactyly, kyphosis, decreased visual acuity, and light skin in a 6-year-old patient suggest hereditary homocystinuria, in which homocysteine accumulates in serum and is excreted in the urine. Hereditary homocystinuria can be caused by one of several autosomal recessive enzyme defects; the increase in serum methionine indicates which enzyme is deficient.
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary homocystinuria, and recall the enzyme deficiency associated with it.

answers.explanation_why: S-adenosyl methionine synthase converts methionine and ATP to S-adenosylmethionine, which is an intermediate substrate in the conversion of methionine to homocysteine. A deficiency of this enzyme can cause intellectual disability and an increased serum methionine concentration, as seen here. However, it would not explain the arachnodactyly, kyphosis, pale skin, and decreased visual acuity seen in this patient. Instead, features such as muscle weakness, facial dysmorphism, liver disease, and a boiled cabbage odor would be expected.

Methionine synthase converts homocysteine to methionine using vitamin B_12 as a cofactor. Homocystinuria, which is responsible for this patient's clinical features, can be caused by methionine synthase deficiency, but a deficiency of this enzyme would be expected to cause a decrease rather than an increase in serum methionine concentration.

Cystathionine synthase converts homocysteine and serine to cystathionine using vitamin B_6 as a cofactor; a deficiency of this enzyme is one of the causes of homocystinuria. In homocystinuria caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity of vitamin B_6 for cystathionine synthase, homocysteine is converted back to methionine by methionine synthase, resulting in an increased serum methionine concentration, as seen here. The treatment for cystathionine synthase deficiency consists of a diet low in methionine and rich in cysteine, and supplementation of vitamin B_6, B_12, and folate.

images.title: Pathophysiology of homocystinuria
images.description:
Methionine synthase deficiency or MTHFR deficiency: impaired conversion of homocysteine to methionine
Cystathionine synthase deficiency or reduced affinity of cystathionine synthase for pyridoxal phosphate: impaired conversion of homocysteine to cystathionineBoth result in accumulation of homocysteine.Substances shown in blue text are enzymes (e.g., MTHFR). Substances shown in parentheses and blue shading are cofactors in enzymatic reactions (e.g., FAD). Substances shown in beige shading are B vitamins, highlighted here because treatment of homocystinuria may involve B vitamin supplementation.PLP: pyridoxal phosphate (active form of vitamin B_6); MTHFR: methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase; FAD: flavin adenine dinucleotide (derived from vitamin B_2); THF: tetrahydrofolate (derived from vitamin B_9)

answers.explanation_why: Phenylalanine hydroxylase hydroxylates phenylalanine to tyrosine, and a deficiency in this enzyme results in phenylketonuria. If untreated, phenylketonuria causes intellectual disability, behavioral changes, and pale skin, as seen here. However, this condition would not explain the arachnodactyly, kyphosis, decreased visual acuity, or increased serum methionine concentration seen in this patient. Moreover, neonatal screening would show increased serum phenyl ketones, and, if the condition went untreated, features such as failure to thrive, dermatitis, and/or a musty body odor would be expected as well.

images.title: Classic phenylketonuria vs. tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency (malignant PKU)

answers.explanation_why: Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase reduces N5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate to N5-methyltetrahydrofolate, which serves as a cofactor for the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. Homocystinuria, which is responsible for this patient's clinical features, can be caused by methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase deficiency. However, a deficiency of this enzyme would be expected to result in a decrease in serum methionine concentration, not an increase.

question_text: A 28-year-old African American woman delivers her first child at 39 weeks' gestation. On examination, the newborn's skin and hair have a milky white color, and his eyes are light blue with a slight reddish hue. A skin biopsy shows a normal number of epidermal and follicular melanocytes. The physician advises the parents that the child will need a comprehensive eye examination and genetic testing to establish the suspected diagnosis. A defect in which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 28-year-old African American woman delivers her first child at 39 weeks' gestation. On examination, the newborn's skin and hair have a milky white color, and his eyes are light blue with a slight reddish hue. A skin biopsy shows a normal number of epidermal and follicular melanocytes. The physician advises the parents that the child will need a comprehensive eye examination and genetic testing to establish the suspected diagnosis. A defect in which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Dihydroxyphenalanine (DOPA), an intermediate compound in the synthesis of catecholamines, serves as one of the substrates of this enzyme. A deficiency of this enzyme will result in oculocutaneous albinism, as seen in this patient.
learning_objective: Recognize oculocutaneous albinism type 1, and recall the enzyme deficiency associated with it.

answers.explanation_why: A defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase is responsible for classic phenylketonuria (PKU), a disorder characterized by phenylalanine accumulation and tyrosine deficiency. If untreated, patients with PKU develop generalized hypopigmentation, as seen here, because tyrosine is a precursor of melanin and high phenylalanine levels inhibit the enzyme responsible for melanin synthesis. However, the clinical features of PKU are not seen at birth because the fetus obtains tyrosine from maternal blood, and excess phenylalanine (as well as its toxic byproducts) is removed by the placenta. The features of PKU (e.g., hypopigmentation, seizures, intellectual disability, a musty odor) typically develop during infancy following the initiation of feeding.

A defect in DOPA decarboxylase leads to a deficiency in dopamine, an important neurotransmitter in the central nervous system. During infancy, patients with DOPA decarboxylase deficiency present with hypotonia, athetosis, lethargy, and poor feeding, none of which are seen in this patient. This patient's presentation is not consistent with a defect in DOPA decarboxylase.

Tyrosine kinase is primarily involved in signal transduction and cell proliferation. Defects in tyrosine kinase can result, e.g., in Bruton agammaglobulinemia (loss of function mutation of the BTK), chronic myeloid leukemia (gain of function mutation of BCR-ABL), or multiple endocrine neoplasia (gain of function mutation of RET). This patient's condition is caused by a defect in a different enzyme.

Tyrosinase is a copper-containing enzyme in melanocytes that produces melanin from dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA), which is derived from tyrosine by the action of tyrosine hydroxylase or tyrosinase itself. Tyrosinase is encoded by the TYR gene on chromosome 11; a defect in this gene is responsible for oculocutaneous albinism type 1 (OCA1), which manifests as hypopigmentation of the hair, skin, and irides with a normal density of melanocytes on skin biopsy, as seen here. The neurological and physical development of infants with OCA1 is similar to that of normal infants, but they have an increased risk of skin cancer and visual abnormalities and therefore need to undergo skin and eye screenings periodically.

images.title: Biosynthesis and breakdown of catecholamines
images.description: Overview of the biosynthesis and breakdown of the catecholamines dopamine, norepinephrine and epinephrine, starting with the amino acid phenylalanine and showing enzymes (blue text) and cofactors (blue highlighting).The glucocorticoid cortisol induces expression of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase and thus the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. The drug carbidopa (used, e.g., in Parkinson disease) inhibits DOPA decarboxylase and thus the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine.Congenital diseases may occur due to enzyme deficiencies, as shown here for phenylketonuria (1; defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase), albinism (2; defect in tyrosinase), and alkaptonuria (3; defect in homogentisate oxidase).

answers.explanation_why: A defect in homogentisate oxidase (alkaptonuria) leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and manifests as ochronosis, a blue-black discoloration of the skin, cartilage, tendons, and body fluids that come in contact with air (e.g., urine). The generalized hypopigmentation in this patient is not consistent with a defect in homogentisate oxidase.

Phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT) is mainly found in the adrenal medulla and catalyzes the formation of epinephrine from norepinephrine. A deficiency of this enzyme is not the cause of this newborn's condition.

question_text:
A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother's first pregnancy ended in stillbirth with hydrops fetalis at 35 weeks' gestation. She did not receive prenatal care during either pregnancy and refused postnatal screening after the first pregnancy. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She lives in Pennsylvania and there is no history of international travel. The newborn appears pale and lethargic. He is at the 10th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. He does not move his extremities spontaneously. Examination shows pallor of the mucosal membranes and jaundice. His spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. The remainder of the examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
9.8 g/dL

Hematocrit
26%

Reticulocyte count
21%

Serum

 Bilirubin, total

15.3 mg/dL

 Direct

1.1 mg/dL

 Aspartate aminotransferase
22 U/L

 Alanine aminotransferase
17 U/L

 Lactate dehydrogenase

820 U/L

A direct antiglobulin test is negative. A peripheral blood smear shows a few echinocytes and polychromasia consistent with reticulocytosis. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase assay show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother's first pregnancy ended in stillbirth with hydrops fetalis at 35 weeks' gestation. She did not receive prenatal care during either pregnancy and refused postnatal screening after the first pregnancy. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She lives in Pennsylvania and there is no history of international travel. The newborn appears pale and lethargic. He is at the 10th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. He does not move his extremities spontaneously. Examination shows pallor of the mucosal membranes and jaundice. His spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. The remainder of the examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL Hematocrit 26% Reticulocyte count 21% Serum Bilirubin, total 15.3 mg/dL Direct 1.1 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase 22 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 17 U/L Lactate dehydrogenase 820 U/L A direct antiglobulin test is negative. A peripheral blood smear shows a few echinocytes and polychromasia consistent with reticulocytosis. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase assay show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Low hemoglobin with an increased reticulocyte count, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, increased LDH, and a negative Coombs test indicate nonimmune hemolytic anemia. The mother's history of stillbirth due to hydrops fetalis suggests a hereditary disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize pyruvate kinase deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD) is an autosomal recessive enzyme defect of the glycolytic pathway that results in extravascular hemolytic anemia. It is the second most prevalent erythrocyte enzyme disorder (after glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency). A higher incidence has been observed within Pennsylvania Amish communities, most likely as a result of the founder effect. The severity of the disease is highly variable; PKD can manifest with fetal demise due to hydrops fetalis, symptomatic anemia from birth that requires lifelong transfusions, or chronic compensated hemolysis. A peripheral blood smear typically shows normal erythrocyte morphology, but echinocytes are sometimes seen. Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring pyruvate kinase enzyme activity.

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection can manifest with jaundice, splenomegaly, lethargy, and hypotonia. While congenital CMV infection also occasionally causes hemolytic anemia, this patient lacks other characteristic features of this condition, such as chorioretinitis, hearing loss, and hepatomegaly with transaminitis.

images.title: Congenital CMV infection TORCH fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Fanconi anemia (FA) has a wide variety of clinical manifestations, which include neonatal anemia. However, FA typically causes aplastic anemia with a decreased reticulocyte count rather than hemolytic anemia. Moreover, most newborns with FA present with congenital anomalies such as café-au-lait spots, microcephaly, thumb and forearm malformations, and eye and ear abnormalities. Finally, although FA is a hereditary disorder that can affect multiple children with the same biological parents, stillbirth due to FA is unlikely.

Congenital parvovirus B19 infection can cause severe neonatal anemia and hydrops fetalis. However, it typically causes aplastic anemia with a decreased reticulocyte count rather than hemolytic anemia, and vertical transmission of parvovirus B19 cannot occur in multiple pregnancies since infection during one pregnancy confers maternal immunity against subsequent infection. The anemia in this newborn and the hydrops fetalis of the stillborn sibling have a different underlying cause.

Classic galactosemia can manifest with jaundice, lethargy, hypotonia, and hemolytic anemia in a newborn. However, patients only become symptomatic after being fed several times with breast milk and/or routine formula. Moreover, the initial presentation typically includes vomiting and hepatomegaly. Finally, although classic galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that can affect multiple children of asymptomatic parents, it does not cause stillbirth.

question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 6-month history of progressive difficulty walking and speaking. Her parents also report that she has recently started having trouble feeding herself and appears to be losing interest in playing. She was born at full term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery, and her early development was within normal limits. Family history is notable for a paternal aunt who had a progressive neurological disorder and died in her early 20s. On examination, the girl is listless and has difficulty following commands. She has poor head control and generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished in all four extremities. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic atrophy. Nerve conduction studies show symmetrically decreased conduction velocities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 6-month history of progressive difficulty walking and speaking. Her parents also report that she has recently started having trouble feeding herself and appears to be losing interest in playing. She was born at full term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery, and her early development was within normal limits. Family history is notable for a paternal aunt who had a progressive neurological disorder and died in her early 20s. On examination, the girl is listless and has difficulty following commands. She has poor head control and generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished in all four extremities. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic atrophy. Nerve conduction studies show symmetrically decreased conduction velocities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Deficient enzyme activity in leukocytes helps establish the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features and diagnosis of metachromatic leukodystrophy.

answers.explanation_why: Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) is caused by hexosaminidase A deficiency, leading to GM2 ganglioside accumulation and progressive neurodegeneration. Symptoms typically appear at 3–6 months of age and include developmental delay, hypotonia, and characteristic ophthalmological findings. In TSD, however, the hallmark ocular feature is a cherry-red spot on the macula, not optic nerve atrophy, and patients have hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia. Peripheral neuropathy and decreased nerve conduction velocity are not features of TSD. Additionally, this patient does not have other expected manifestations of TSD, such as hyperacusis and seizures.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by arylsulfatase A (ARSA) deficiency, resulting in the accumulation of sulfatides that are toxic to oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This leads to progressive demyelination in both the central and peripheral nervous systems. Childhood onset is characterized by psychomotor regression, impaired memory, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, ataxia, and optic nerve atrophy that can lead to vision loss. Nerve conduction studies reveal decreased velocities due to demyelination. Metachromatic leukodystrophy is diagnosed by finding deficient ARSA enzyme activity in peripheral blood leukocytes or dried blood spots, and/or by identifying pathogenic mutations in the ARSA gene. A positive family history of progressive neurological decline supports the diagnosis of genetic leukodystrophy.

Krabbe disease is caused by galactocerebrosidase deficiency, which leads to progressive demyelination. In childhood, this condition typically manifests with significant mental and motor deficits, including developmental delay, peripheral neuropathy, and optic nerve atrophy that can lead to vision loss. However, Krabbe disease commonly manifests within the first year of life, and affected infants initially have limb stiffness rather than hypotonia.

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene. This condition almost exclusively affects girls and manifests with neurodevelopmental regression, including loss of motor skills, intellectual and verbal disability, and ataxia. Peripheral neuropathy, decreased nerve conduction velocity, hypotonia, and optic atrophy are not features of Rett syndrome. Additionally, this patient does not present with typical symptoms of the condition, such as scoliosis, hyperventilation, microcephaly, and characteristic hand wringing.

Niemann-Pick disease (NPD) is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency that leads to sphingomyelin accumulation and progressive neurodegeneration. NPD typically manifests with psychomotor regression, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and characteristic ophthalmological findings. However, the hallmark ocular finding in NPD is a cherry-red spot on the macula, not optic nerve atrophy. Peripheral neuropathy and decreased nerve conduction velocity are not features of NPD. In addition, this patient does not have common systemic findings of NPD, such as hepatosplenomegaly.
